Elizabeth is deeply impressed by the beauty of the house and grounds, and by the housekeeper's glowing account of Mr. Darcy as a kind master, landlord, and brother, contrasting sharply with Wickham's portrayal. Unexpectedly, Mr. Darcy returns early and encounters Elizabeth and the Gardiners at Pemberley. He is civil and attentive, surprising Elizabeth and her aunt and uncle. He invites them to dinner the next day and asks to introduce his sister, Georgiana. The Gardiners observe Darcy's clear partiality for Elizabeth.

At Pemberley, Elizabeth is introduced to the shy and amiable Miss Darcy. Mr. Bingley also arrives, expressing his unaffected cordiality. Miss Bingley, still present, attempts to insult Elizabeth by mentioning the Meryton militia and Wickham. Darcy defends Elizabeth, and later, when Miss Bingley criticizes Elizabeth's looks, Darcy declares Elizabeth to be "one of the handsomest women of my acquaintance."

Elizabeth receives two urgent letters from Jane, revealing Lydia has eloped with Wickham from Brighton. The second letter confirms Wickham has no intention of marrying her. Jane reports that Mr. Bennet is in London searching for them, and implores Mr. Gardiner's help. Elizabeth, distraught, accidentally encounters Darcy again and tearfully reveals Lydia's disgrace. Darcy is visibly distressed. He offers his assistance to the Gardiners, who are rushing to London. Elizabeth feels she has lost any chance with Darcy due to her family's shame.

Mr. Gardiner finds Lydia and Wickham in London. Wickham had never intended to marry Lydia. Darcy, feeling responsible for not exposing Wickham's true character earlier, finds them and negotiates the marriage himself. He pays off Wickham's substantial gambling debts and buys him a commission in a northern regiment, also settling an additional £1000 on Lydia, beyond her eventual inheritance. He insists on bearing all the expense, refusing Mr. Gardiner's offer to share it, stating it was his duty to remedy the situation caused by his own pride and reserve. Mr. Bennet is informed of the settlement and reluctantly agrees to Lydia marrying Wickham, though he refuses to provide new clothes or receive them at Longbourn. Mrs. Bennet, however, is ecstatic about Lydia's marriage, ignoring the scandalous circumstances. Elizabeth is deeply grateful and humbled by Darcy's magnanimity, realizing he did it for her sake.

Mr. Bennet is eventually persuaded by Jane and Elizabeth to allow Lydia and Wickham to visit Longbourn after their marriage. Lydia arrives, unabashed and boastful of her marriage. She casually mentions that Mr. Darcy was present at her wedding. Elizabeth, astonished, writes to Mrs. Gardiner for an explanation. Mrs. Gardiner's reply confirms Darcy's extraordinary role in arranging and financing the marriage, and she expresses her high esteem for him. Elizabeth is overwhelmed by gratitude and a newfound love for Darcy.

Bingley returns to Netherfield and quickly renews his attentions to Jane. Mrs. Bennet's persistent efforts to leave them alone finally lead to Bingley proposing to Jane, who joyfully accepts. The family is delighted. Mr. Bennet, though teasing, expresses his sincere happiness for Jane.

Lady Catherine de Bourgh, having heard a rumor of Darcy's impending marriage to Elizabeth, unexpectedly visits Longbourn to demand that Elizabeth promise never to marry Darcy, asserting Darcy is destined for her own daughter. Elizabeth firmly refuses, defending her right to choose. Lady Catherine is enraged and departs. Elizabeth realizes that Lady Catherine's aggressive interference actually gave Darcy hope that Elizabeth was not entirely against him, as she would have explicitly denied her feelings if she intended to marry someone else.

Darcy returns to Longbourn. Elizabeth, seizing the moment, thanks him for his kindness to Lydia. Darcy admits his actions were partly motivated by his desire to make her happy, acknowledging he thought "only of you." He then confesses his feelings for her are unchanged and asks if hers are still as they were. Elizabeth, with embarrassment, admits her sentiments have changed and she receives his assurances with gratitude and pleasure. Darcy reveals Lady Catherine's visit, which, by prompting Elizabeth's steadfast refusal to promise not to marry him, gave him hope that she was not irrevocably against him. He also explains how her reproof of his initial arrogant proposal "tortured" him and led him to self-reflection and humility. He admits his initial purpose for returning to Netherfield was to see her and gauge her feelings.

Mr. Bennet gives his consent to Elizabeth's marriage to Darcy, after Elizabeth explains her change of heart and reveals Darcy's generosity to Lydia. Mrs. Bennet is ecstatic about Elizabeth marrying such a wealthy and distinguished man, her earlier dislike for him vanishing entirely. She focuses on the grand benefits of the match. Mr. Bennet dryly comments on his daughters' successful marriages.

Miss Bingley is mortified by Darcy's marriage but quickly sets aside her resentment to maintain social standing. Lady Catherine de Bourgh is initially indignant and sends an abusive letter, but Elizabeth eventually persuades Darcy to seek reconciliation. Lady Catherine's resentment gives way to curiosity and affection, and she visits them at Pemberley.

Bingley and Jane remain at Netherfield for a year, then move to an estate closer to Pemberley. Kitty, removed from Lydia's influence, matures. Mary remains at home. Wickham and Lydia, however, remain extravagant and heedless, frequently needing financial assistance from Jane and Elizabeth. Darcy, for Elizabeth's sake, helps Wickham in his profession.

The story concludes with Darcy and Elizabeth happily married at Pemberley, and Bingley and Jane settled nearby. They maintain close relationships with the Gardiners. Darcy's initial pride and Elizabeth's initial prejudice are overcome through self-reflection, understanding, and the revealing of true character, leading to a loving and respectful union.

The narrative begins with Robinson Crusoe, born in York in 1632 to a German father and an English mother from the Robinson family. His original name was Kreutznaer, but it was corrupted to Crusoe. He had two elder brothers; one was killed in Flanders, the fate of the other is unknown. Despite his aging father's earnest advice to settle into a "middle state" of life to avoid misery and hardship, Robinson was filled with "rambling thoughts" and a strong desire to go to sea. His father tearfully warned him against this "foolish step," predicting God would not bless him.

Initially affected, Robinson soon forgot his resolution. At eighteen, he tried to persuade his mother to let him make one voyage, promising to return if he disliked it. His mother refused, and his father, upon hearing of it, sighed that Robinson would be "the most miserable wretch that ever was born" if he went abroad.

Almost a year later, in September 1651, Robinson went to Hull and, without his parents' blessing, embarked on a ship bound for London with a companion. Immediately, a violent storm arose, terrifying him and prompting vows of repentance. However, when the storm abated, his companion mocked his fears, and Robinson, drinking punch, drowned his repentance and resolutions. Six days later, while anchored in Yarmouth Roads, an even more dreadful storm struck. The ship became disabled, sprang a leak, and the crew, including Robinson, worked desperately at the pumps. They were rescued by a boat from another ship, and minutes later, their ship sank. All eleven men in the boat eventually reached shore near Yarmouth.

Despite this "visible instruction," Robinson's "ill fate" compelled him to continue. Ashamed to return home, he travelled to London by land. His former companion's father, who was the master of the shipwrecked vessel, warned him against going to sea again, suggesting his misfortunes were a sign from Heaven. Robinson was undeterred.

In London, he met a shipmaster who had been to Guinea (Africa) and offered him free passage as a messmate. Robinson, with £40 worth of goods, made this his first successful venture, learning navigation and returning with nearly £300 in gold-dust. This success fueled his ambition. The honest captain, his friend, died soon after. Robinson, with £200 of his earnings, embarked on a second voyage to Guinea with the former mate, now captain. This proved disastrous. Their ship was attacked and captured by a Turkish rover from Sallee. Robinson was taken to Sallee, a port of the Moors, and became the rover captain's slave for two years, performing household chores and looking after the ship.

He constantly plotted escape. An opportunity arose when his master often went fishing, taking Robinson and a boy named Xury. Robinson used the master's refitted long-boat, intended for fishing, to escape. He tricked a Moorish kinsman into loading provisions and ammunition, then tossed the Moor overboard and threatened to shoot him if he tried to return. The Moor swam to shore. Robinson secured the loyalty of the boy, Xury, who swore fidelity.

He steered south along the African coast for five days, covering 150 miles beyond the Emperor of Morocco's dominions. They landed for fresh water, encountering wild beasts at night. Xury bravely shot a hare-like creature for food. They continued south, encountering naked black natives who traded dried meat and corn for signs of thanks. Robinson shot a leopard that attacked them, astonishing the natives, who then helped him secure the skin and offered more food and water.

After eleven more days, they reached the Cape de Verde Islands. Spotting a Portuguese ship, Robinson signaled distress. A Scottish sailor on board helped him communicate, and the captain, hearing of his escape from slavery, took them aboard. The generous captain refused payment, promising safe passage and delivery of all his goods in Brazil. He bought Robinson's boat for 80 pieces of eight and Xury for 60 pieces of eight, promising Xury freedom in ten years if he became a Christian.

They arrived in Brazil, where Robinson, with the proceeds from his goods (around 220 pieces of eight), became a planter. He bought land, acquired a Black slave and two European servants, and began cultivating tobacco and sugar cane. He arranged for £100 of his money from London to be sent to him in goods, which arrived with tools. This initial success and prosperity again led to ambition. After four years, he agreed to join three fellow planters on a secret, illegal slave-trading voyage to Guinea, acting as supercargo for a share of the slaves, despite the risks and leaving his thriving plantation behind. He made a will, naming the Portuguese captain his heir.

On September 1, 1659, exactly eight years after his first ill-fated voyage, Robinson set sail. After crossing the equator, a violent hurricane drove them for twelve days, claiming one life and washing two others overboard. The ship was disabled and leaking. They changed course for Barbados, but a second storm struck. The ship ran aground near an unknown island. All eleven men in the boat, including Robinson, were then caught by a raging wave and swallowed by the sea. Robinson was the only survivor, washed ashore, half-dead, and bruised against rocks.

Stranded, he found fresh water and slept in a tree for safety from wild beasts. The next morning, he discovered the ship had floated closer to shore. He swam to it and, over several days, made eleven trips on a self-built raft, salvaging provisions (food, rum), tools (carpenter's chest, grindstone, hatchets, saws, axes), weapons (guns, pistols, powder, shot, swords), clothes, bedding, and even money (which he initially considered useless). On his last trip, a storm broke up the ship completely.

He built a fortified habitation: a tent under a rock face, surrounded by a double fence of stakes and cables, further reinforced with earth. He dug a cave behind it, creating various compartments. A lightning storm made him fear for his gunpowder, so he divided it into many small, hidden parcels. He established a daily routine of hunting (killing goats and fowls), exploring, and working on his habitation. To keep track of time, he cut notches on a large post. He found he had salvaged Bibles, other books, pens, ink, and paper. His dog had swum ashore, and he kept two cats.

Robinson fell ill with a violent ague, experiencing a profound spiritual awakening. He prayed earnestly, reflected on his past sins, and found solace in reading the Bible. He discovered corn and rice growing from spoiled chicken feed he had discarded, seeing it as a sign of Providence. He carefully harvested and replanted, eventually learning to cultivate two crops a year. He also made basic pottery, a wooden mortar, and sieves from old neckcloths to process his grain, and learned to bake bread. He built a "country bower" or second dwelling in a fruitful valley on the island, complete with its own fence.

After several years, he built a large canoe, but realized it was too heavy to launch. He then built a smaller periagua (canoe) and, after digging a canal, successfully launched it into the creek. On a voyage to circumnavigate the island, he was caught in a strong current and swept far out to sea, again fearing loss. He eventually found an eddy and, using a favorable wind, returned to the island. This terrifying experience made him resolve to stop venturing out to sea.

During his eleventh year, he started breeding tame goats to ensure a steady food supply as his powder dwindled. He set pitfalls and caught three kids, which he successfully tamed. He built strong enclosures for his growing flock, eventually having over 40 goats, and learned to make butter and cheese.

In his twenty-third year, while harvesting, he saw a fire on his side of the island. He took defensive measures and, from a hill with his spyglass, observed nine naked savages engaged in a cannibal feast. He was filled with horror and rage, considering an attack, but ultimately decided against it, believing it was not his place to judge or punish them. He relocated his boat to a hidden cove to avoid discovery.

A year and a half later, in his twenty-fourth year, a storm brought a shipwreck to the east side of his island. He heard distress guns and lit a signal fire. The next day, he found the wreck of a Spanish ship and, to his sorrow, a drowned boy. He was overwhelmed with a longing for human companionship. He ventured to the wreck, finding a living dog (which he rescued) and the bodies of two drowned men. He salvaged useful items, including a large quantity of money which he considered useless but took anyway, and some provisions.

Robinson continued to live in heightened caution. After two more years, he had a vivid dream of savages landing with a prisoner, who escaped and ran to his grove. In the dream, he rescued the savage, who became his servant. This dream spurred him to actively seek a servant/companion.

One morning, he observed five canoes and thirty savages on his side of the island, preparing another cannibal feast with two prisoners. He positioned himself with Friday (his newly acquired servant, whom he named after the day of his rescue). Friday, an agile and loyal young savage, was about to be eaten by his enemies. Robinson, overriding his moral scruples, intervened, shooting some of the pursuers and knocking down another. Friday, amazed by the guns, then skillfully beheaded the stunned savage with Robinson's sword. They burned the remains of the feast.

To Robinson's great joy, the second prisoner turned out to be Friday's father. After their emotional reunion, Robinson, Friday, and his father (a "Pagan and a cannibal") and the rescued Spaniard (a "Papist") formed a small community. Robinson gave them clothes, provided food, and instructed Friday and his father in Christianity. Friday proved a quick and loyal student.

The escaped savages, terrified by the "thunder and lightning" of the guns, never returned. The Spaniard recounted that sixteen of his countrymen and Portuguese were shipwrecked on the mainland, living among savages, but in dire need. Robinson, after much deliberation and securing a solemn oath of fidelity from the Spaniard, agreed to help them. They expanded their plantations for six months to ensure enough provisions for the larger group.

When ready, the Spaniard and Friday's father departed in a canoe to retrieve the others. Eight days later, Friday rushed to Robinson, announcing the arrival of another boat. Robinson, from his lookout, saw an English ship at anchor and an English long-boat landing. A "secret hint" filled him with suspicion. He observed mutineers landing with three bound prisoners. He learned from the ship's captain, one of the prisoners, that his crew had mutinied.

Robinson, with Friday, the captain, his mate, and a passenger, strategically attacked the mutineers. They rescued the three prisoners, disabled one of the mutineers' boats, and captured some of the mutineers on shore. Robinson (presenting himself as "Governor" of the island with a large army) forced the captured mutineers to cooperate in recovering the ship. The captain, with his loyal men and some re-armed former mutineers, successfully retook the ship after a brief struggle that resulted in the death of the rebel captain.

Overwhelmed with joy and gratitude, Robinson received abundant provisions and new clothes from the captain. He offered the remaining incorrigible mutineers the choice of being left on the island or taken to England for trial and probable hanging. They chose to stay. Robinson provided them with firearms, tools, seeds, and instructions on how to survive, making them promise to treat the expected Spaniards well. He also sent two of the originally unrepentant mutineers, who had since begged for mercy, to the ship.

On December 19, 1686, after twenty-eight years, two months, and nineteen days, Robinson left the island. He took his goat-skin cap, umbrella, one parrot, and the money he had salvaged. He arrived in England in June 1687. He found his father and mother dead, and his family mostly extinct, but discovered two sisters and two nephews. He rewarded his old benefactress, the widow, and his sisters. The ship owners also gave him £200 for saving their vessel.

Driven by a desire to check on his Brazil plantation, he travelled to Lisbon with Friday. He was reunited with his old Portuguese captain, who informed him of the great wealth his plantation had accumulated over the years, despite the king and a monastery having taken a share. Robinson generously rewarded the old captain and his son, granting them annuities from his estate. He then secured his claim to the plantation, receiving bills of exchange and a vast cargo of sugar, tobacco, and gold.

Now extremely wealthy, Robinson, after initial sickness from the shock of his good fortune, distributed his wealth further. He resolved against sea travel again, due to past misfortunes and a "strong impulse" to avoid it. He chose to travel by land through France, accompanied by Friday and several other gentlemen and servants. They faced a perilous journey through the snow-covered Pyrenees, encountering and fighting off multiple wolf attacks, and Friday bravely killing a bear.

After many adventures and challenges, they reached Dover, England, in January. Robinson settled his affairs, sold his Brazilian estate, and married, having three children. His wife died. Years later, influenced by his adventurous nephew, Robinson, though old, embarked on a new voyage to the East Indies in 1694. On this journey, he revisited his island. He found the men he had left there, along with the Spaniards, who had faced their own struggles against mutineers and Caribbean invaders. The Spaniards had also rescued more men and women, resulting in about twenty children on the island. Robinson stayed twenty days, providing supplies, arms, and two workmen (a carpenter and a smith). He divided the land among them, reserving ultimate property rights for himself. He then sent more settlers and livestock (cows, sheep, hogs) from Brazil. The narrative concludes with a promise to recount further surprising incidents from his subsequent ten years of adventures in a second part of his story.

book_title: Six Characters in Search of an Author-Luigi Pirandello
summary_llm:
The play opens on a bare stage set for a rehearsal of a Pirandello play, "Mixing It Up." The theatrical company, including a Manager, a Prompter, and various actors, is preparing for the second act. The Manager expresses his frustration with modern comedies and Pirandello's work, which he finds absurd and difficult to understand. He instructs the Property Man on set details and bickers with a Leading Man about wearing a cook's cap, explaining the symbolic meaning of the part.

During this rehearsal, six mysterious figures—The Father, The Mother, The Step-Daughter, The Son, The Boy, and The Child—enter the stage, surrounded by a faint, dreamlike light. They interrupt the rehearsal, stating they are "characters in search of an author" because the author who created them abandoned their drama. The Manager and actors are initially annoyed and skeptical, believing the newcomers to be mad.

The Father explains that they carry an unfinished drama within them and seek someone to stage it. The Step-Daughter, vivacious and impudent, quickly engages, suggesting they could be the Manager's new play. She alludes to her "passion" for the Father and reveals that she, The Boy, and The Child are the Mother's illegitimate children, despised by The Son, who is the Father's legitimate son. The Mother, dressed in black and seemingly crushed by shame, attempts to prevent the full story from being revealed.

Through a series of urgent and conflicting revelations, the Characters' story unfolds:
The Father states that The Mother had a lover, who has recently died, and that her drama revolves around her four children by two men. The Mother protests, claiming the Father forced her to leave him and their first son (The Son) to live with the other man. The Step-Daughter disputes this, saying The Mother lived happily with her second partner and only blames the Father to appease The Son, whom she abandoned.

The Father admits he sent The Mother away, well-provided for, to be free of him, but also admits it was a liberation for himself. He claims he later watched over the new family, particularly the Step-Daughter, out of "pure interest." The Step-Daughter confirms he used to follow her from school, bringing her gifts, which her mother eventually noticed.

The drama intensifies when The Father describes his own "wretchedness" as a man seeking female companionship. He reveals that after the Step-Daughter's second father died, The Mother and her three children fell into misery and returned to the city, unknown to him. The Mother began working as a modiste for Madame Pace, a woman who used poor girls to attract clients. The Step-Daughter recounts how she herself was exploited by Madame Pace and how, one day, The Father entered the shop and was about to engage in a shameful act with her (the Step-Daughter) before The Mother arrived and recognized him. The Father claims he recognized The Mother "in time" and brought them all back to his house.

The Son expresses profound disgust and shame at this entire narrative, declaring himself an "unrealized character" who wants no part in their "vulgar" drama. He feels like an intruder in his own home. The Father, however, insists The Son is central to the action, particularly in his cruel aloofness towards his reunited mother and the younger children. He explains that the full drama culminates in the disappearance of the extraneous family (Step-Daughter, Boy, Child) and the resulting desolation between himself, The Mother, and The Son.

Despite the chaotic and deeply personal nature of the Characters' story, the Manager becomes increasingly intrigued, seeing its potential for a "drama." The Father proposes that the Manager become their author and stage their story, taking it down scene by scene as they perform it. The Manager, though initially hesitant, is tempted by the novelty and agrees to try. The performance is then interrupted for a brief meeting in the Manager's office.

**Act II** begins after the interruption. The Step-Daughter, The Boy, and The Child emerge from the office. The Step-Daughter expresses dissatisfaction with the arrangements and playfully tells The Child that they are about to "act a comedy, dead serious." She notices The Boy holding a revolver and mockingly suggests he should shoot the Father and Son instead of himself. The Son enters, lamenting his inability to escape the situation and his shame at having his family's private life exposed.

The Manager returns with The Father and The Step-Daughter, and they begin preparing the stage for Madame Pace's shop, with The Step-Daughter meticulously insisting on details like a yellow, flowered sofa and a specific small table. The Manager instructs the Prompter to take down the dialogue in shorthand.

The Manager then tries to cast the actors in the Characters' roles. The Characters strongly object, especially The Step-Daughter, who finds the Leading Lady utterly unlike her. The Father argues that actors cannot truly embody their inherent "temperaments" and "souls," which are their fixed reality, whereas the actors merely "pretend." The Manager asserts that the actors give "body and form" to the characters and that the "spirit of the piece" is created by their performance, not inherent in the Characters themselves.

To everyone's surprise, when the stage is set for Madame Pace's shop (with hats and cloaks from the actresses hung up), Madame Pace herself materializes on stage, drawn by the "articles of her trade." The scene between the Step-Daughter and Madame Pace spontaneously begins, with Madame Pace speaking in a comical, unintelligible jargon. The Mother, previously quiet, suddenly cries out, calling Madame Pace a "murderess."

The Step-Daughter then directs The Father in his entry, instructing him on his tone and gestures. As The Father performs the scene where he offers the Step-Daughter a hat, The Mother watches in anguished sobs. The Step-Daughter delivers a line about being in mourning, and The Father replies, "Ah well, then let's take off this little frock." The Manager, horrified, tries to cut the line, deeming it unsuitable for the stage. The Step-Daughter vehemently insists on the "truth" of her experience, including the Father's proposition and her subsequent disgust, threatening to leave if the scene is not accurately portrayed. She asserts that the Father is responsible for her "faults" even before her birth.

The Mother, overwhelmed, explains that her torment is "not a pretended one" and that she "lives and feels every minute of my torture," with the children serving to make her suffering "actual and vivid." The Father adds that The Step-Daughter is here to "fix me, and hold me eternally in the stocks for that one fleeting and shameful moment of my life." The Step-Daughter physically re-enacts the near-encounter, leaning on the Father's chest and describing feeling a vein pulse, which awakened "disgust." She prompts The Mother to "Cry out as you did then!" The Mother cries out and rushes to separate them, calling the Father a "brute." The Manager, pleased with the dramatic climax, calls for the curtain, which is then accidentally lowered completely by the Machinist.

**Act III** opens with the stage crew having quickly changed the scenery to a garden with trees and a fountain basin. The Characters are grouped, with The Son still aloof. The Manager discusses the challenges of staging multiple locations simultaneously. The Father passionately objects to the use of the word "illusion," explaining that what is a "game of art" for the actors is the Characters' "sole reality," a fixed and immutable reality that contrasts with the transitory nature of human existence. He argues that characters have a life independent of their authors.

The Manager, growing frustrated with the Father's "philosophizing," insists on action over discussion. The Step-Daughter describes her only pleasure as seeing The Child play happily in the garden, away from their shared squalor. She alludes to The Boy being "consumed" by some "project" indoors.

The Manager attempts to stage a scene in the garden. The Step-Daughter declares The Boy will not speak as long as The Son is present, prompting The Son to try to leave. The Step-Daughter stops him, asserting he "can't go away" as he is "indissolubly bound to the chain." The Son defiantly states he will not act, insisting he was dragged there by The Father and that the author never wanted them on stage. He claims he walked out of his room to avoid a scene with The Mother.

The Manager presses The Son for details about what happened next in the garden. The Son reluctantly reveals that he saw The Child in the fountain. The Father adds that The Mother was following The Son at that moment. The Son then describes running to save The Child, but seeing The Boy standing motionless, "with eyes like a madman's, watching his little drowned sister, in the fountain!" As The Step-Daughter bends over the fountain prop, sobbing, a revolver shot rings out from behind the trees where The Boy is hidden.

The Mother screams and rushes towards the sound. Actors declare The Boy is "dead!", while others claim it's "only make believe, it's only pretence!" The Father cries out, "Pretence? Reality, sir, reality!" The Manager, utterly exasperated and frustrated by the day's events, dismisses it all, declaring, "To hell with it all! Never in my life has such a thing happened to me. I've lost a whole day over these people, a whole day!" The curtain falls.

book_title: The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn-Mark Twain
summary_llm:
Huckleberry Finn (Huck) begins by explaining that he and Tom Sawyer became rich after finding money hidden by robbers in a cave, each receiving $6,000. Judge Thatcher invested their money, providing a dollar a day. Huck was adopted by the Widow Douglas, who tried to "sivilize" him with proper manners, clothes, and religious instruction from her sister, Miss Watson. Finding this life stifling, Huck ran away, but Tom Sawyer convinced him to return by promising him a place in a new band of robbers.

That night, Huck secretly met Tom. While sneaking through the Widow's garden, they narrowly avoided being discovered by Jim, Miss Watson's slave, who later boasted that witches rode him all over the state, a story that earned him local fame. The boys then gathered other friends (Joe Harper, Ben Rogers) and went to a hidden cave to form "Tom Sawyer's Gang." The gang took a blood oath to keep secrets and kill anyone who wronged a member's family. When it was pointed out Huck had no family to avenge, he offered Miss Watson. They planned to be "highwaymen," robbing and murdering travelers, and sometimes holding people for "ransom" (a concept Tom didn't fully understand but insisted on because it was "in the books"). They agreed to avoid killing women, instead bringing them to the cave to fall in love with the robbers. The gang's first "adventure" involved ambushing a "Spanish merchants and A-rabs" caravan, which turned out to be a Sunday-school picnic. Huck became disillusioned with Tom's fantastical adventures, especially when his attempt to summon genies from a lamp failed.

After several months of school, Huck saw distinctive boot tracks in the snow, realizing his abusive, drunken father, Pap, had returned. Fearing Pap would take his money, Huck went to Judge Thatcher and tried to give him all his wealth, which the Judge "bought" for a dollar. Huck then consulted Jim and his magic hair-ball, which predicted Huck would have trouble and joy, eventually marry, avoid water, and be hung. That night, Pap confronted Huck in his room, berating him for being "sivilized" and educated, and demanding his money. Pap took Huck's dollar for whiskey and threatened to beat him if he continued school. Pap tried to get Huck's money from Judge Thatcher through the courts, but a new judge wouldn't separate them. Pap spent borrowed money on alcohol, leading to jailings. Pap eventually kidnapped Huck, taking him to a secluded log cabin on the Illinois shore.

Pap kept Huck locked in the cabin, beating him frequently, especially when drunk. Huck initially enjoyed the free, wild life but eventually resolved to escape the constant abuse and confinement. During one of Pap's three-day absences, Huck found an old saw and began cutting through a log in the cabin wall. He devised an elaborate plan to fake his own death: he killed a wild pig, used its blood to stage a murder scene, smashed the cabin door, and created false trails leading away from the river to suggest robbers had killed him. He then hid in a stolen canoe on Jackson's Island.

On the island, Huck discovered Jim, Miss Watson's runaway slave, who was hiding after overhearing Miss Watson planning to sell him to New Orleans for $800. Jim was terrified, believing Huck was a ghost, but Huck reassured him. They decided to travel together down the Mississippi River on a raft. They appropriated a section of a lumber raft. One night, they boarded a wrecked steamboat to look for loot. Huck overheard three robbers (Jim Turner, Bill, and Jake Packard) arguing, with Bill wanting to kill Turner. Packard convinced Bill to leave Turner tied up to drown when the wreck broke up, avoiding the "risk" of murder. Huck and Jim escaped in the robbers' skiff just as their own raft broke loose. Huck felt pity for the trapped murderers and tried to get help for them from a ferryboat watchman, fabricating a story about a stranded family, but the wreck floated away before help could reach them.

Huck and Jim found their raft and continued downriver. They missed Cairo, the entrance to the free states, in a fog, realizing they were now traveling deeper into slave territory. A steamboat then accidentally smashed their raft, separating them. Huck swam to shore and stumbled upon the Grangerford family's house. He introduced himself as George Jackson and was welcomed into their home. He learned about the long-standing, violent feud between the Grangerfords and the Shepherdsons, which had resulted in many deaths on both sides. He befriended Buck Grangerford, a boy his age. He observed their strict, aristocratic ways and the pervasive violence. Miss Sophia Grangerford secretly used Huck to retrieve a note from church, which read "Half past two." Later, Jim (Huck's Jim) found Huck, revealing he had followed him and that the Grangerford "niggers" had helped him hide and even repaired their broken raft. Jim explained that Miss Sophia had run off to marry Harney Shepherdson, sparking a renewed outbreak of the feud. Huck witnessed a bloody gunfight between the families, seeing Buck and his cousin Joe shot while trying to escape into the river. Huck was horrified and fled. He found Jim, and they escaped on the repaired raft.

Further downriver, they picked up two con artists: an old man who claimed to be the rightful Duke of Bridgewater, and a younger man who claimed to be the lost Dauphin, Louis XVII of France. Huck quickly recognized them as frauds but played along to keep the peace. The "duke" and "king" immediately began devising schemes. They learned about the death of Peter Wilks and decided to impersonate his long-lost English brothers, Harvey (the preacher) and William (the deaf-mute). They gathered information about the family from a young man on a steamboat.

Upon arriving in the town, the "king" and "duke" put on a grand show of grief, convincing the townspeople and Peter Wilks's nieces (Mary Jane, Susan, and Joanna) of their identity. The will was read, revealing $6,000 in gold. Discovering they were $415 short, the king and duke made up the difference from their own money to maintain the illusion of legitimacy. The "duke" then had the brilliant idea to give the entire $6,000 to the girls, further cementing the town's trust. Only Dr. Robinson and lawyer Levi Bell suspected them, but their warnings were dismissed by the emotional townspeople. Huck, disgusted by the frauds, stole the $6,000 from their hiding place in the king's room, intending to give it back to the girls. He hid the money in Peter Wilks's coffin.

During the funeral, Huck was anxious about the money's discovery. The undertaker screwed down the coffin lid, leaving Huck uncertain if the money was still inside. The "king" then announced he and "William" would take the girls to England and immediately put all of Peter Wilks's property, including his slaves, up for auction. Huck was horrified when the "king" sold the "niggers," separating a mother from her children. Huck told Mary Jane the truth about the frauds and the money's location, convincing her to leave town so her face wouldn't betray her. He then convinced Mary Jane's sisters that she was visiting a sick friend, inventing a fantastical illness (the "pluribus-unum mumps") to explain her sudden departure and prevent them from telling the "uncles."

Just as the auction was ending, the real Harvey and William Wilks arrived. A chaotic scene ensued, with Dr. Robinson and Levi Bell challenging the "duke" and "king." The townspeople demanded proof of identity. The "king" and the real Harvey Wilks were both asked to write, revealing the "king's" illegible scrawl and Harvey's (copied by William) more convincing hand. The real Harvey then asked what was tattooed on Peter Wilks's breast. The "king" guessed a "blue arrow," but the men who laid out the corpse denied it. Harvey then claimed it was "P—B—W." The men again denied any marks. The crowd, now enraged, decided to dig up the corpse to verify. As they dug, Huck escaped in the confusion, but was intercepted by the "king" and "duke" who had also fled.

Huck lied to the "king" and "duke" that he had escaped when the gold was discovered, and that he was worried about their safety. The "king" and "duke" then had a furious argument, accusing each other of trying to double-cross the other by hiding the gold in the coffin. They eventually reconciled, both drunk. Huck, feeling he had to steal Jim out of slavery again, hid the raft and went to the Phelps plantation, where he discovered Jim was being held. Tom Sawyer then arrived and, to Huck's astonishment, agreed to help him "steal" Jim, but only by enacting a wildly elaborate and unnecessary escape plan full of "style" and "adventure," involving digging a tunnel with case-knives, making a rope ladder from sheets, and collecting various animals (rats, spiders, snakes) to keep Jim company. They even tricked Aunt Sally into believing that missing items (spoons, sheets, candles) were due to rats and her own absent-mindedness.

As they finalized their plan, Tom wrote anonymous warning letters to the Phelps family and staged signs (skull and crossbones, coffin) to terrorize them, claiming a gang of cutthroats was coming to steal Jim. He also wrote a final letter, supposedly from a reformed gang member, instructing the Phelpses to ambush the "cutthroats" by locking them in the cabin. The night of the escape, Huck, dressed in Aunt Sally's clothes, snuck to the cellar for butter. Aunt Sally caught him, thinking he had "brain-fever" as the butter melted down his face, and sent him to bed. Huck rushed to Tom, telling him the house was full of armed farmers waiting for the ambush. Tom, delighted by the added danger, insisted on proceeding. As the farmers entered the cabin, Huck, Jim, and Tom slipped out through their dug tunnel. Tom's britches caught on the fence, making a noise, and the farmers opened fire. They escaped through the woods, with the Phelps's dogs (who recognized them) running past them towards the noise. They reached their canoe and then the raft.

Tom revealed he had been shot in the calf. Jim refused to proceed without a doctor. Huck went to town, lying to a doctor that his brother had shot himself while hunting on an island. The doctor took Huck's canoe to treat Tom. Huck returned to the Phelps's, lying to Uncle Silas that he and "Sid" (Tom) had been out hunting the runaway "nigger." At dinner, the townspeople discussed the bizarre escape attempts from Jim's cabin, blaming the "nigger's" madness and accusing others of helping him. Aunt Sally, exhausted, confessed she had locked Huck and Tom in their room for safety. She pleaded with Huck (thinking he was Tom) not to go out again for her sake. The next morning, Aunt Sally received a letter from Tom's real Aunt Polly, who soon arrived. She revealed that the "Tom" at the house was actually Huck, and that the real Tom had been pretending to be Sid. She also revealed that Miss Watson had died two months ago and freed Jim in her will. Tom admitted he had intercepted Aunt Polly's letters.

Jim was freed from his chains. Aunt Polly, Uncle Silas, and Aunt Sally, upon learning how Jim had helped the doctor nurse Tom, treated him kindly. Tom gave Jim forty dollars for being a patient prisoner. Jim rejoiced, claiming his hairy breast sign for wealth had come true. Tom then proposed that he, Huck, and Jim go for "howling adventures amongst the Injuns, over in the territory." Huck worried he had no money, as Pap would have taken it. Tom revealed that Pap hadn't returned, and Huck's $6,000 was still with Judge Thatcher. Jim then solemnly revealed that the dead man in the floating house that Huck found on Jackson's Island was Pap.

Huck, tired of being "sivilized" by Aunt Sally, declared he would "light out for the territory ahead of the rest."

book_title: The Count of Monte Cristo-Alexandre Dumas
summary_llm:
This detailed plot summary is based *solely* on the provided text, without incorporating any external knowledge of the novel.

**Volume One**

**Chapter 1: Marseilles—The Arrival**
On February 24, 1815, the three-master ship, the _Pharaon_, arrives in Marseilles from Smyrna, Trieste, and Naples. Its owner, M. Morrel, quickly boards the vessel. He is met by Edmond Dantès, the young, active, and vigilant mate, aged eighteen or twenty. Dantès informs M. Morrel of a great misfortune: their brave Captain Leclere died of brain fever off Civita Vecchia. Despite this, the cargo is safe. Dantès explains that Captain Leclere, before dying, instructed him to deliver a packet to Marshal Bertrand on the Island of Elba. During this stop, Dantès even spoke with the Emperor Napoleon, who inquired about the ship and its owner, M. Morrel. M. Morrel is delighted by Dantès's skill and loyalty, and declares his intention to make Dantès the new captain of the _Pharaon_ after consulting his partner.

Danglars, the ship's supercargo, a man of twenty-five or twenty-six, with an unprepossessing countenance and an arrogant attitude towards subordinates, approaches M. Morrel. He expresses dislike for Dantès, criticizing his self-confidence and the stop at Elba, implying it was a whimsical delay. M. Morrel dismisses Danglars's complaints, affirming Dantès's actions were his duty. Dantès asks for some days' leave to visit his father and his betrothed, Mercédès, and then travel to Paris for Captain Leclere's commission. M. Morrel grants the leave, emphasizing that the _Pharaon_ cannot sail without Dantès as her captain, solidifying his promotion. As Dantès leaves, he mentions a past quarrel with Danglars near the island of Monte Cristo. Danglars watches Dantès depart with a look of hate.

**Chapter 2: Father and Son**
Edmond Dantès hurries to his father's small house. His father, frail and joyful, is unaware of his son's arrival. Edmond is dismayed to learn that his father has suffered greatly in his absence, having spent the 200 francs Edmond left him to pay a debt to a neighbor, Caderousse, living on only 60 francs for three months. Edmond empties his pockets, insisting his father buy provisions. Caderousse, a tailor, soon appears, feigning congratulations but casting greedy glances at the money. Edmond offers him some, which Caderousse declines, boasting of his own self-sufficiency. Caderousse hints that Mercédès has many admirers, causing Edmond slight uneasiness. After Edmond leaves to see Mercédès, Caderousse meets Danglars, confirming Edmond's impending captaincy and marriage, and discussing Mercédès's popularity. Danglars expresses his deep hatred and desire to thwart Edmond.

**Chapter 3: The Catalans**
In the village of the Catalans, Mercédès, a beautiful young girl, is with her cousin, Fernand Mondego, who is desperately in love with her. Mercédès, however, repeatedly rejects Fernand, declaring her unwavering love for Edmond Dantès and her intention to marry only him. She cites Fernand's conscription status and her own poverty as reasons against their union. Fernand is consumed by jealousy and expresses a desire for revenge. Edmond arrives, and he and Mercédès embrace passionately. Fernand's gloomy presence is noted by Edmond, but Mercédès insists Fernand is a friend. Fernand, after a forced handshake, rushes out, exclaiming, "Oh, who will deliver me from this man?" He joins Danglars and Caderousse at a nearby inn. Caderousse openly discusses Fernand's suffering and Edmond's good fortune. Danglars, seeing Fernand's despair, suggests imprisoning Dantès rather than killing him. He writes an anonymous letter with his left hand, accusing "Edmond Dantès, mate of the ship _Pharaon_," of being a Bonapartist agent carrying letters from Murat to Napoleon, and from Napoleon to a Bonapartist committee in Paris. Danglars crumples the letter, claiming it was a joke, and discards it. Fernand secretly retrieves the letter and heads towards the city. Edmond and Mercédès leave, joyful, announcing their wedding will be held in a day or two at La Réserve.

**Chapter 5: The Marriage Feast**
The wedding feast is prepared at La Réserve. M. Morrel arrives, confirming his intention to make Dantès captain. Edmond and Mercédès enter, radiant with happiness. Mercédès, with innocent kindness, insists Fernand sit next to her, unknowingly torturing him further. Edmond reveals that thanks to M. Morrel, the usual marriage formalities have been waived, and they will be married in an hour and a half at the city hall, before he leaves for Paris. Suddenly, a magistrate and four soldiers arrive and arrest Edmond Dantès in the name of the law. M. Morrel tries to intervene, but the magistrate is firm, stating Dantès is accused of serious political crimes. Old Dantès is devastated. Caderousse, realizing the "trick," confronts Danglars, who denies involvement, claiming he destroyed the incriminating letter. Fernand has disappeared. Edmond, believing it a mistake, assures everyone he will soon be free. As he is led away in a carriage, Mercédès cries out in despair, and Edmond shouts a promise to meet again. M. Morrel leaves to seek information from M. de Villefort. Caderousse, remembering Fernand picking up the letter, suspects his deeper involvement, but Danglars warns him against speaking out, implying he would be seen as an accomplice. Fernand, having returned, now acts as Mercédès's protector, taking her home. Old Dantès is taken home by friends, nearly lifeless. M. Morrel returns with the news: Edmond is charged with being a Bonapartist agent. Danglars, solidifying his own position, is placed in temporary command of the _Pharaon_ by M. Morrel.

**Chapter 6: The Deputy Procureur du Roi**
M. de Villefort celebrates his betrothal to Renée de Saint-Méran, a woman of high social standing and wealth. The guests are staunch Royalists, rejoicing in Napoleon's recent downfall. Villefort, an ambitious man, has distanced himself from his Girondin father, Noirtier, to advance his career as a king's attorney. He is called away by urgent business but returns beaming. He announces the discovery of a Bonapartist conspiracy and reads the anonymous letter denouncing Edmond Dantès. Renée expresses pity for the accused, but Villefort, while appearing to acknowledge her compassion, emphasizes his duty to be severe with conspirators, especially given his family's royalist connections. He reveals his intention to handle the case rigorously.

**Chapter 7: The Examination**
Villefort begins his interrogation of Dantès. Initially, Villefort is favorably impressed by Dantès's intelligence, courage, and frankness. Dantès calmly explains Captain Leclere's dying wish to deliver a packet on the Island of Elba and his brief encounter with Emperor Napoleon. He admits he received a letter from the grand marshal for a M. Noirtier in Paris. Villefort shows Dantès the anonymous denunciation, which Dantès does not recognize, concluding it was written by an envious enemy. Villefort, swayed by Dantès's sincerity and Renée's words, is about to release him. However, when Dantès reveals the letter's recipient is "Monsieur Noirtier, Rue Coq-Héron, Paris," Villefort is utterly shocked. He realizes Noirtier is his own father. To protect his career from being ruined by his father's Bonapartist activities, Villefort, feigning kindness, tells Dantès he must remain detained but promises to destroy the incriminating letter. He burns the letter before Dantès's eyes and makes him swear never to mention the name Noirtier or the letter's contents to anyone. Dantès, believing himself saved, is grateful. Alone, Villefort confirms his decision to sacrifice Dantès to further his own ambition.

**Chapter 8: The Château d’If**
Dantès is transferred from the Marseilles prison. He remains optimistic, believing Villefort's promise of imminent release. He is taken by carriage, then by boat, past familiar landmarks of Marseilles, including La Réserve and the Catalans. To his horror, he realizes he is being taken to the formidable Château d’If, an island fortress used for political prisoners. He attempts to jump overboard but is restrained by gendarmes. He is thrown into a dark, underground dungeon. Overwhelmed by despair and near madness, he laments his missed opportunity to escape into the sea. He repeatedly demands to see the governor, but the jailer refuses, citing prison rules and mentioning a previous prisoner, an abbé, who went mad in that cell. Dantès, desperate, offers the jailer 100 crowns to deliver a message to Mercédès. The jailer refuses, fearing for his job. Dantès, in a fit of rage, threatens the jailer with a stool. As a result, he is moved to an even deeper, darker dungeon, further pushing him towards insanity.

**Chapter 9: The Evening of the Betrothal**
Villefort, after arresting Dantès, returns to his betrothal celebration. He immediately informs the Marquis de Saint-Méran of the grave Bonapartist conspiracy and his urgent need to go to Paris to inform the king. He advises the Marquis to sell his financial assets, hinting at impending political turmoil. Mercédès intercepts Villefort outside his house, desperately inquiring about Edmond. Villefort coldly dismisses Edmond as a dangerous criminal and claims ignorance of his whereabouts. Consumed by remorse, Villefort departs for Paris. Meanwhile, Mercédès returns to the Catalans, sinking into despair, with Fernand attempting to console her. M. Morrel learns of Dantès's arrest and attempts to help him but is met with universal refusal due to the serious Bonapartist accusation. He returns home, hopeless. Caderousse, drunk and remorseful, retreats into his house. Danglars, however, is pleased, having eliminated a rival and secured his position on the _Pharaon_. Fernand, still obsessed with Mercédès, hopes Dantès's absence will lead to their marriage.

**Chapter 10: The King’s Closet at the Tuileries**
In Paris, at the Tuileries Palace, King Louis XVIII is dismissive of M. de Blacas's and M. Dandré's (Minister of Police) concerns about Napoleon on Elba. He jests about Napoleon's boredom and possible insanity. M. de Blacas, however, insists on the seriousness of the threat. Villefort is introduced, having traveled post-haste from Marseilles. He confirms a grave Bonapartist conspiracy and Napoleon's imminent landing, emphasizing his sacrifice in leaving his own betrothal to bring this urgent news. Louis XVIII remains skeptical, believing the monarchy is secure.

**Chapter 11: The Corsican Ogre**
M. Dandré bursts in, pale and trembling, confirming Napoleon has landed in France, near Antibes, on March 1st. Louis XVIII is furious, accusing his ministers of blindness and incompetence. Villefort seizes the opportunity, suggesting immediate action to rally Royalist regions against Napoleon. He then subtly protects M. Dandré, fearing that if Dandré is completely ruined, he might investigate Dantès's arrest, which would expose Villefort. Louis XVIII, impressed by Villefort's apparent foresight, awards him the cross of the Legion of Honor. The king then orders the police to search for a conspirator (described as a dark man of 50-52 with a black moustache), who was involved in the General Quesnel affair. Villefort recognizes this description as his father, Noirtier. He lies, claiming he has not seen his father.

**Chapter 12: Father and Son**
M. Noirtier, Villefort's father, unexpectedly arrives at Villefort's hotel in Paris, having followed his son from Marseilles. Noirtier reveals he is indeed the Bonapartist conspirator and the man involved in General Quesnel's death, which he frames as a political removal, not murder, in a duel. He acknowledges Villefort's act of burning the incriminating letter and sarcastically notes his son's ambition. Noirtier, aware of the police description, quickly shaves his whiskers and changes his clothing to disguise himself. He instructs Villefort to remain silent about their connection and his activities, warning him that his own career is tied to his father's fate. Villefort, agitated, destroys all traces of his father's disguise and leaves for Marseilles, already hearing news of Napoleon's triumphant advance.

**Chapter 13: The Hundred Days**
Noirtier's predictions come true; Napoleon's "Hundred Days" are a reality. Villefort's Royalist stance is a liability, but Noirtier's influence in the imperial court protects his son's position. Villefort's marriage is postponed. M. Morrel, now influential as a Bonapartist, repeatedly intercedes for Dantès. Villefort, however, falsely claims Dantès was imprisoned by "high authority" under the Bourbons and delays his release, even dictating a petition for Dantès that exaggerates his Bonapartist ties, thus further incriminating him if the Bourbons return. After Waterloo, Louis XVIII is restored. Villefort is promoted and marries Renée. Dantès remains in prison, forgotten. Danglars, fearing Dantès's return, leaves the sea, makes a fortune through speculation, and becomes Baron Danglars. Fernand joins the army, eventually becoming a general and count, amassing wealth through betrayal in Greece. Old Dantès dies of hunger, attended by Mercédès, who subsequently marries Fernand. M. Morrel pays for old Dantès's funeral.

**Chapter 14: The Two Prisoners**
In July 1816, over a year after his imprisonment, Edmond Dantès, now "number 34," is in a state of despair. He makes desperate attempts to communicate with the outside world. An Inspector-General of Prisons visits the Château d’If. Dantès seizes this chance to demand a trial, asserting his innocence and stating he was arrested on February 28, 1815. The Inspector, though somewhat moved, attributes Dantès's state to madness. He then visits "number 27," the Abbé Faria, who is considered utterly insane due to his claims of possessing an immense treasure and offering millions for his release. Dantès, marking the date as July 30, 1816, clings to a flicker of hope after the inspector's visit. A new governor arrives, and Dantès loses his name, becoming merely "number 34."

**Chapter 15: Number 34 and Number 27**
Dantès succumbs to profound despair, contemplating suicide by starvation. After four days without food, he suddenly hears a scratching sound from the wall, realizing another prisoner is attempting to escape. He regains his will to live, eats the food his jailer brings (pretending delirium to avoid suspicion), and begins digging a hole in his cell with a broken jug and later the iron handle of his soup saucepan. He successfully breaks through the wall. He hears a voice, which he identifies as the "mad abbé," Faria. Faria reveals his escape tunnel went in the wrong direction and led him to Dantès's cell instead of the sea. Dantès tells Faria his story. The older, wiser Faria is astonished by Dantès's youth and his unjust imprisonment for Bonapartist conspiracy. They agree to collaborate.

**Chapter 16: A Learned Italian**
Dantès enters Faria's cell. Faria, a man of profound intellect, shows Dantès his homemade tools, including a chisel made from his bedstead. He explains his failed escape attempt, caused by a miscalculation, and the reinforced walls of the prison. Faria reveals he is the Abbé Faria, imprisoned for political reasons due to his dream of a unified Italy, which led him to be betrayed by a "crowned simpleton." He confesses he was labeled "mad" for his claims of a vast treasure. Faria has dedicated his imprisonment to writing and study, making his own pens (from fish bones) and ink (from soot and wine). He has written a voluminous treatise on Italian monarchy. Dantès, humbled by Faria's knowledge, begs to be taught. Faria agrees to educate him in subjects like mathematics, physics, history, and languages. After a year of intense study, Dantès is transformed into a learned man. Faria, now physically weaker, is struck by a paralytic attack (catalepsy), a hereditary illness. He instructs Dantès to administer an elixir to save his life. Dantès successfully revives Faria, who, though partially paralyzed, insists Dantès should escape without him. Dantès, out of deep affection, swears never to leave him. Faria promises to reveal something important the next day.

**Chapter 18: The Treasure**
Faria reveals to Dantès that the half-burnt paper he possesses is the key to his immense treasure. He explains its origin: it is the last will and testament of Cardinal Spada, whose family fortune was sought by Pope Alexander VI and Cesare Borgia. Faria recounts how the Cardinal and his nephew were poisoned, and the treasure secretly hidden on the uninhabited Island of Monte Cristo. Faria discovered the will when a fragment, used as a bookmark, revealed a message in sympathetic ink upon being exposed to fire. The complete will, reconstructed by Faria's tireless research, directs the reader to "the farthest angle of the second opening" on Monte Cristo. Faria, embracing Dantès as his son, bestows half the treasure upon him, and the whole if he dies. Dantès, overwhelmed, initially disbelieves, fearing Faria's madness. The governor visits, finding Faria apparently well. Faria, now partially paralyzed, is determined for Dantès to have the treasure.

**Chapter 19: The Third Attack**
The escape tunnel they had painstakingly dug is discovered and sealed off, crushing their hopes. Dantès, though disappointed, reassures Faria that Faria's wisdom is his true treasure. Faria, still paralyzed, focuses on teaching Dantès the exact location of the treasure on Monte Cristo. He makes Dantès memorize the will and then destroys the second part, ensuring its secrecy. One night, Faria suffers his third and fatal catalepsy attack. With his last breaths, he urges Dantès to remember "Monte Cristo!" Dantès administers the elixir, but Faria dies. Dantès is consumed by grief but resolves to use Faria's body to escape. He overhears the jailers planning to sew Faria's body into a sack and throw it into the sea, as the Château d’If has no cemetery.

**Chapter 20: The Cemetery of the Château d’If**
Dantès, now free from doubt and filled with a renewed will to live and enact vengeance, decides to take Faria's place in the burial sack. He moves Faria's corpse to his own cell, covering it in his bed, then enters Faria's empty cell, gets into the sack, and sews it up from the inside with the knife Faria made. He waits in terrifying darkness. Two grave-diggers arrive, comment on the body's weight, and tie a 36-pound cannonball to his feet. They carry him to the edge of the rock and throw him into the sea. Dantès screams as he plunges into the icy water.

**Chapter 21: The Island of Tiboulen**
Underwater, Dantès uses Faria's knife to cut through the sack and sever the cord attaching the cannonball. He surfaces far from the Château d’If, seeing the fortress's alarm gun (a torch) lit. He swims towards the uninhabited islands of Tiboulen or Lemaire, guided by the Planier lighthouse. During a storm, he reaches Tiboulen. He finds shelter and drinks rainwater. He sees a fishing boat, the _Jeune Amélie_, wrecked nearby. Inspired, he takes a red cap and timber from the wreckage and, pretending to be a shipwrecked sailor, signals the passing _Jeune Amélie_, which rescues him. He speaks bad Italian and claims to be a Maltese sailor. The sailor Jacopo notes his long hair and beard. Dantès invents a story of a vow and the shipwreck. The captain, Gaetano, impressed by his seamanship, offers him a temporary position. A distant cannon shot from the Château d’If is heard, signaling an escape. Dantès calmly identifies it as an alarm for a prisoner. Jacopo reveals the date: February 28, 1829. Dantès realizes he has been imprisoned for fourteen years and renews his oath of vengeance against Danglars, Fernand, and Villefort.

**Chapter 22: The Smugglers**
Dantès, now disguised, quickly learns that the _Jeune Amélie_ is a smuggling vessel. He maintains his fabricated identity. In Leghorn, he cuts his long hair and beard, observing his transformed, stern, and intelligent appearance in a mirror. He buys new clothes, completing his disguise. The captain offers him a permanent position, but Dantès agrees only to a three-month engagement. The ship loads contraband. During a confrontation with customs officers, Dantès is wounded, but conceals his pain, demonstrating his newfound indifference to physical suffering. Jacopo's genuine concern touches him. Dantès, using charts, teaches navigation to Jacopo. The captain proposes a lucrative smuggling operation on Monte Cristo Island. Dantès, feigning indifference, readily agrees, planning to use this opportunity to find his treasure.

**Chapter 23: The Island of Monte Cristo**
On the night before reaching Monte Cristo, Dantès is restless, dreaming of the treasure. The next day, he steers the ship, feigning exhaustion. They anchor at Monte Cristo. Dantès, eager to search for the treasure, pretends to go hunting for wild goats and sends Jacopo back to the ship with a killed kid. Alone, he follows the cryptic marks on the rocks, which lead to a large circular stone. Realizing the stone was lowered, not lifted, he uses gunpowder to blast it open, revealing an iron ring set in a flagstone. He lifts the flagstone, discovering steps descending into a dark grotto. Initially fearful and doubting, he then remembers Faria’s words about the "second opening" and descends. He finds a second grotto, and using his pickaxe, discovers an oaken coffer with the Spada family crest. He breaks it open and is dazzled by compartments filled with gold coins, gold bars, diamonds, pearls, and rubies. He spends the night overcome with awe and disbelief, guarding his immense fortune.

**Chapter 25: The Unknown**
The morning after discovering the treasure, Dantès meticulously re-hides it in the grotto, disguising any trace of his activity. Six days later, the smugglers return. Dantès feigns continued injury from his "accident" to explain his prolonged stay. He learns the smugglers narrowly escaped a guard-ship. In Leghorn, Dantès sells four small diamonds for 5,000 francs each, allaying any suspicion by pretending to be a wealthy eccentric. He buys Jacopo a new fishing vessel and gives him 100 piastres, sending him to Marseilles to inquire about his father, Louis Dantès, and Mercédès, and to return to Monte Cristo. Dantès then buys a luxurious yacht in Genoa for 60,000 francs (paid with diamonds), commissioning a secret locker inside. He sails the yacht to Monte Cristo and transfers his treasure. Jacopo returns with devastating news: Dantès's father is dead, and Mercédès has disappeared. Dantès, though outwardly calm, is deeply affected. He sails his yacht to Marseilles, using an English passport under the name "Lord Wilmore." He tests his unrecognizable appearance by speaking to an old _Pharaon_ sailor, who does not know him. He then buys his old house in the Allées de Meilhan for an exorbitant sum and provides free housing for the current tenants. After inquiring about Mercédès and Caderousse (now gone), he leaves Marseilles.

**Volume Two**

**Chapter 26: The Pont du Gard Inn**
Caderousse, now the impoverished innkeeper of the "Pont du Gard" between Beaucaire and Bellegarde, struggles financially. His wife, Madeleine (La Carconte), is sickly and complains constantly. An Italian priest, the Abbé Busoni (Monte Cristo in disguise), arrives, asking for Caderousse by name. Caderousse, surprised, confirms his identity and his former profession as a tailor in Marseilles. The Abbé orders wine and asks if Caderousse is alone.

**Chapter 27: The Story**
The Abbé Busoni (Monte Cristo) asks Caderousse about Edmond Dantès. Caderousse, after initial hesitation, tearfully recounts Edmond's fate: he died a miserable prisoner. He also reveals that Edmond's father died of "downright starvation." The Abbé then reveals that Edmond, before his death, bequeathed a magnificent diamond (worth 50,000 francs) to his four friends (Caderousse, Danglars, Fernand, Mercédès) and his father, with the father's share to be divided among the survivors. La Carconte, overhearing, is drawn into the conversation. Caderousse confesses, reluctantly, that Danglars wrote the anonymous denunciation letter, and Fernand posted it. He claims he was drunk and thought it was a harmless joke. The Abbé also learns that M. Morrel is now ruined, while Danglars has become a wealthy baron and Fernand a celebrated general, who acquired his fortune through the betrayal of Ali Pasha in Greece. The Abbé gives the diamond to Caderousse as his and old Dantès's share. Caderousse and La Carconte, overcome with greed, plan to sell the diamond. Caderousse leaves for Beaucaire to have the diamond appraised. The Abbé (Monte Cristo) leaves, having uncovered the full extent of the past betrayals and their consequences.

**Chapter 28: The Prison Register**
Monte Cristo, disguised as an "Englishman" named Thomson & French, a Roman banker, visits the Mayor of Marseilles to inquire about M. Morrel's financial state. The Mayor, a creditor himself, directs him to M. de Boville, the Inspector of Prisons, another major creditor. Monte Cristo offers to buy Boville's 200,000-franc debt for its full value, in cash. As a "commission," he asks to see the prison registers. Boville, delighted, recounts how the "mad abbé" Faria claimed to have a treasure. He then tells the story of Edmond Dantès, a "dangerous Bonapartist," who, after Faria's death, escaped by taking Faria's place in the burial sack and was thrown into the sea with a cannonball, presumed drowned. Monte Cristo, maintaining his composure, obtains Dantès's mortuary deposition and the original denunciation letter (which was kept in the prison records). He discovers Villefort's marginal notes on Morrel's petition, which had further sealed Dantès's fate by exaggerating his Bonapartist ties. Monte Cristo pays Boville and leaves, now fully aware of the extent of the conspiracy against him.

**Chapter 29: The House of Morrel & Son**
M. Morrel's shipping business is in a state of ruin, with lost ships and no credit. His last hope, the _Pharaon_, is overdue. Emmanuel, his future son-in-law, and Julie, his daughter, are distraught. Cocles, the cashier, remains steadfast, unable to believe the house could fail. The "Englishman" (Monte Cristo) arrives, presenting bills totaling 287,500 francs, including M. de Boville's debt. Morrel, in despair, confesses he cannot pay. News then arrives that the _Pharaon_ has been lost, but its crew, including Penelon, is saved. Morrel is grateful for the lives saved. The Englishman grants Morrel a three-month extension to pay his debts. He gives Julie a mysterious instruction: to obey a future letter signed "Sinbad the Sailor" implicitly. He leaves, taking Penelon aside for a private conversation.

**Chapter 30: The Fifth of September**
Morrel's temporary reprieve gives him a glimmer of hope, but his resources are exhausted. He travels to Paris to seek help from Danglars, who is now immensely wealthy, but is coldly refused. Returning home, Morrel, determined to die honorably rather than face bankruptcy, prepares to commit suicide. His son, Maximilian, a captain in the Spahis, arrives, having been summoned by his mother and sister. Maximilian confronts his father, who reveals his suicidal intent. Maximilian, in turn, offers to die with him. Morrel convinces Maximilian to live for his family's honor. At the last moment, as Morrel is about to shoot himself, Julie rushes in. She presents him with a red silk purse containing a receipt for all his debts (287,500 francs) and a large diamond, with a note: "Julie's Dowry. Sinbad the Sailor." Simultaneously, Emmanuel announces the miraculous arrival of a new ship, also named the _Pharaon_, fully laden and with Captain Gaumard and Penelon on board. Morrel is overwhelmed with joy, believing it a divine intervention. Monte Cristo, observing the scene from a distance, murmurs that his vengeance is now complete for the good, and he will now focus on punishing the wicked. He then hails Jacopo and departs in his yacht.

**Chapter 31: Italy: Sinbad the Sailor**
In Florence in 1838, Albert de Morcerf and Franz d’Épinay plan to attend the Carnival in Rome. Franz, after visiting Elba, decides to explore the uninhabited Island of Monte Cristo. His boat's captain, Gaetano, warns him the island is a refuge for smugglers and pirates, and landing there would require a six-day quarantine. Franz accepts. Gaetano recounts how pirates dispose of victims. Approaching Monte Cristo at night, Franz sees a fire and learns it's occupied by Spanish smugglers and Corsican bandits. He's invited to sup with their chief, "Sinbad the Sailor," on condition of being blindfolded. Franz is led into a magnificent subterranean cave, where he meets his host, a man of 38-40, dressed in Tunisian costume. Sinbad recounts how he saved his mute Nubian servant, Ali, from execution. He speaks of his life of absolute freedom and dispensing his own justice. Sinbad offers Franz hashish, claiming it provides profound pleasures and insights. Franz takes it and experiences vivid, voluptuous dreams.

**Chapter 32: The Waking**
Franz awakes in a grotto, feeling refreshed. The hashish dream dissipates. The sailors inform him "Signor Sinbad" has departed for Malaga. Franz sees Sinbad's yacht sailing away. He unsuccessfully attempts to find the enchanted grotto again. He leaves Monte Cristo, heading for Rome. There, he meets Albert. They struggle to find a carriage for Carnival, as all are booked. Signor Pastrini, their innkeeper, informs them that the Count of Monte Cristo, residing on the same floor, has offered them seats in his carriage and windows at the Palazzo Rospoli. Franz, recalling his Monte Cristo adventure, suspects this count is "Sinbad the Sailor."

**Chapter 33: Roman Bandits**
Franz reads a public notice of executions: Andrea Rondolo and Peppino (an accomplice of Luigi Vampa) are to be executed. He realizes this matches the conversation he overheard at the Colosseum, confirming Monte Cristo's connection to bandits. Albert and Franz visit Monte Cristo, who is calm and cultured. Monte Cristo discusses his philosophy of justice and vengeance, implying he has experienced profound suffering. He casually mentions a pardon for Peppino. Franz, witnessing the Carnival festivities, sees the Rospoli Palace windows display the agreed-upon signal (white damask with a red cross), confirming Peppino's pardon. Albert, meanwhile, flirts with a mysterious "Roman peasant" who throws him violets, leading to a rendezvous. On the last day of Carnival, Albert attends the rendezvous but is ambushed by Luigi Vampa's bandits, led by "Beppo" (a boy disguised as a peasant girl). Albert is taken to the Catacombs of St. Sebastian. He sends a ransom note for 4,000 piastres to Franz, signed by Luigi Vampa. Franz, realizing the danger, goes to Monte Cristo for help. Monte Cristo, with Ali and Peppino, rescues Albert from the catacombs, confronting Vampa and reminding him of his "friends." Albert is freed, returning to a ball, unaware of how close he came to death.

**Chapter 38: The Rendezvous**
Albert de Morcerf, grateful for his rescue, visits Monte Cristo to thank him and offers his family's influence in Parisian society. Monte Cristo, feigning to be a stranger to Paris, accepts Albert's offer to introduce him. They agree to meet at Albert's home (No. 27, Rue du Helder) on May 21st at 10:30 AM. Franz, uneasy about Monte Cristo's enigmatic nature and the cold touch of his hand, recounts his experiences with Monte Cristo, but Albert dismisses his fears as imagination.

**Chapter 39: The Guests**
Albert prepares his pavilion for Monte Cristo's arrival. His friends, including Debray, Beauchamp, Château-Renaud, and Maximilian Morrel, gather for breakfast. They discuss society, politics, and Danglars's recent financial gains. Albert recounts his capture by bandits and rescue by Monte Cristo, referring to him as "Sinbad the Sailor" and hinting at his hidden wealth. Maximilian Morrel, upon hearing this, hints at his own past connection to a "Sinbad." Monte Cristo arrives, punctually, and Albert introduces him to his friends. Monte Cristo displays his extensive knowledge, admits to using opium and hashish, and speaks of exchanging emeralds for human lives (Peppino's pardon and the Sultan's slave). He mentions his Corsican steward, Bertuccio, has a mysterious past involving a "stab with a knife." Monte Cristo reveals he has credit with Thomson & French, causing Maximilian Morrel to react strongly. Monte Cristo invites everyone to a dinner at his Auteuil country house, but subtly excludes the Morcerfs, claiming he has an engagement with Major Cavalcanti and his son.

**Chapter 40: The Breakfast**
During breakfast, Albert and his friends continue to discuss Monte Cristo. Monte Cristo's past actions (the emeralds, the pardons) are brought up, and Albert notes his "egotism." Albert, concerned about his unwanted marriage to Eugénie Danglars and his mother's disapproval, seeks advice from Monte Cristo. Monte Cristo suggests inviting the Danglars and Villeforts to his Auteuil house, but to exclude the Morcerfs to avoid a "matrimonial meeting," which would displease Albert's mother. Albert accepts, deciding to go to Tréport with his mother. Monte Cristo confirms his invitation to the Cavalcantis.

**Chapter 41: The Presentation**
Albert gives Monte Cristo a tour of his luxurious pavilion. Monte Cristo is particularly drawn to a portrait of Mercédès in Catalan costume, painted years ago. Albert reveals it is his mother, painted during his father's absence, and that his father dislikes it. He mentions his mother cries when looking at it. Albert then introduces Monte Cristo to his parents, the Count and Countess of Morcerf (Fernand and Mercédès). Monte Cristo observes Fernand's careworn face and Mercédès's paleness and silence. Monte Cristo compliments Fernand's military career. Mercédès, deeply moved, thanks Monte Cristo for saving Albert's life. Monte Cristo is equally pale. After he leaves, Mercédès questions Albert about the count, expressing deep unease and calling him a "problem" and an "enigma." Albert dismisses her fears.

**Chapter 42: Monsieur Bertuccio**
Monte Cristo's Parisian mansion in the Champs-Élysées is sumptuously furnished. He orders Bertuccio to purchase a seaside estate in Normandy for his corvette, registered in Bertuccio's name. Monte Cristo then buys a house in Auteuil, Rue de la Fontaine, No. 28, which had belonged to M. de Saint-Méran (Villefort's father-in-law). Bertuccio is visibly agitated upon hearing the address. Monte Cristo insists Bertuccio accompany him to Auteuil. Bertuccio makes the sign of the cross and mutters a prayer, clearly terrified.

**Chapter 43: The House at Auteuil**
Monte Cristo and Bertuccio arrive at the house in Auteuil. The concierge confirms the previous owner was M. de Saint-Méran and that his daughter married M. de Villefort. Bertuccio's agitation increases. Monte Cristo forces Bertuccio to lead the way down a private staircase to the garden. Bertuccio, overcome, refuses to go further, exclaiming that "the evil has arrived!" and that this house is the scene of an "assassination." Monte Cristo demands an explanation. Bertuccio, trembling, reveals he declared a vendetta against M. de Villefort after Villefort, as a procureur, refused to investigate the murder of Bertuccio's brother (a Bonapartist).

**Chapter 44: The Vendetta**
Bertuccio confesses to Monte Cristo the full story of his vendetta against Villefort. He explains that in 1815, his brother, a Bonapartist soldier, was murdered in Nîmes during Royalist massacres. Villefort, then a procureur, dismissed Bertuccio's plea for justice with cruel indifference, justifying his brother's death politically. Bertuccio swore vengeance. He tracked Villefort to the Auteuil house, where he observed Villefort having a secret affair with a pregnant woman. One night, he saw Villefort bury a box in the garden. Believing it contained treasure, Bertuccio stabbed Villefort, took the box, and found a newborn infant inside, still alive. He left the child at a foundling asylum, keeping half of a napkin with the initials "H.N." (Hermine de Nargonne, Madame Danglars' maiden name) and a baron's coronet. Monte Cristo (as Abbé Busoni) later visited Bertuccio in prison, where Bertuccio had been wrongly accused of the murder of a jeweller (Joannes). Bertuccio made a full confession to Busoni, who then helped clear his name by arranging for the arrest of the actual culprit, Caderousse. Bertuccio, released, became Monte Cristo's steward. Bertuccio expresses remorse for abandoning the infant and is terrified to revisit the scene of his crime, fearing the house. Monte Cristo, having extracted the full story, implies that Villefort may not be dead and that the child (Benedetto) will be an instrument of divine retribution.

**Chapter 45: The Rain of Blood**
(This chapter contains the story Caderousse told to Monte Cristo, disguised as Abbé Busoni, about the murder of Joannes, and how Bertuccio was wrongly imprisoned for it.) Caderousse confessed that he and his wife, La Carconte, murdered the jeweller Joannes after selling him the diamond Monte Cristo (as Abbé Busoni) had given Caderousse. They lured Joannes to stay overnight at their inn. Caderousse attacked him, and La Carconte assisted. Bertuccio, hidden in a shed, witnessed the crime. When Bertuccio tried to help the dying Joannes, he was found by gendarmes and mistakenly arrested due to his blood-stained clothes (from stabbing Villefort previously). Bertuccio was imprisoned and accused. The Abbé Busoni (Monte Cristo) visited him, heard his confession about both the Auteuil crime and the Joannes murder, and then arranged for Caderousse to be apprehended. Caderousse was eventually sentenced to the galleys for life, and Bertuccio was released and subsequently hired by Monte Cristo.

**Chapter 46: Unlimited Credit**
