An old man, hoary white with age, approaches in a bark, crying, "Woe to you wicked spirits! hope not ever to see the sky again. I come to take you to the other shore across, into eternal darkness, there to dwell in fierce heat and in ice." He tells the protagonist, a "live spirit," to leave the dead. But seeing the protagonist remain, he says, "By other way, by other haven shalt thou come to shore, not by this passage; thee a nimbler boat must carry." Virgil intervenes, telling Charon (the boatman with eyes like "wheeling flames") not to torment himself, as "so 'tis will'd, where will and power are one." Charon, silent, falls into silence.
The faint and naked spirits, hearing these cruel words, change color and gnash their teeth, blaspheming God, their parents, mankind, the place, the time, and their birth. They then all wailing draw to the "curs'd strand." Charon, a "demoniac form," beckons them, striking any who linger with his oar. Like autumn leaves falling, Adam's evil brood cast themselves one by one from the shore into the "umber'd wave."
Virgil explains that "those, who die subject to the wrath of God," come here from every clime and are eager to cross because "heaven's justice goads them on, that fear is turn'd into desire." He notes that no good spirit ever passes here, which explains Charon's complaint about the protagonist.
As Virgil finishes speaking, the gloomy region shakes terribly, chilling the protagonist with clammy dews. The earth emits a blast and a "vermilion flame," conquering his senses, and he drops "as one with sudden slumber seiz'd."

**CANTO IV**
A crash of heavy thunder breaks the protagonist's deep slumber, rousing him. He looks around, finding himself on the brink of a "lamentable vale," a "dread abyss" with a thundering sound of innumerable plaints. It is dark, deep, and thick with clouds, and he cannot discern its bottom.
Virgil, looking pale, bids them descend to the "blind world" beneath, leading the way. The protagonist, noticing Virgil's pallor, asks how he can proceed if his guide yields to dread. Virgil explains that his pallor is from pity for the suffering souls below, not fear, and urges haste.
They enter the "first circle, that surrounds th' abyss." Here, only sighs are heard, not from tortures, but from grief felt by vast multitudes of "men, women, and infants." Virgil explains these spirits are "blameless" of sin, but are lost because "baptism was not theirs," the "portal to thy faith." Those who lived before the Gospel "serv'd not God aright," and Virgil himself is among them. Their affliction is "only so far afflicted, that we live desiring without hope."
The protagonist feels grief, knowing many souls "of mighty worth" are suspended in this "Limbo." He asks Virgil if any, by their own or others' merit, ever came forth from there to be blessed.
Virgil, understanding, replies that he was "new to that estate" when he saw a "puissant one arrive amongst us, with victorious trophy crown'd." This figure drew forth the shades of Adam, Abel, Noah, Moses, Abraham, David, Israel and his family (including Rachel), and "others many more," exalting them to bliss. Before these, "no spirit of human kind was ever sav'd."
They continue through the "wood" of spirits. Not far from a summit, the protagonist sees a flame shining through the darkened hemisphere. He discerns a "tribe in honour high" possessing that place. He asks Virgil who these honored souls are, separate from the rest. Virgil replies that their "renown of their great names" in the upper world acquires "favour in heaven," advancing them.
A voice calls out, "Honour the bard sublime! his shade returns that left us late!" Four mighty spirits approach, neither sorrowful nor glad. Virgil identifies the one bearing a "falchion keen" as Homer, followed by Flaccus (Horace), Naso (Ovid), and Lucan. He explains they greet him thus because they all share the appellation of "bard sublime."
The protagonist finds himself admitted to this "bright school" of poets, becoming "sixth amid so learn'd a band." They pass on, speaking of matters "then befitting well to speak, now fitter left untold." They arrive at a magnificent castle, "seven times with lofty walls begirt," and defended by a "pleasant stream," which they cross as if on dry land. Through "seven gates," the protagonist enters with the sages into a "mead with lively verdure fresh."
Here dwell a race moving their eyes "majestically," bearing "eminent authority," and speaking seldom, but with "tuneful sweet" words. They retire to an "open and bright and lofty" place, where the protagonist sees "great spirits," by whose sight he is "exalted in my own esteem." He sees Electra, Hector, Anchises' son (Aeneas), Caesar (all armed), Camilla, Penthesilea, old King Latinus with his child Lavinia, Brutus (who chased Tarquin), Lucretia, Cato's wife Marcia, Julia, and Cornelia. Apart, he sees the "Soldan fierce."
Raising his brow, he spies "the master of the sapient throng," seated amid philosophers. All admire and reverence him. He marks Socrates and Plato nearest to him, then Democritus, Diogenes, Heraclitus, Empedocles, Anaxagoras, Thales, Zeno, Dioscorides, Orpheus, Linus, Tully (Cicero), Seneca, Euclid, Ptolemy, Hippocrates, Galen, Avicenna, and Averroes.
To speak of all fully would be vain, as his theme urges him onward. The six associates part, and Virgil leads the protagonist from that "air serene, into a climate ever vex'd with storms," arriving at a place where "no light shines."

**CANTO V**
The protagonist descends from the first circle to the second, a lesser space containing "so much more of grief provoking bitter moans." Here, Minos stands, "grinning with ghastly feature," examining crimes and giving sentence by encircling himself with his tail as many times as the degrees the soul must descend into Hell. Souls confess all before him, and he, "judge severe of sins," determines their place. A numerous throng always stands before him, each awaiting judgment.
Minos, seeing the protagonist approach, cries out, "O thou! who to this residence of woe approachest? Look how thou enter here; beware in whom thou place thy trust; let not the entrance broad deceive thee to thy harm." Virgil silences him, stating, "Wherefore exclaimest? Hinder not his way by destiny appointed; so 'tis will'd where will and power are one."
Rueful wailings begin to be heard as they enter a place where "light was silent all." A bellowing noise, like a sea in tempest, groans through the air. The "stormy blast of hell with restless fury drives the spirits on, whirl'd round and dash'd amain with sore annoy." At the "ruinous sweep," shrieks, lamentations, moans, and blasphemies "gainst the good Power in heaven" are heard.
The protagonist understands that "carnal sinners, in whom reason by lust is sway'd," are condemned to this torment. Like starlings borne abroad by winter winds, or cranes chanting dolorous notes, these evil souls are driven relentlessly by the "tyrannous gust," with no hope of rest or milder pang.
He asks Virgil who these spirits "scourg'd by the black air" are. Virgil replies that the first among them, "empress o'er many tongues," was Semiramis, who in "vice of luxury was so shameless" that she made "liking be lawful by promulg'd decree, to clear the blame she had herself incurr'd." She succeeded Ninus and ruled the land now under the Soldan. The next "in amorous fury slew herself," breaking faith with Sicheus (Dido). Then follows Cleopatra, "lustful queen."
He also sees Helen, Achilles (who "with love fought to the end"), Paris, and Tristan. Virgil shows him "a thousand more" who were "bereav'd of life" by love.
Overpowered by pity, the protagonist's mind is almost lost. He expresses a desire to speak with "those two together coming, which seem so light before the wind." Virgil advises him to entreat them by the love that carries them.
As the wind sways them closer, the protagonist addresses them, "O wearied spirits! come, and hold discourse with us, if by none else restrain'd." Like doves invited by fond desire to their nest, two spirits issue from the troop where Dido ranks, speeding through the ill air, moved by his strong affection.
One spirit speaks, addressing him as a "gracious creature and benign" who visits them through this "obscure element," they who "the world with bloody stain imbru'd." She states that if they had a friend in the "King of all," their prayer would arise for his peace since he shows pity for their plight. She agrees to discourse freely while the wind is mute. She reveals her birthplace to be on the coast where the Po descends to the ocean.
She continues, explaining that "Love, that in gentle heart is quickly learnt," entangled her beloved by her "fair form," which was "ta'en in such cruel sort, as grieves me still." "Love, that denial takes from none belov'd," caught her with pleasing him so well that he "yet deserts me not." "Love brought us to one death: Caina waits the soul, who spilt our life."
The protagonist looks down in anguish, pondering "by what sweet thoughts, what fond desire must they at length to that ill pass have reach'd!" He then addresses her as Francesca, expressing his grief and pity. He asks her to tell him "by what, and how love granted, that ye knew your yet uncertain wishes?"
Francesca replies that "No greater grief than to remember days of joy, when mis'ry is at hand!" She then agrees to tell her tale, weeping as she speaks. One day, for their delight, they read of Lancelot and how love enthralled him. They were alone, with no suspicion near. Often, by that reading, their eyes met, and their cheeks blanched. But at one point, when they read of "that smile, the wished smile, rapturously kiss'd by one so deep in love," the man who "ne'er from me shall separate" at once kissed her lips, all trembling. She concludes, "The book and writer both were love's purveyors. In its leaves that day we read no more."
While she speaks, the other spirit wails so sorely that the protagonist, heartstruck with compassion, faints and falls to the ground "like a corpse."

**CANTO VI**
The protagonist's senses revive, having drooped from pity for the "kindred shades." He finds himself in the "third circle," where new torments and tormented souls appear. This circle is afflicted by "show'rs ceaseless, accursed, heavy, and cold, unchang'd for ever." Large hail, discolored water, and sleet stream down through the "dun midnight air," making the land stink.
Cerberus, a "cruel monster, fierce and strange," barks through his "wide threefold throat" over the immersed multitude. His eyes glare crimson, his beard is black and unctuous, his belly large, and his hands clawed, with which he tears, flays, and dismembers the spirits. The spirits howl like curs, screening themselves with one side and often rolling around in the "rainy deluge."
When Cerberus, "that great worm," espies them, he opens his jaws and shows his fangs, trembling all over. Virgil fills his palms with earth and casts it into Cerberus's "ravenous maw." The demon quietens, like a dog that ceases barking when given food, dropping his "loathsome cheeks."
They pass over the prostrate shades, whose "emptiness, that substance seem'd." All lie extended on the earth, save one who suddenly sits up when he sees them. This spirit cries, "O thou! who through the infernal shades art led, own, if again thou know'st me. Thou wast fram'd or ere my frame was broken." The protagonist replies that the anguish he endures has perhaps so altered his form that he doesn't recognize him, and asks his identity.
The spirit answers that "Thy city heap'd with envy to the brim," Florence, held him in brighter days, and citizens named him Ciacco. He suffers under the rain for the "sin of glutt'ny, damned vice." He is not alone in this woe; all present incurred like punishment for like crime.
The protagonist asks Ciacco about the fate of the "divided city" (Florence), if any just ones remain, and the cause of its discord. Ciacco prophesies that after long striving, they will "come to blood," and "the wild party from the woods" will chase the other out. Within "three solar circles," the wild party will fall, and the other will rise by "borrow'd force of one, who under shore now rests." This new power will oppress the other for a long time. He states that the "just are two in number, but they neglected." He attributes the city's woes to "Av'rice, envy, pride, three fatal sparks."
The protagonist then asks about Farinata, Tegghiaio, Giacopo, Arrigo, Mosca, and others "who bent their minds on working good," inquiring where they bide and whether "heaven's sweet cup or poisonous drug of hell be to their lip assign'd." Ciacco replies that "These are yet blacker spirits. Various crimes have sunk them deeper in the dark abyss. If thou so far descendest, thou mayst see them." He entreats the protagonist to mention him when he returns to the "pleasant world." He then says, "No more I tell thee, answer thee no more," turns his fixed eyes askance, bows his head, and falls amidst his "blind companions."
Virgil explains that Ciacco "no more his bed he leaves, ere the last angel-trumpet blow." Then, the "Power Adverse to these shall then in glory come, Each one forthwith to his sad tomb repair, resume his fleshly vesture and his form, and hear the eternal doom re-echoing rend the vault."
They pass through the "foul mixture of spirits and rain with tardy steps." The protagonist questions if these tortures will increase, mitigate, or remain severe after "the great sentence passes." Virgil replies that "as each thing to more perfection grows, It feels more sensibly both good and pain." Though the accursed race will never reach true perfection, they will approach it nearer then. They journey onward, discussing more, until they reach steps leading below, where they find Plutus.

**CANTO VII**
Plutus loudly exclaims, "Ah me! O Satan! Satan!" Virgil comforts the protagonist, assuring him that Plutus has no power to hinder their descent. Virgil then silences Plutus, calling him "Curs'd wolf!" and telling him to consume himself with fury, as the protagonist passes "not without cause" by divine will. Plutus drops to the ground like collapsed sails.
They descend to the "fourth steep ledge," a dismal shore encompassing "all the woe of all the universe." The protagonist marvels at "Almighty Justice!" for the new pains and troubles.
He beholds a multitude, more numerous than elsewhere, who "dance" like waves against Charybdis. From both sides, with loud voices, they roll weights with their breasts, then collide, and each rolls back. One side exclaims, "Why holdest thou so fast?" and the other answers, "And why castest thou away?" They traverse the "horrid circle," repeating their "despiteful song," then meet again in the middle.
The protagonist, stung with grief, asks Virgil what race this is, and if those with "shorn heads" on their left were "separate to the church." Virgil replies that all these in their first life were "so distorted" in mind that they made no proper use of their wealth. Their words, howling at each extremity of the circle, confirm this. Those "separate to the church," Popes and Cardinals, are "crown'd with no hairy cowls" and dominated by avarice.
The protagonist asks if he might recognize any of them. Virgil responds that such a thought is "vain," as their ignoble life now makes them "dark, and to all knowledge indiscernible." They will forever meet in this "rude shock," some rising from the tomb "with clenched grasp" (misers), others "with close-shaven locks" (prodigals). Their failure to "give" and "keep" wealth has deprived them of the beautiful world and set them in this strife. Virgil points out the brevity and vanity of "goods committed into fortune's hands." Not all the gold on earth could purchase rest for one of these souls.
The protagonist then asks Virgil to explain "this fortune, that thou speak'st of, what it is, whose talons grasp the blessings of the world?"
Virgil explains that God, with "transcendent wisdom," created the heavens with ruling powers for equal light distribution. Similarly, God ordained a "guiding hand and general minister" (Fortune) to rule over worldly goods, changing "empty vantages of life from race to race, from one to other's blood," beyond man's wisest care. Fortune acts as she wills, unseen like a "serpent train" in the grass, planning, judging, and reigning with foresight, like other divine powers. Her changes are incessant, and she is swift to grant favors. She is "execrated" by those who owe her praise, yet she is blessed and "in her bliss exults."
They must now pass to "heavier woe," as each star that mounted at their entrance is falling, forbidding further tarrying. They cross to the next steep, arriving at a well that boils down into a foss. The wave is murkier than "sablest grain." They journey by the inky waters, entering beneath by a different track.
The dismal stream expands into the "Stygian nam'd" lake at the foot of withered cliffs. The protagonist gazes at a "miry tribe, all naked, and with looks betok'ning rage" sunk in the marsh. They strike each other with hands, heads, breasts, feet, and tear each other piecemeal with their fangs.
Virgil explains these are the souls of those "whom anger overcame." He also reveals that "underneath the water dwells a multitude, whose sighs into these bubbles make the surface heave." Fixed in the slime, these say, "'Sad once were we in the sweet air made gladsome by the sun, carrying a foul and lazy mist within: Now in these murky settlings are we sad.'" They gurgle this "dolorous strain," but cannot utter distinct words. They continue their route along the embankment and the pool, observing those "who gulp'd its muddy lees," until they reach a tower's base.

**CANTO VIII**
Before reaching the tower's base, they spot two cressets hanging high, and from afar, another light returning the signal. The protagonist asks Virgil for its meaning. Virgil replies they will soon see what awaits them on the "filthy waters," if the marsh fog does not conceal it.
A small bark, ferried by a single figure, swiftly approaches. The boatman cries, "Art thou arriv'd, fell spirit?" Virgil replies, "Phlegyas, Phlegyas, this time thou criest in vain; no longer shalt thou have us, but while o'er the slimy pool we pass." Phlegyas, hearing this, pines "in his fierce ire."
Virgil steps into the skiff and bids the protagonist enter next to him. The vessel seems freighted only after their entrance. The ancient prow cuts the waves more deeply than usual.
As they cross the "dead channel," one spirit, drenched in mire, asks the protagonist, "Who art thou, that thou comest ere thine hour?" The protagonist replies he comes but does not tarry and asks the spirit's identity. The spirit says he is "one, as thou seest, who mourn." The protagonist recognizes him, even disguised in filth, and tells him to "tarry" in mourning. The spirit stretches hands to the bark, but Virgil thrusts him back, exclaiming, "Away! down there, to the other dogs!"
Virgil then embraces the protagonist, kissing his cheek, and praising him as "justly disdainful," saying he was "conceiv'd" in a blessed woman. He identifies the spirit as one "for arrogance noted" in the world, whose "shadow furious" is here. Many "mighty kings" above will wallow like swine in this mire, leaving "horrible dispraise."
The protagonist expresses a desire to see this spirit "whelm'd in these dregs" before they leave the lake. Virgil assures him his wish will be satisfied. Scarcely have Virgil's words ended when the "miry tribes" set on the spirit with such violence that the protagonist gives thanks to God. They all cry, "To Filippo Argenti!" and the "moody Florentine" turns his "avenging fangs" on himself. They leave him there.
Suddenly, a sound of lamentation strikes the protagonist's ear. Virgil announces that "Draws near the city, that of Dis is nam'd, with its grave denizens, a mighty throng." The protagonist descries minarets "gleaming vermilion, as if they from fire had issu'd." Virgil explains these are eternally burning fires that illuminate them in "this nether hell."
They reach the deep fosses that moat this comfortless region. The walls appear to be made of iron. After a wide circuit, they arrive where the mariner (Phlegyas) vehemently cries, "Go forth! The entrance is here!"
On the gates, the protagonist spies "more than a thousand" spirits, "hurl'd of old from heaven." With ireful gestures, they demand, "Who is this, that without death first felt, goes through the regions of the dead?" Virgil signals a desire for secret parley. Their anger abating, they say, "Come thou alone; and let him go who hath so hardily enter'd this realm. Alone return he by his witless way." They tell the protagonist he must tarry there as Virgil's escort. The protagonist is filled with fear, believing he will never return.
He cries to Virgil, his "lov'd guide," who has rendered him security "more than seven times," not to desert him. He asks to retrace their steps if they are denied passage. Virgil replies, "Fear not: for of our passage none hath power to disappoint us, by such high authority permitted." He tells the protagonist to wait, comfort his spirit, and feed it with hope, assuring him he will not be left.
Virgil then departs and quits the protagonist, who remains hesitating, "at war 'twixt will and will not." He cannot hear the terms Virgil offers, but they confer not long, for the adversaries "fled within" and closed the gates on Virgil's breast. Excluded, Virgil returns with tardy steps, eyes bent on the ground, all confidence erased, sighing, "Who hath denied me these abodes of woe?" He tells the protagonist not to fear his anger, for he will vanquish their hindrance. He notes this insolence is not new, as they displayed it "at gate less secret," which is "still without bolt," and the protagonist saw the "deadly scroll" on its arch. He announces that "even now on this side of its entrance, down the steep, passing the circles, unescorted, comes one whose strong might can open us this land."

**CANTO IX**
The protagonist's fear, imprinted on his pale cheeks, causes Virgil's newly worn hue to be chased and inwardly restrained. Virgil stands attentive, listening, as his eye cannot penetrate the "sable air, and the thick-gath'ring cloud." He begins, "It yet behooves we win this fight," then adds, "if not—Such aid to us is offer'd.—Oh, how long me seems it, ere the promis'd help arrive!" The protagonist notes the words are inconsistent, increasing his fear.
He asks Virgil if anyone ever descends into this "rueful concave's extreme depth" from the first degree (Limbo), whose pain is merely "deprivation of sweet hope." Virgil replies it "Rarely" happens, but he once came here, conjured by the sorceress Erictho, who compelled shades back to their bodies. Virgil states he entered these walls to draw forth a spirit from "Judas' circle," the "Lowest place" of all, "obscurest, and remov'd farthest from heav'n's all-circling orb." He knows the road well and assures the protagonist. He adds that the "noisome stench" of the lake encompasses the "city of grief," which they cannot enter without rage.
Virgil adds more, but the protagonist does not remember, as his eye is drawn to the burning top of the lofty tower. He instantly beholds "three hellish furies stain'd with blood," feminine in limb and motion, with green hydras twisting around them and adders and cerastes for hair.
Virgil, knowing these "miserable hags" who tend the "queen of endless woe," identifies them: Megaera (left), Alecto (right), and Tisiphone (middle). They claw their breasts, smite themselves, and raise such a clamor that the protagonist clings to Virgil. They cry, "Hasten Medusa: so to adamant him shall we change." They add that even when assailed by Theseus, they took "no ill revenge." Virgil warns the protagonist to turn around and hide his countenance, for if he views the "Gorgon dire," his "return upwards would be for ever lost." Virgil turns him around and hides him with his own hands. The narrator addresses readers to note the "lore conceal'd under close texture of the mystic strain."
A loud-crashing, terrible sound comes over the perturbed waves, making both shores tremble, like an impetuous wind. Virgil unbinds the protagonist's eyes and tells him to direct his sight along the "ancient foam," where the smoke is thickest. He sees "more than a thousand spirits destroy'd" fleeing before one who passes with "unwet feet the Stygian sound." This figure removes the "gross air" from his face, often stretching forth his left hand, seeming only weary from the annoyance. The protagonist perceives he is "sent from heav'n" and turns to Virgil, who signals him to stand quiet and bow to him. The heavenly messenger seems full of "noble anger." He comes to the gate and touches it with his wand, and it "flew open without impediment."
Standing on the "horrid grunsel," he addresses the "Outcasts of heav'n! O abject race and scorn'd!" demanding to know the source of their insolence and why they oppose God's will, which has "laid on you enforcement of your pangs." He reminds them that their Cerberus still bears a peeled throat and maw from a previous encounter.
He then turns back along the "filthy way," speaking no syllable to them, but appearing beset by other cares. They then move their steps "toward that territory, secure after the hallow'd words." They enter unopposed.
The protagonist, eager to learn, looks around and sees "wide-stretching space replete with bitter pain and torment ill." It resembles the sepulchers of Arles or Pola, but with scattered flames amidst the graves, burning intensely, hotter than iron for any craft. Their lids hang suspended, and from beneath, "lamentable moans" issue.
The protagonist asks Virgil who is interred in these vaults. Virgil replies that "The arch-heretics are here, accompanied by every sect their followers." Many more tombs are freighted, with "like with like" buried, and monuments differing "in degrees of heat." Virgil then turns to the right, and they pass between the afflicted and the high ramparts.

**CANTO X**
They proceed by a "secret pathway" between the walls and the tormented souls, Virgil first, the protagonist behind. The protagonist asks if those within the sepulchres can be seen, as the lids are raised and none keep watch. Virgil answers that the lids "shall be closed all, what-time they here from Josaphat return'd shall come, and bring their bodies, which above they now have left." He explains that this part of the cemetery holds Epicurus and his followers, who "with the body make the spirit die." He assures the protagonist that his question and silent wish will soon be satisfied. The protagonist says he only conceals his heart to avoid "vain length of words," a lesson Virgil taught him.
Suddenly, a voice from a vault cries, "O Tuscan! thou who through the city of fire alive art passing, so discreet of speech! Here please thee stay awhile. Thy utterance declares the place of thy nativity to be that noble land, with which perchance I too severely dealt." The protagonist, startled, moves closer to Virgil, who tells him to turn. "Lo, Farinata, there! who hath himself uplifted: from his girdle upwards all expos'd behold him." Farinata, with breast and forehead erect, seems to hold even hell in scorn. Virgil pushes the protagonist toward him, warning him to "See thy words be clear!"
Farinata eyes the protagonist, then disdainfully asks, "Say, what ancestors were thine?" The protagonist reveals his lineage. Farinata, somewhat uplifting his brow, cries that they were "fiercely adverse to me, my party, and the blood from whence I sprang: twice therefore I abroad scatter'd them." The protagonist replies that "Though driv'n out, yet they each time from all parts return'd; an art which yours have shown, they are not skill'd to learn."
Then, from Farinata's side, a shade rises "high as the chin," peering forth from the unclosed jaw, leaning on its raised knees. It looks around, as if to find someone else with the protagonist. Perceiving its "fond imagination quench'd," it speaks with tears: "If thou through this blind prison go'st, led by thy lofty genius and profound, where is my son? and wherefore not with thee?"
The protagonist replies he comes not of himself, but is conducted by Virgil, "whom perchance Guido thy son had in contempt." The words and context reveal the name. The shade, "up starting," exclaims, "How! said'st thou he HAD? No longer lives he? Strikes not on his eye the blessed daylight?" When the protagonist delays his reply, the shade falls supine and is seen no more.
Meanwhile, Farinata, "great of soul," remains stern, unchanged. Continuing their first discourse, he cries, "And if they in this art small skill have shown, that doth torment me more e'en than this bed." He prophesies that "not yet fifty times shall be relum'd her aspect, who reigns here Queen of this realm, ere thou shalt know the full weight of that art." He asks, if the protagonist wishes to return to the world, why the people of Florence are "so fell" against his kin.
The protagonist blames "The slaughter and great havoc that colour'd Arbia's flood with crimson stain." Farinata sighs and shakes his head, then replies that he "stood not singly" in that affray, but "singly there I stood, when by consent of all, Florence had to the ground been raz'd, The one who openly forbad the deed."
The protagonist adjures him to solve another doubt: "Ye seem to view beforehand, that which time leads with him, of the present uninform'd." Farinata answers that they "view, as one who hath an evil sight, plainly, objects far remote." God imparts "so much of his large spendour" to them, but "when they approach or actually exist, our intellect then wholly fails, nor of your human state except what others bring us know we aught." He concludes that their knowledge will expire when "on futurity the portals close."
Conscious of his fault, the protagonist, smitten by remorse, asks him to tell the fallen shade that his "offspring still is to the living join'd" and that his silence was due to his thoughts being intent on the error Virgil just solved.
Virgil summons him back. The protagonist eagerly asks Farinata who else shares his lot. Farinata replies, "More than a thousand with me here are laid. Within is Frederick, second of that name, And the Lord Cardinal, and of the rest I speak not." He then withdraws from sight.
The protagonist, returning to Virgil, ruminates on the words "betokening me such ill." Virgil, moving onward, asks about his "amaze." The protagonist satisfies the inquiry, and Virgil enjoins him to "store what thou hast heard to thee importing harm" and notes that "When thou shalt stand before her gracious beam, whose bright eye all surveys, she of thy life the future tenour will to thee unfold."
Virgil then turns his feet to the left. They leave the wall and go towards a path striking to a valley, which "e'en thus high exhal'd its noisome steam."

**CANTO XI**
They arrive at the "utmost verge of a high bank, by craggy rocks environ'd," where "woes beneath more cruel yet were stow'd." To avoid the "horrible excess of fetid exhalation," they stand retired behind the lid of a great monument. On it, the protagonist sees a scroll: "I have in charge Pope Anastasius, whom Photinus drew from the right path." Virgil explains they must delay their descent to accustom their senses to the dire breath. The protagonist agrees, asking for some compensation of the time.
Virgil says his thoughts align with the protagonist's wishes. He then explains that within these rocks are "three close circles in gradation plac'd." Each is full of accursed spirits, and to suffice the sight, he will explain why and how they abide in durance.
He states that the end of all "malicious act abhorr'd in heaven" is "injury," which works woe "either by force or fraud." Fraud, being "peculiar evil" to man, is more displeasing to God, so the fraudulent endure "severer pang." The violent occupy the first of these three circles, framed in three rounds because "three persons are obnoxious" to force: God, his neighbor, and himself.
Force against one's neighbor includes "violent death, and painful wounds," and wasting "substance by devastation, pillage, and the flames." Slayers, malicious smiters, plunderers, and robbers suffer in the first round in different herds.
Man can do violence "to himself and his own blessings." For this, he in the second round must "aye deplore with unavailing penitence his crime," whoever "deprives himself of life and light" (suicides) and wastes his talent in "reckless lavishment" (prodigals, here not previously mentioned as distinct from misers).
Force may be offered "to God, in the heart denying and blaspheming his high power, and nature with her kindly law contemning." Hence, the inmost round marks Sodom and Cahors (sodomites and usurers), and those who speak contemptuously of the Godhead.
Fraud, which stings every conscience, can be employed on one whose trust is won, or on another who withholds strict confidence. The latter breaks only the bond of love nature makes. Thus, in the second circle (of fraud, here described as less malicious), dwell dissimulation, witchcraft, flatteries, theft, falsehood, simony, seducers to lust, and those who pawn their honesty. The other way (fraud against trust, here described as more malicious) forgets both nature's general love and the "special faith" added. Thus, "in the lesser circle, point of the universe, dread seat of Dis," the traitor is "eternally consum'd."
The protagonist acknowledges Virgil's clear discourse and distinction of the chasm's inhabitants. He then asks why those in the "dull, fat pool," beaten by rain, driven by tempest, or conflicting with fierce tongues (from earlier circles), are not punished within the "city fire-illum'd" if God's wrath is on them. And if not, why are they condemned?
Virgil asks why his mind wanders, not accustomed to such thoughts. He reminds the protagonist of "thy ethic page" (Aristotle) which describes "Three dispositions adverse to Heav'n's will, Incont'nence, malice, and mad brutishness," and how incontinence "the least offends God, and least guilt incurs." If he notes this judgment and remembers those "without these walls to vain repentance doom'd," he will discern why they are placed apart and receive less vengeful divine justice.
The protagonist praises Virgil as a "Sun!" who heals his imperfect sight and solves his doubt, making ignorance as charming as knowledge. He then asks Virgil to explain why usury "offends celestial Goodness."
Virgil replies that philosophy clearly points out how "imitative nature takes her course from the celestial mind and from its art." He mentions the "Stagyrite" (Aristotle), whose laws, when unfolded, show that human art follows nature, being "second in descent from God." These two (nature and art), from creation's holy book, were the right source of life and excellence for mankind. But the usurer "walks in another path," setting nature and her follower at naught, placing his hope elsewhere.
Virgil then urges them to follow his steps, as "the Pisces play with undulating glance along the horizon," and "the Wain lies all o'er the north-west," indicating it is time for their "steep passage down the rocky height."

**CANTO XII**
The place where they descend the precipice is "rough as Alp," with an object on its verge "as every eye would shun." It is a ruin, like that struck by the Adice river near Trento, shattered from the mountain's summit, creating a passage. Stretched at the point of the ridge is "the infamy of Crete, detested brood of the feign'd heifer" (the Minotaur), gnawing itself in rage.
Virgil exclaims to the Minotaur, "Perchance thou deem'st the King of Athens here, who, in the world above, thy death contriv'd. Monster! avaunt! He comes not tutor'd by thy sister's art, but to behold your torments is he come." The Minotaur plunges like a bull struck by a fatal blow. Virgil tells the protagonist to "Run to the passage! while he storms, 't is well that thou descend."
They take their road down through dilapidated crags, which often move under the protagonist's feet, unused to such weight. The protagonist ponders this, and Virgil explains that when he "erst hither descended to the nether hell," this rock had not yet fallen. He deduces that it fell "not long ere He arrived, who carried off from Dis the mighty spoil of the highest circle," causing a trembling throughout the "deep concave and foul," as if the universe was thrilled with love. At that time, this old rock toppled down here and elsewhere.
Virgil then directs the protagonist's eyes beneath, where "the river of blood approaches, in the which all those are steep'd, who have by violence injur'd." The narrator exclaims against "blind lust" and "foolish wrath" that goad in brief life and overwhelm miserably in eternity.
He beholds an "ample foss, that in a bow was bent," circling the plain. Between it and the rampart, Centaurs run on trail, armed with keen arrows, as they were in life. Seeing them descend, the Centaurs stop. Three, with bows and missile weapons, speed forth, and one cries from afar, "Say to what pain ye come condemn'd, who down this steep have journied? Speak from whence ye stand, or else the bow I draw."
Virgil replies they will answer Chiron when nearer, rebuking the Centaur for his quick and rash mind. Virgil touches the protagonist and identifies the Centaur as Nessus, "who for the fair Deianira died, and wrought himself revenge for his own fate." The one in the middle, looking down on his breast, is Chiron, who nursed Achilles. The other is Pholus, "prone to wrath." Thousands of Centaurs patrol the foss, aiming shafts at any spirit emerging from the blood more than their guilt allows.
They approach the Centaurs, and Chiron takes an arrow, pushes back his shaggy beard with the notch, and, exposing his mouth, exclaims to his fellows, "Are ye aware, that he who comes behind moves what he touches? The feet of the dead are not so wont." Virgil, standing near Chiron's breast (where the two natures join), replies that the protagonist is "indeed alive," and he must needs be shown the gloomy vale, induced by "strict necessity, not by delight." He states that a "Dame from heaven" consigned this new office to his care. He affirms he is no robber or dark spirit. He asks Chiron to grant one of his band to guide them to the ford and convey the protagonist across on his back, as he is not a spirit who can walk the air.
Chiron turns to Nessus and tells him to return and be their guide, commanding any other troop to keep aloof. They move onward with Nessus, their faithful escort, along the border of the "crimson-seething flood," from which loud shrieks arise.
The protagonist marks some immersed up to their brow. Nessus identifies these as "the souls of tyrants, who were given to blood and rapine," wailing their "merciless wrongs." He points out Alexander and Dionysius, who wrought years of woe for Sicily. He identifies Azzolino by his "jetty clust'ring hair" and Obizzo of Este (destroyed by his step-son) by his "flaxen locks." The protagonist turns to Virgil, who says Nessus should be his first leader.
Nessus pauses near others immersed to the throat and points out a spirit apart, exclaiming, "He in God's bosom smote the heart, which yet is honour'd on the bank of Thames."
Next, the protagonist espies a race holding their heads and busts above the stream, recognizing many faces. The blood becomes shallower, eventually only imbruing their feet, and their path lies across the foss.
Nessus explains that as the boiling wave diminishes on this side, it sinks lower on the other, joining where "tyranny is to mourn." There, Heaven's justice chastises Attila ("scourge of earth"), Sextus, and Pyrrhus, extracting tears from the Rinieri (of Corneto) and Pazzo, who filled the ways with violence and war. Nessus then turns and, quitting them, repasses the ford alone.

**CANTO XIII**
Before Nessus reaches the other bank, they enter a forest with no worn path. The foliage is dusky, not verdant; the boughs are gnarled and thick, not light and tapering; there are thorns filled with venom instead of fruits. The narrator compares the brakes to those where animals hating cultivated fields abide between Corneto and Cecina's stream.
Here, "brute Harpies make their nest," the same who drove the Trojan band from Strophades with dire omens. They have broad wings, human necks and countenances, keen talons for feet, and huge bellies fledged with wings. They sit and wail in this "drear mystic wood."
Virgil informs the protagonist that he is in the "second round" until he reaches the "horrid sand," advising him to look around for things that would discredit his speech. The protagonist hears sad plainings but sees no one, standing amazed. Virgil, thinking the voices come from hidden figures, tells him, "If thou lop off a single twig from one of those ill plants, the thought thou hast conceiv'd shall vanish quite."
The protagonist stretches forth his hand, plucks a branch from a "great wilding," and the trunk exclaims, "Why pluck'st thou me?" As dark blood trickles, it adds, "Wherefore tear'st me thus? Is there no touch of mercy in thy breast? Men once were we, that now are rooted here." It states his hand "might well have spar'd us, had we been the souls of serpents." Words and blood burst from the broken splinter like a green brand hissing in the wind.
The protagonist lets fall the bough, terror-struck. Virgil apologizes to the injured spirit, explaining that the protagonist would not have done it had he believed what he has only read in verse. He prompted the deed because it "surpass'd belief." He asks the spirit who he was, so the protagonist may "revive his fame" in the upper world.
The trunk replies that Virgil's "pleasant word" has so "inveigled" him that he cannot refrain from speech. He was one "who held both keys to Frederick's heart," opening and shutting his inmost breast with skill. His faith to his "high charge" cost him his life-blood. The "harlot, who ne'er turn'd her gloating eyes from Caesar's household," inflamed minds against him, turning his "glad honours" to woes. His "soul, disdainful and disgusted," sought refuge in death from scorn, becoming "unjust toward myself." He swears by his roots that he never broke faith with his liege lord and asks, if any return to the world, to clear his memory from "envy's cruel blow."
After a pause, Virgil tells the protagonist to speak and ask more if he wishes. The protagonist replies he cannot, due to pity in his heart. Virgil then asks the spirit how the soul is tied in these "gnarled joints" and if any are ever "loosen'd from such frame."
The trunk breathes hard, and the wind changes into articulate sounds. He replies that when the "fierce soul from the body...torn asunder" departs, Minos dooms it to the "seventh gulf." It falls into the wood "no place assign'd, but wheresoever chance hurls it," sprouting like a grain into a sapling, then a "savage plant." The Harpies feed on its leaves, causing pain and a "vent to grief." They, like the rest, shall come for their "own spoils," but will not be clad again in them, "for what a man takes from himself it is not just he have." Their bodies will be hung "each on the wild thorn of his wretched shade."
As they listen, a noise like a wild boar and hunt approaching surprises them. Two naked spirits, torn with briers, flee headlong, breaking through the wood. The foremost cries, "Haste now, now haste thee death!" The other, impatient, exclaims, "Lano! not so bent for speed thy sinews, in the lists of Toppo's field." He then makes himself one group with a bush, perhaps for lack of breath. Behind them, the wood is full of "black female mastiffs, gaunt and fleet," like greyhounds slipped from leash. They seize the squatted spirit, tear him piecemeal, and bear away his limbs. Virgil seizes the protagonist's hand and leads him to the thicket, which mourns through its bleeding wounds, crying, "O Giacomo of Sant' Andrea! what avails it thee that of me thou hast made thy screen? For thy ill life what blame on me recoils?"
Virgil asks the thicket who he was. He replies, "O ye spirits: arriv'd in time to spy the shameful havoc, that from me my leaves hath sever'd thus, gather them up, and at the foot of their sad parent-tree carefully lay them." He states he dwelt in the city (Florence) that changed her patron for the Baptist, whence the Baptist "shall cease not with his art to work her woe." If some "faint glimpse of him" (the Baptist) had not remained on Arno's passage, those citizens who rebuilt her walls after Attila's ashes would have toiled in vain. He concludes, "I slung the fatal noose from my own roof."

**CANTO XIV**
Moved by "charity of native land," the protagonist collects the scattered leaves and restores them to the hoarse-voiced spirit. They reach the limit dividing the second and third rounds, where "horrible contrivance" of justice is displayed. They enter a plain of "arid sand and thick," resembling the soil Cato trod, which repels every plant. The "mournful wood waves round its garland on all sides," and the "sad foss spreads round the wood."
Many naked spirits are seen, all weeping piteously, subjected to different laws: some supine on the earth, some crouching, others pacing incessantly. The pacers are most numerous, the supine fewer but louder in grief.
Over all the sand, "dilated flakes of fire" fall slowly, like snow on an Alpine summit when the wind is hushed. The narrator compares it to the solid flames Alexander saw descending on his army in India, which he had his troops trample to extinguish the vapor. So falls the "eternal fiery flood," making the marble glow "as under stove the viands, doubly to augment the pain."
Wretched hands incessantly ply, shaking off the fresh-falling heat. The protagonist asks Virgil who the "huge spirit" is that "heeds not the burning, but lies writhen in proud scorn."
The spirit himself, aware of the question, exclaims, "Such as I was when living, dead such now I am. If Jove weary his workman out... if the rest be weary out at their black smithy labouring... and the bolts launch he full aim'd at me with all his might, He never should enjoy a sweet revenge."
Virgil, in a raised voice, replies, "Capaneus! Thou art more punish'd, in that this thy pride lives yet unquench'd: no torrent, save thy rage, were to thy fury pain proportion'd full." He then turns to the protagonist with milder lip, explaining that Capaneus was one of the "seven kings, who girt the Theban walls with siege," and still holds God in disdain, setting His omnipotence at naught. But his "despiteful mood is ornament well suits the breast that wears it."
Virgil tells the protagonist to follow him, keeping close to the wood and not stepping on the hot sand. They pass silently to a little brook gushing from the forest's bound, whose "crimson'd wave yet lifts my hair with horror." It runs through the sand like the rill from Bulicame, its bottom and banks "stone-built," where their passage lies.
Virgil declares this river to be the most worthy of regard of all he has shown, as "o'er which the flaming volley all is quench'd." The protagonist asks for an explanation.
Virgil begins by describing Crete, an island in the ocean, where the world once lived pure and chaste under its monarch. A mountain called Ida there, once joyous, now deserted, was where Rhea hid Saturn's son, drowning his cries with shouts. Within the mount, a "huge ancient form" stands upright, turning its shoulders toward Damiata and looking at Rome "as in his mirror." Its head is of "finest gold," breast and arms of "pure silver," then to the middle of "brass," and downward all beneath "well-temper'd steel," save the right foot of "potter's clay." Each part except the gold is rent, and from the fissures tears distil, joining to penetrate a cave. These tears form Acheron, Styx, and Phlegethon, then passing beneath through a straitened channel, form Cocytus in the lowest depth, which the protagonist will see later.
The protagonist asks why, if this sluice is derived from their world, it appears only now. Virgil explains the place is round, and though they have passed a great part, descending to the nethermost, they have not yet circled the whole orb.
The protagonist then asks where Phlegethon and Lethe flow, as one was not mentioned and the other is formed from the shower. Virgil replies that his questions please him, but the "red seething wave" (Phlegethon) should have resolved one. Lethe, he says, will be seen "not within this hollow, in the place, whither to lave themselves the spirits go, whose blame hath been by penitence remov'd."
He concludes that it is time to leave the wood and instructs the protagonist to follow his steps, as the margins provide safe passage, unimpeded by flames because "over them all vapour is extinct."

**CANTO XV**
They are now borne on one of the solid margins, enveloped in a mist from the stream that hovers over and protects the piers and water from fire. The narrator compares these mounds to those built by Flemings between Ghent and Bruges, or by Paduans along the Brenta, to defend against floods.
Not far from the wood, they meet a troop of spirits walking beside the pier. They eye the protagonist intently, like an old tailor at a needle's eye. One recognizes the protagonist, catches him by the skirt, and cries, "What wonder have we here!"
The protagonist fixes his gaze on the spirit's parched looks, and though smirched with fire, he remembers him. He asks, "Sir! Brunetto! And art thou here?" Brunetto Latini asks if it would displease the protagonist if he turned back a little to speak with him, leaving his fellows. The protagonist eagerly agrees, offering to sit with him if Virgil permits.
Brunetto explains that anyone from this throng who stops for an instant lies for a hundred years without ventilation from the fire. He bids the protagonist pass on, and he will walk close by his garments, then rejoin his troop. The protagonist dares not descend to walk on equal ground, but holds his head bent down.
Brunetto asks what chance or destiny brings him here before his last day, and who guides him. The protagonist replies that in the "life serene," he wandered lost in a valley before his age reached fullness. He met Virgil "yester-morn" and is now being led back home by this path.
Brunetto answers that if the protagonist follows his "star," he will reach a "glorious haven," unless Brunetto's judgment erred in "fairer days." He wishes he could have given comfort in the protagonist's work, but the "ungrateful and malignant race" from Fesole, still showing their "rough mountain-flint" nature, will show enmity for his good deeds. He warns that it "suits not the sweet fig-tree lay her fruit" amongst "ill-savour'd crabs." He describes them as blind, covetous, envious, and proud, advising the protagonist to cleanse himself of their ways. He prophesies that the protagonist's fortune has such honor in reserve that "either party shalt be crav'd with hunger keen," but he should keep "the fresh herb far from the goat's tooth." The "herd of Fesole" may make litter of themselves but should not touch the plant (the protagonist), if any such still springs from their "rank bed," where the "holy seed revives" from true Romans.
The protagonist replies that if his wish were fulfilled, Brunetto would not have been driven from "man's nature." He keeps the "dear, benign, paternal image" of Brunetto fixed in his mind, remembering how he taught him "the way for man to win eternity." He resolves to speak of this lesson as long as life endures. He writes down what Brunetto tells him of his fate and keeps it with "another text to comment on for her, the celestial dame, who will know all, if I to her arrive." He declares his conscience clear, prepared for fortune's will.
Virgil, turning back, smiles and says, "He listens to good purpose who takes note."
The protagonist continues, discoursing with Brunetto, asking who are most known among his tribe. Brunetto replies it's good to know some, but silence is best for the rest, as time is short. He briefly states that all these were "clerks, men of great learning and no less renown, by one same sin polluted." He names Priscian and Francesco, Accorso's son, and says if the protagonist wished to see "so impure a blotch," he might have seen one transferred "from Arno's seat to Bacchiglione, where his ill-strain'd nerves he left." Brunetto would add more, but must desist from speech and way, as he sees "a mist new-risen on the sandy plain." A company he cannot join approaches. He commends his "TREASURE" (presumably his literary works) to the protagonist, "wherein I yet survive."
Brunetto then turns and seems like one who tries for the green mantle prize in Verona's champaign, "not he who loses but who gains the prize."

**CANTO XVI**
The protagonist arrives where the water's din is heard, falling into the next round, like the hum of swarming bees. From a troop passing beneath the "fierce tormenting storm," three spirits run swiftly towards them, crying, "Oh do thou stay! Whom by the fashion of thy garb we deem to be some inmate of our evil land." The narrator notes the wounds on their limbs, both recent and old, inflicted by the flames, grieving at the memory.
Virgil pauses and turns to the protagonist, saying, "Wait now! our courtesy these merit well: And were 't not for the nature of the place, whence glide the fiery darts, I should have said, That haste had better suited thee than them."
When they stop, the three spirits resume their wail, and as they reach them, they whirl around together "in one restless wheel," like naked champions smeared with oil. Each directs his face at the protagonist, their necks moving opposite their feet.
One spirit begins, asking the protagonist, "who thou art, that dost imprint with living feet unharm'd the soil of Hell." He points out his companion as Guidoguerra, "grandchild of the chaste Gualdrada," of high estate, who achieved noble acts by wisdom and sword. The next is Aldobrandi, deserving of honor in the upper world. The speaker identifies himself as Rusticucci, brought to this evil by his "savage temper" wife, more than aught else. The protagonist states that if not for fear of fire, he would have cast himself among them, and his guide would not have restrained him, but fear vanquished his desire for their embrace.
He tells them that their doom fills him not with scorn but with grief, fixed deep within him since Virgil spoke of their race. He says he is their countryman, affectionate to their renowned deeds and names. He is leaving "the gall for the sweet fruit" with a sure guide, tending downward to the center first.
Guidoguerra asks the protagonist to tell if "courtesy and valour, as they wont, dwell in our city, or have vanish'd clean?" for one recently condemned to wail, Borsiere, grieves them with his news. The protagonist cries, "An upstart multitude and sudden gains, pride and excess, O Florence! have in thee engender'd, so that now in tears thou mourn'st!" The three spirits look at each other as if hearing truth. They tell him if he easily satisfies questioners, he is happy. They ask him to speak of them among mankind if he escapes "this darksome clime" and returns to see the stars.
They break the circle and flee swiftly. The protagonist notes they vanished quicker than one could say "Amen." Virgil pursues his track, and the protagonist follows. The sound of water becomes so loud they can barely hear each other.
The narrator describes the water's sound as like a river (Acquacheta) that rebellows over Saint Benedict as it falls from an Alpine summit down a precipice, where space enough for a thousand spreads.
The protagonist has a cord around his girdle, which he once thought to use to bind the "painted leopard." At Virgil's command, he unloosens it and hands it to him. Virgil turns to the right, and from the brink, a few paces distant, casts it down into the deep abyss. The protagonist wonders what strange signal this is that Virgil follows intently. He reflects on how men must be cautious with those who "spy into the thoughts with subtle skill."
Virgil says that what he expects, the protagonist's eye will quickly discover, and "that whereof thy thought is dreaming." The narrator comments that a man should bar his lip from truth that wears "the semblance of a falsehood," but here silence is vain. He swears, by his notes, that through the "gross and murky air," he spied "A shape come swimming up, that might have quell'd the stoutest heart with wonder," like one returning from loosening an anchor or aught else from the sea, drawing in his feet as he springs upward.

**CANTO XVII**
Virgil addresses the protagonist, "Lo! the fell monster with the deadly sting! Who passes mountains, breaks through fenced walls and firm embattled spears, and with his filth taints all the world!" He beckons the monster to shore.
The "vile image of fraud" (Geryon) appears, its head and upper part on land, but its "bestial train" not on the shore. Its face resembles a "just man," kind and gracious, but the rest is serpent. Two shaggy claws reach its armpits, and its back, breast, and sides are painted with nodes and orbits in variegated colors. It sits perched on the rim, its tail upturned, armed with a scorpion's sting.
Virgil states they must turn toward this "ill beast." They shape their course to the right, proceeding ten paces along the verge to escape the flame and burning marl. Arriving, the protagonist sees a "tribe of spirits, seated on the sand near the wide chasm." Virgil tells him to go and mark their mien but not to speak long, as he will parley with Geryon to gain the "aid of his strong shoulders."
The protagonist walks alone along the extremity of the seventh circle, where the "mournful tribe" is seated. Pangs gush from their eyes. They alternately ply their shifting hands against the vapors and torrid soil, like dogs in summer warding off gnats or flies.
He notes their visages, but knows none of them, only perceiving that each bears a pouch hanging from his neck, "with colours and with emblems various mark'd," on which "it seem'd as if their eye did feed." He sees a yellow purse with an azure lion, then a redder one with a white-winged goose. One, bearing a fat, azure swine on his white scrip, asks, "What dost thou in this deep? Go now and know, since yet thou livest, that my neighbour here Vitaliano on my left shall sit. A Paduan with these Florentines am I. Ofttimes they thunder in mine ears, exclaiming 'O haste that noble knight! he who the pouch with the three beaks will bring!'" He then writhes his mouth and lolls his tongue like an ox licking his nostrils. The protagonist turns back from these spirits.
He finds Virgil already seated on the "haunch of the fierce animal" (Geryon). Virgil encourages him to be "stout" and "bold," as they must descend a "steep flight." He tells the protagonist to mount first, and he will be in the middle to prevent the tail from harming him.
The protagonist, hearing this, turns blue and quivers like one with an ague fit. But shame makes him bold. He settles on Geryon's huge shoulders, wanting to say, "Look thou clasp me firm!" but the words fail. Virgil, whose succor he has proved before, embraces him and holds him up. He tells Geryon, "now move thee! be thy wheeling gyres of ample circuit, easy thy descent. Think on th' unusual burden thou sustain'st."
Geryon loosens from the land, turns its forked tail where its breast had been, and steers like an eel, gathering air with retractable claws. The protagonist's dread is immense, greater than Phaeton or Icarus's falls, as he sees only the "fell beast" and air around him. Geryon slowly sails downward, unnoticed by the protagonist, except for the wind from below. The protagonist hears a hideous crash of the cataract on their right. Bending down to explore, he conceives new terror at the steep plunge, seeing flames and hearing wailings, realizing their downward course is winding.
Geryon descends like a weary falcon, landing them at the base of the "deep-furrow'd rock," discharges his burden, and springs forward like an arrow.

**CANTO XVIII**
They are now in Malebolge, a place in the depths of hell, "all of rock dark-stain'd with hue ferruginous," encircling a spacious gulf. This region forms ten trenches in its hollow bottom, like fosses around a castle. Flinty paths advance from the rock's base, crossing moles and dikes to the gulf. Dislodged from Geryon's back, they are in this place. Virgil goes left, and the protagonist follows.
On their right, the protagonist sees "new misery, new pains, new executioners of wrath," swarming in the first chasm. Naked sinners below come meeting them from the middle, passing them with a larger stride. The narrator compares this to Romans during Jubilee, managing crowds on a bridge.
He sees "Horn'd demons... with lashes huge," smiting the sinners' backs, making them bound at the first stripe, none waiting for a second or third.
He spots one sinner and cries, "Of him... not yet mine eye hath had his fill." Virgil pauses, allowing him to walk backward and scan the spirit, who tries to hide. The protagonist exclaims, "Thou who dost cast thy eye upon the ground, unless thy features do belie thee much, Venedico art thou." He asks what brings him to this "bitter seas'ning." The spirit replies unwillingly, constrained by the protagonist's clear speech that recalls the world. He confesses he was Venedico, who "led fair Ghisola to do the Marquis' will." He adds that Bologna sends many barterers here, and they would rather say 'aye' for lucre than 'no'. If proof is needed, remember their craving thirst for gold.
A demon strikes him with his thong, exclaiming, "Away! corrupter! here women are none for sale." The protagonist rejoins Virgil, and they reach a rock that issued from the bank. They ascend it and turn right, departing from the "eternal barriers."
Arriving where the "gaping arch lets pass the scourged souls," Virgil tells him to pause and observe these "miserable others," faces not yet beheld, who have walked with them. From the old bridge, they eye a pack coming from the other side, excoriated by the lash. Virgil, unasked, identifies a "lofty shade" as Jason, who won the ram from Colchos. His passage to Lemnos led him to beguile Hypsipyle, a young virgin who had first beguiled the rest of the women (who had slain all their males). He left her impregnated and forlorn. This guilt condemns him, and Medea's injuries are avenged here. All who practiced similar deceit bear him company. This suffices for the first vale.
They then cross the next pier to another arch. In the second chasm, they hear ghosts jibbering "in low melancholy sounds," snorting with "wide-stretch'd nostrils," and smiting themselves with palms. A scurf of condensed foul steam hangs on the banks, combating sight and smell.
The depth is so hollow that nothing can be distinguished from above. They reach it, and the protagonist sees a crowd immersed in "ordure, that appear'd draff of the human body." He marks one with a grimed head, hard to discern if clerk or layman. The spirit cries, "Why greedily thus bendest more on me, than on these other filthy ones, thy ken?"
The protagonist replies he has seen him with dry locks and he is Alessio of Lucca. The spirit replies his "flatteries have sunk" him thus low. Virgil points out "that besotted, sluttish courtezan, who there doth rend her with defiled nails," identifying her as Thais, "the harlot, whose false lip answer'd her doting paramour that ask'd, 'Thankest me much!'—'Say rather wondrously.'"

**CANTO XIX**
The narrator exclaims woe to Simon Magus and his followers who prostitute "the things of God... for gold and silver in adultery," for theirs is the third chasm. They mount the following vault, where the rock impends over the center of the foss. The narrator marvels at Divine Wisdom.
He sees the "livid stone" full of apertures, all circular and equal in width, like baptismal fonts in Saint John's dome, one of which he once broke to save an infant. From each aperture, a sinner's feet and legs up to the calf emerge, the rest hidden beneath. Their soles are burning, causing their "flexile joints" to glance with violent motion. Flames glide from heel to point, scarcely touching.
The protagonist asks who the spirit is "glancing in fiercer agony," on whom a ruddier flame preys. Virgil offers to carry him down to the least steep bank so the spirit can tell his story. The protagonist agrees.
They descend to the depth of the fourth pier, a narrow, perforated strait. Virgil sets him down at the orifice of the quivering limb. The protagonist addresses the "sad spirit! thus revers'd, and as a stake driv'n in the soil," asking him to speak. He feels like a friar shriving a condemned murderer.
The spirit shouts, "Ha! already standest there? Already standest there, O Boniface! By many a year the writing play'd me false. So early dost thou surfeit with the wealth, for which thou fearedst not in guile to take the lovely lady, and then mangle her?"
The protagonist is bewildered, but Virgil admonishes him to quickly say, "I am not he, not he, whom thou believ'st." The protagonist complies.
The spirit wrenches his feet and sighs woefully, asking what the protagonist requires. If it imports him to know his identity, he says he was "rob'd in the mighty mantle" and was "the son of a she-bear," eager to advance his whelps, having "stow'd" his wealth above and himself here. He states that others, his predecessors in simony, are dragged beneath his head, and he will fall among them when the one for whom he mistook the protagonist arrives. He notes that he has stood "Upturn'd with fiery feet" longer than the coming one. After him, "one yet of deeds more ugly shall arrive, from forth the west, a shepherd without law, fated to cover both his form and mine." This new Jason will receive favor from "France's monarch."
The protagonist replies, asking what treasures Christ demanded of St. Peter when giving him the keys, noting he asked only "Follow me!" and neither Peter nor the others took gold or silver. He declares the spirit's punishment merited and warns him to "look well to that ill-gotten coin." He says if not for reverence for the keys, he would speak more severely. He blames their avarice for casting the world in mourning, treading good underfoot and raising bad men. He refers to the Evangelist who saw the "whore who sits upon the waves, with kings in filthy whoredom." He condemns them for making gold and silver their god. He attributes much ill to Constantine's "plenteous dower," not his conversion.
As the protagonist speaks, the spirit, whether smitten by wrath or conscience, violently springs up, spinning on his soles. Virgil is pleased. He catches the protagonist in his arms, lifts him to his bosom, and retraces his descent. He carries him without weariness to the summit of the rock, their passage from the fourth to the fifth pier. He gently places his "cherish'd burden" on the rugged rock.
Thence, another vale appears.

**CANTO XX**
The narrator introduces the twentieth canto about new torments. He looks into the depth, moistened with tears, and sees a tribe weeping silently, walking along the hollow vale like choirs chanting litanies.
He observes each spirit wondrously reversed at the neck-bone, their countenances averted from their reins, compelled to advance backward because they cannot look forward. He notes that one might be "by force of palsy clean transpos'd," but he has never seen it.
The narrator addresses the reader, asking how he could keep his face dry seeing "our form distorted in such guise, that on the hinder parts fall'n from the face the tears down-streaming roll'd." He leans against a rock and weeps. Virgil exclaims, "What, and art thou too witless as the rest? Here pity most doth show herself alive, when she is dead. What guilt exceedeth his, who with Heaven's judgment in his passion strives?"
Virgil tells him to raise his head and see Amphiaraus, before whose eyes earth gaped in Thebes, falling to Minos. He notes how Amphiaraus makes his breast his shoulders, and who once wished to see too far before him, now looks backward and treads reverse. He then points out Tiresias, "who semblance chang'd, when woman he became of male," and then again became male by striking two entwining serpents with his rod.
Next comes Aruns, "with more his belly facing," who dwelt in a cavern in Luni's mountains, from which he held a boundless view of stars and sea.
The next is Manto, whose "loosen'd tresses overspread her bosom." She searched many regions and fixed her seat in Virgil's "native land." He recounts her story: after her father's death, she wandered, then found a waste territory in a fen in Italy, where she remained, practicing her arts with her slaves, and lived and left her body. Tribes gathered to that strong place, enclosed by the fen, and built a city on her "dead bones," calling it Mantua, for she first chose the spot. He warns the protagonist against any other origin story for his country.
The protagonist tells Virgil his words are certain. He asks if there are any other spirits "that merit more especial note."
Virgil identifies Eurypylus, whose beard sweeps over his shoulders, as the seer from Aulis who gave the sign to cut the cable when Greece was emptied of males. He says he sang of him in his "tragic strain." The other, "so slender of his shape," was Michael Scot, skilled in magic.
He points out Guido Bonatti and Asdente, who now repents leaving his thread and cordwain. Next, he points to "wretches, who the needle left, the shuttle and the spindle, and became diviners," working "baneful witcheries with images and herbs."
Virgil then notes it is time to move on, as Cain now confines with a fork of thorns on either hemisphere beneath Seville's towers. He reminds the protagonist the moon was round yesternight, which served him in the "gloom of the deep wood." They both move onward.

**CANTO XXI**
They pass from bridge to bridge with other talk not rehearsed in the drama, reaching the summit to view another gap in Malebolge with "other bootless pangs." The place is shrouded in "Marvelous darkness."
The narrator compares the scene to the Venetian arsenal where pitch boils in winter to smear unsound vessels. So, "not by force of fire but art divine" boils a "glutinous thick mass," liming all the shore beneath. He sees nothing but the surge of the boiling.
Virgil exclaims, "Mark! mark!" and draws the protagonist away. The protagonist turns, seeing a "devil black" running along the rock, with fierce cruelty in his look, buoyant outstretched wings, and nimble feet. His shoulder is charged with a sinner, held by the haunch, gripping the foot's sinew fast.
The devil cries, "Ye of our bridge! keen-talon'd fiends! Lo! one of Santa Zita's elders! Him whelm ye beneath, while I return for more." He adds that the land (Lucca) has many such, all barterers except Bonturo, where "of 'no' for lucre there an 'aye' is quickly made." He dashes the sinner down and returns with eager haste. The sinner sinks, then rises writhing to the surface. The dark demons from beneath the bridge cry, "Here the hallow'd visage saves not: here is other swimming than in Serchio's wave. Wherefore if thou desire we rend thee not, Take heed thou mount not o'er the pitch." They grapple him with hooks, shouting, "Cover'd thou must sport thee here; so, if thou canst, in secret mayst thou filch." The narrator compares this to a cook thrusting meat into a cauldron with flesh-hooks.
Virgil tells the protagonist to hide behind a craggy rock lest they descry him, and not to fear any force or insult to Virgil, as he has been in similar frays. Virgil passes the bridge's head and reaches the sixth pier, showing a "forehead terror-proof."
The demons rush forth like dogs on a poor man, pointing their weapons at Virgil. Virgil cries, "Be none of you outrageous: ere your time dare seize me, come forth from amongst you one, who having heard my words, decide he then if he shall tear these limbs." They shout, "Go, Malacoda!" One advances, asking, "What may this turn avail him?"
Virgil answers that he came so far "without will divine and destiny propitious," for "Heaven's pleasure is, that I should lead another through this savage wilderness." Malacoda's pride falls, he drops his instrument of torture, and tells the rest they have "no power to strike him." Virgil tells the crouching protagonist to safely return to him.
The protagonist rises, moving with speed, fearing the fiends might break their compact. He compares this fear to infantry at Caprona fearing the foe might break a covenant. He adheres to Virgil, observing their "unkindly visage." The fiends speak of touching him on the hip, but Malacoda turns rapidly, saying, "Stay, stay thee, Scarmiglione!"
Malacoda tells them that the rock offers no further footing because it is "shiver'd to the base of the sixth arch." But to proceed, they can go up "by this cavern," where "another rock will yield you passage safe." He explains that yesterday, "later by five hours than now, Twelve hundred threescore years and six had fill'd the circuit of their course, since here the way was broken." He dispatches a troop of ten scouts, led by Barbariccia, to spy if any bask on the surface and to lead them safely where the other crag traverses the dens. He names them: Alichino, Calcabrina, Cagnazzo, Libicocco, Draghinazzo, Ciriatto (fanged), Graffiacane, Farfarello, and Rubicant.
The protagonist expresses fear, asking Virgil if they should journey alone without escort, as the fiends gnarl and threaten tortures. Virgil reassures him not to fear, saying it is only a token of their spite against the tormented souls.
The fiends turn left over the pier, each pressing his tongue between his teeth, looking for a signal from their leader, who gives it with an "obscene triumphant" sound.

**CANTO XXII**
The narrator recalls having seen cavalry in martial order, but never such a strange formation as the ten demons moving with them. He calls it "fearful company."
He gazes at the pitch to mark everything within the chasm. Like dolphins showing their backs to warn mariners, some sinners show their backs to ease pain, then hide. Like frogs at the brink of a moat with only their jaws out, the sinners stand, but soon as Barbariccia approaches, they hide under the wave. The protagonist sees one sinner who waits. Graffiacan, the nearest fiend, seizes his "clotted locks" and drags him up, making him appear like an otter. The narrator knew their names from when they were chosen. The cursed crew shouts, "O Rubicant! See that his hide thou with thy talons flay."
The protagonist asks Virgil what wretched soul this is. Virgil approaches and asks where he comes from. The spirit replies he was born in Navarre, placed in a lord's retinue by his mother (who bore him to a vile spendthrift). He served King Thibault, then turned to "peculating," for which he now gives account in this heat.
Ciriatto, with tusks like a boar, rips him. Barbariccia seizes the sinner with both arms, crying, "Stand thou apart, while I do fix him on my prong transpierc'd." He tells Virgil to inquire further before the sinner is rent again. Virgil asks about his partners in guilt from Latian land under the tar. The sinner replies he just parted from one nearby and wishes he were with him, safe from hooks and talons.
Libicocco cries, "Too long we suffer," and seizes the sinner's arm with a prong, mangling the sinewy part. Draghinazzo attempts to catch his thighs, but Barbariccia angrily restrains them. When the strife ceases, Virgil asks about the spirit from whom he parted.
The sinner replies it was "the friar Gomita," from Gallura, a "vessel of all guile," who had his master's enemies in hand and used them well, taking money to dismiss them. He "play'd the part of barterer to the height" in all charges. Michel Zanche, chief of Logodoro, herds with him. Sardinia is a theme they never tire of. The sinner points out another who grins and expresses fear of being mauled.
Barbariccia rebukes Farfarello, who rolls his "moony eyes in act to strike," crying, "Off! cursed bird! Avaunt!"
The sinner, quaking, offers to make Tuscan or Lombard spirits appear if the fiends "bate their fury." He promises to make seven appear with his whistle, as it is their custom to call each other. Cagnazzo grins deridingly, saying it's a mischievous device to plunge him down. The sinner replies it would only bring him more woe.
Alichino, gainsaying the rest, says if the sinner casts himself down, he will pursue him above the pitch with his plumes. He suggests they quit the vantage ground and let the bank be a shield to see if the sinner can prevail alone.
The narrator invites the reader to expect new sport. The fiends turn their eyes to the other shore. The Navarrese spirit, choosing his time well, plants his feet on land and leaps, escaping them. Quick resentment stings the fiends, especially Alichino, who pursues him, exclaiming, "Thou art caught." But terror outstrips his flight. The sinner plunges beneath the pitch, and Alichino, with upward pinion, raises his breast. The narrator compares this to a waterfowl diving from a falcon.
This mockery angers Calcabrina, who flies after Alichino and turns his talons on his comrade for the escape. They grapple over the dyke and fall into the boiling lake. The heat becomes umpire, and their glued plumes prevent them from lifting themselves. Barbariccia, lamenting, dispatches four fiends from the other coast to their posts, armed with hooks, to retrieve the struggling fiends. They leave them to their broil.

**CANTO XXIII**
They proceed in silence, one first, the other following, like minor friars. The recent fray makes the narrator muse on Aesop's fable of the mouse and frog, noting the similarity in sense between the events. This thought leads to another, doubling his fear: the fiends, foiled and mocked, will pursue them more fiercely than a hound chasing a leveret.
His hair stands on end, and he looks back. He tells Virgil to hide them quickly from the "evil talons" that seem to urge them from behind, as imagination works so powerfully he already feels them.
Virgil replies that his thoughts are already presented before his own, similar in act and countenance, so he has formed one design. If the right coast inclines enough to descend into the other chasm, they will escape this "imagined pursuit."
Before he finishes, the narrator sees the fiends approaching with spread wings. Virgil suddenly catches him "ev'n as a mother" awakened by fire snatches her babe and flies. He casts himself supine down from the jutting beach to a pendent rock that closes one part of the chasm.
Virgil runs along the edge with hurrying pace, carrying the narrator in his bosom. Scarcely have his feet reached the lowest bed when the fiends reach the steep above them. But Virgil feels no fear, for high Providence, which placed them as ministers of the fifth foss, took from them the power of departing thence.
In the depth, they see a "painted tribe," pacing slowly, weeping, faint and toiled. They wear caps with hoods like Cologne monks, overlaid with dazzling gold but leaden within, of such weight that Frederick's were straw by comparison. The narrator exclaims at the "everlasting wearisome attire!"
