They turn left with the spirits, intent on their dismal moan. The fainting people move so slowly that their company changes at every step. The narrator asks Virgil to find a spirit whose name is known by his deeds.
One spirit, understanding Tuscan, cries out to them to stop. Virgil tells the narrator to pause and proceed at their pace. The narrator waits and sees two spirits eager to overtake him, but their load and the narrow path retard them.
Arriving, they eye him askance, then one asks the other, "This one seems, by the action of his throat, alive. And, be they dead, what privilege allows they walk unmantled by the cumbrous stole?" Then to the narrator: "Tuscan, who visitest the college of the mourning hypocrites, disdain not to instruct us who thou art."
The narrator replies he was bred in Florence by the Arno and wears the body he has ever worn. He asks who they are, suffering such grief. One answers that their "bonnets gleaming bright with orange hue" are so "leaden gross, that with their weight they make the balances to crack beneath them." They were "Joyous friars," natives of Bologna, Catalano (the speaker) and Loderingo, taken by Florence as arbitrators to reconcile strifes. Gardingo's vicinage can best declare how they fared.
The narrator begins to speak of their miseries, but is interrupted by seeing one fixed to a cross with three stakes. This spirit writhes and sighs deeply. Catalano points out that this "pierced spirit" was Caiaphas, who advised the Pharisees that one man should suffer for the people. He lies transverse, and everyone who passes must make "feeling trial how each weighs" on him. The father of his consort and others in that council are placed in similar straits. The narrator notes Virgil gazing with wonder at Caiaphas.
Virgil asks the friar if there is an opening on their right to leave without constraint on the dark angels. The friar replies that "Nearer than thou dost hope, there is a rock from the next circle moving, which o'ersteps each vale of horror, save that here his cope is shatter'd. By the ruin ye may mount: For on the side it slants, and most the height rises below." Virgil stands with head bent, then says, "He warn'd us ill, Who yonder hangs the sinners on his hook." The friar adds that at Bologna, he heard many vices of the devil, including "He is a liar, and the father of lies!"
Virgil proceeds with large strides, somewhat disturbed by anger. The narrator leaves the "spirits heavy laden" and follows his footsteps.

**CANTO XXIV**
In the early part of the year, when the sun is in Aquarius and nights recede towards equal day, the rime whitens the plain. A village hind, lacking winter stores, at first laments, then finds new hope as the world changes, and drives his flock to pasture. Similarly, the protagonist was disheartened by Virgil's troubled forehead, but that ill was quickly cured. At the fallen bridge, Virgil turns back with a sweet look. Regarding the ruin, and after internal counsel, he opens his arms and lifts the protagonist. Like a workman calculating his labor, Virgil lifts him to one peak, then fixes his eye on another, telling him to "Grapple that... but first make proof, if it be such as will sustain thee."
The narrator notes this would be no journey for one capped with lead. Scarcely could he, though light, and the protagonist, though pushed from crag to crag, mount. If this precinct were not less ample than the last, his strength would have failed. Malebolge, inclining toward the mouth of the nethermost abyss, requires each valley to slope upward on one side and fall on the other.
They reach the point of descent from the last flag, and the protagonist is so exhausted he must sit. Virgil tells him to "Now needs thy best of man," for fame is not won on downy plumes or under canopies. Without fame, one leaves "such vestige of himself on earth, as smoke in air or foam upon the wave." He urges him to rise, banish weariness by mind's effort, as a "longer ladder yet remains to scale."
The protagonist rises, appearing less spent than he feels, and cries, "On, for I am stout and fearless." They hold their way up the rock, more rugged, narrower, and steeper than before. The protagonist talks ceaselessly to appear less faint. A voice from the other foss issues forth, "for utt'rance suited ill." Though standing on the arch, he cannot understand the words, but the speaker seems angry. He stoops but cannot see the depth for darkness. He asks Virgil to bend their steps to the next circle and dismount from the wall. Virgil replies, "I answer not... but by the deed. To fair request silent performance maketh best return."
They descend from the bridge's head to the eighth mound, and the chasm opens to view. Inside, the protagonist sees a crowd of "serpents terrible, so strange of shape and hideous, that remembrance in my veins yet shrinks the vital current." He dismisses Libya's boast of snakes, saying it never showed such plagues in numbers or direness.
Amidst this "dread exuberance of woe," naked spirits run, "wing'd with horrid fear," with no hope of hiding. Serpents bind their hands behind them, their tails and heads twisted in folds before their reins. An adder darts onto one near them, transpiercing him where the neck joins the shoulders. Quicker than a pen writes O or I, the spirit kindles, burns, and changes to ashes. The dust then spontaneously re-rolls and instantly resumes the same form. The narrator compares this to the Arabian Phoenix. The sinner rises aghast.
The narrator remarks on God's severe judgment. Virgil asks who the spirit is. He replies, "Vanni Fucci am I call'd, not long since rained down from Tuscany to this dire gullet." He states the "bestial life and not the human pleas'd," a mule from Pistoia.
The protagonist asks Virgil to make him stay and ask his crime, recalling him as a "choleric and bloody" man. The sinner hears and, with dismal shame depicted on his face, says it grieoves him more to be caught by the protagonist in this sad plight than when he was taken from life. He is doomed here for having robbed the sacristy of its ornaments and falsely charged another. To ensure the protagonist does not joy in his suffering, he forebodes what will happen: Pistoia will pine, reft of the Neri; Florence will change citizens and laws. A vapor, drawn by Mars, will rise from Valdimagra, wrapped in turbid mists, and drive a storm with "arrowy hurtling o'er Piceno's field," bursting suddenly to strike "Each helpless Bianco prostrate to the ground." He tells this to rend the protagonist's heart.

**CANTO XXV**
After speaking, the sinner raises his hands in mockery, crying, "Take them, God! I level them at thee!" From that day, the serpents are the narrator's friends, as one twists around the sinner's neck, as if saying, "Be silent, tongue!" Another glides up his arms, tying them.
The narrator exclaims, "Pistoia! Ah Pistoia! why dost doubt to turn thee into ashes?" He did not mark any spirit swelling so proudly against God, not even the one who fell headlong from Thebes. The sinner fled, uttering no more. A centaur, Cacus, full of fury, comes after him, shouting, "Where, where is the caitiff?" Serpents swarm on his haunch up to his human face. Behind his head on his shoulders is a dragon breathing fire. Virgil identifies him as Cacus, who spread a "lake of blood" beneath Aventine rock. He is parted from his brethren here for his "fraudful theft of the great herd," which ended under Hercules' mace.
While Virgil speaks, the centaur speeds away. Three spirits come up from below, unnoticed until they exclaim, "Say who are ye?" They break off discourse. The protagonist doesn't know them, but one names another, "Where doth Cianfa lurk?" The protagonist puts a finger to his lips, signaling Virgil to be attentive. The narrator addresses the reader, saying it's no marvel if they don't believe, for he himself scarcely trusts his eyes.
As he looks, a six-footed serpent springs onto one spirit, fastening itself on him: its middle grasps the belly, a forefoot seizes each arm, fangs flesh deep in cheeks, and hinder feet spread on thighs, tail curled on reins. The monster intertwines with the spirit like ivy on an oak. Both melt into each other like burning wax, mingling hues, so neither is seen anymore. The narrator describes it like browning paper before burning. The other two exclaim, "Ah, how dost thou change, Agnello! See! Thou art nor double now, nor only one." The two heads become one, two figures blend into one form, losing both original shapes. Two arms are made from four lengths, belly, chest, thighs, and legs change into unseen members. All trace of former shape vanishes. The miscreated image passes on with tardy steps.
Like a lizard darting across a road, an adder, all on fire, approaches the entrails of the other two spirits. It transpierces one where life is first nourished, and the spirit falls stretched out. The pierced spirit looks at the serpent, both breathing thick smoke that joins.
The narrator says Lucan and Ovid may now be mute, for they never sang of two natures transmuted face to face. In mutual guise, the serpent splits its tail to a fork, and the pierced spirit draws his legs and thighs together, making no sign of juncture. The disparted tail takes the spirit's lost figure, its skin softening, while the spirit's indurates to a rind. Shoulders join the monster's armpits, its two shorter feet lengthen as the other's shrink. The feet behind twist up to form the part man conceals, which in the wretch (the spirit) was cleft in twain. As the smoke veils both with new color, one body grows an excrescent pile, while the other peels it off. One rises upright, the other falls prone. Their "glaring and malignant lamps" (eyes) are not shifted, though features change. The standing one's face retreats to temples, superfluous matter forms ears, the nose swells, and lips protrude. The one on the earth extends his sharpened visage, drawing ears into his head like a slug its horns. His tongue, continuous and apt for utterance, severs, while the other's fork closes and unites. The smoke then dissipates. The soul transformed into the brute glides off, hissing. The other, now talking, sputters and turns his new-grown shoulders on him, speaking to another, "Along this path crawling, as I have done, speed Buoso now!"
The narrator saw the "unsteady ballast of the seventh hold" fluctuate in change. He attributes any linguistic swerving to the strangeness of events. Confusion and amaze hang over his eyes and thoughts.
Yet they did not escape so covertly that he failed to mark Sciancato, the only one of the three first who did not change. He mentions Gaville still rues the other's fate.

**CANTO XXVI**
The narrator addresses Florence, exulting in its might across land and sea, spreading its name even in hell. He found three of its citizens among the plunderers, bringing shame to him and no honor to the city. He prophesies Florence will soon feel the woes that Prato wishes upon it, saying it would be good if it happened now, for he will grieve more as time passes.
They depart the depth, Virgil scaling the flinty steps they previously descended, pulling the protagonist up. They proceed on their solitary way among crags and splinters, needing hands as well as feet.
Sorrow seizes the narrator as he recalls what he saw, and he curbs his nature's powers to avoid running where virtue guides not, valuing the good his star or something better gave him.
Like a peasant seeing innumerable fire-flies spangling the vale at sunset, the narrator sees the eighth chasm shining with "flames so numberless," when the depth is exposed. Like the one whose wrongs bears avenged, seeing Elijah's chariot rise, his eyes straining until only a misty speck of flame remains, so moves every flame along the gulf, each enclosing a sinner so closely that "none exhibits token of the theft."
The narrator leans forward on the bridge to look, grasping a flinty mass lest he fall. Virgil, noting his gaze, explains that "Within these ardours are the spirits, each swath'd in confining fire." The narrator says he believes this, but wonders who is in the "horned flame" that seems parted at the summit, like the Theban brothers' funeral pile. Virgil replies, "Ulysses there and Diomede endure their penal tortures, thus to vengeance now together hasting, as erewhile to wrath." They deplore the ambush of the horse (Trojan Horse), which opened a portal for the seed that sowed imperial Rome, and the guile that reft Achilles from Deidamia, who still complains in death. They also rue the stratagem that despoiled Troy of her Palladium.
The narrator asks if they can speak from within the sparks, begging Virgil to pause until the horned flame arrives. Virgil praises his prayer and accepts it, but tells him to refrain his tongue, as he will question them, divining the protagonist's wish, and they, being Greeks, might shun discourse with him.
When the flame arrives, Virgil asks, "O ye, who dwell two spirits in one fire! If living I of you did merit aught... move ye not on, till one of you unfold in what clime death o'ertook him self-destroy'd."
The greater horn of the old flame begins to roll, murmuring like fire with wind, then wags its top like a tongue, speaking. It says that after escaping Circe, who held him for a year near Caieta, neither fondness for his son, reverence for his father, nor Penelope's love could overcome his "zeal... t' explore the world, and search the ways of life, man's evil and his virtue." He sailed into the "deep illimitable main" with one bark and a small band. He saw both shores as far as Iberia and Morocco, and Sardinia and other islands. He and his companions were old when they reached the "strait pass, where Hercules ordain'd the bound'ries not to be o'erstepp'd by man." He left Seville's walls to his right, and Ceuta already past.
He addressed his brothers, urging them, having reached "through perils without number" the "short remaining watch" of their senses, not to refuse proof "of the unpeopled world, following the track of Phoebus." He reminded them they were "not form'd to live the life of brutes but virtue to pursue and knowledge high." These words sharpened their minds, making them unstoppable. They turned their poop to the dawn and used their oars as wings, gaining on the left. They saw the stars of the other pole, and theirs so low it rose not from the ocean. Five times the moon's light had re-illumined and vanished since they entered the deep way. Then, from afar, a dim mountain appeared, the loftiest he ever beheld. Joy seized them, but quickly changed to mourning. A whirlwind sprung from the new land, striking the vessel's foremost side. It whirled her thrice, the fourth time lifting the poop and sinking the prow, as fate decreed. "And over us the booming billow clos'd."

**CANTO XXVII**
The flame rises, stilling its light after speaking, then passes on with Virgil's leave. Another flame follows, from whose top a confused sound draws their eyes.
The narrator compares it to the Sicilian bull bellowing from the tormented voice within, seeming pierced with pain. So the dismal words turn into language from the flame, speaking when they find passage. "O thou! to whom I now direct my voice! That lately didst exclaim in Lombard phrase, 'Depart thou, I solicit thee no more,' Though somewhat tardy I perchance arrive, Let it not irk thee here to pause awhile, And with me parley: lo! it irks not me And yet I burn. If but e'en now thou fall into this blind world, from that pleasant land of Latium, whence I draw my sum of guilt, Tell me if those, who in Romagna dwell, Have peace or war. For of the mountains there was I, betwixt Urbino and the height, whence Tyber first unlocks his mighty flood."
The narrator listens. Virgil touches his side, saying, "Speak thou: he is a Latian." The narrator replies that Romagna "never was... without war in her proud tyrants' bosoms, nor is now." He left no open war there; Ravenna's state is steadfast, with Polenta's eagle brooding, overshadowing Cervia. The "green talons" (Malatesta family) grasp the land that stood long against the host of France.
He continues describing other tyrants: the "old mastiff of Verruchio and the young" (Malatesta of Rimini) still make an auger of their fangs, having torn Montagna. Lamone's city and Santerno's range under the "lion of the snowy lair" (Ordelaffi of Forlì), an inconstant partisan. The city by Savio's wave (Cesena) lives "betwixt tyrant power and liberty."
He then asks the spirit who he is, entreating him not to be harder than others, so his name may "rear its forehead high" in the world.
The fire roars awhile, then its sharpened point waves, and it speaks: "If I did think, my answer were to one, who ever could return unto the world, This flame should rest unshaken. But since ne'er, if true be told me, any from this depth has found his upward way, I answer thee, nor fear lest infamy record the words."
He says he was "a man of arms at first," then clothed himself "in good Saint Francis' girdle, hoping so t' have made amends." His hope would not have failed, but "the high priest again seduc'd me into sin." He explains that while alive, his deeds bespoke the nature "of the lion than the fox," knowing "winding subtlety" that reached the world's limit. When he reached the point in life to "lower sails and gather in the lines," he rued his past and turned to repentance and confession.
Meanwhile, the "chief of the new Pharisees" (Pope Boniface VIII), waging war near the Lateran not against Saracens or Jews but Christians, revered neither his charge nor the cord of Francis. Like Constantine seeking Sylvester's aid for leprosy, this man (Boniface) sought him to cure "the fever of his pride," asking for counsel. The spirit was silent, for Boniface's words "seem'd drunken." But Boniface resumed, "From thy heart banish fear: of all offence I hitherto absolve thee. In return, Teach me my purpose so to execute, that Penestrino cumber earth no more. Heav'n, as thou knowest, I have power to shut and open: and the keys are therefore twain."
Yielding to these "forceful arguments," deeming silence more perilous, he answered, "Father! since thou washest me clear of that guilt wherein I now must fall, Large promise with performance scant, be sure, Shall make thee triumph in thy lofty seat." (This refers to giving Boniface counsel on how to take the city of Penestrino by promising mercy then breaking it).
He continues: when he died, Saint Francis came for him, but a "cherub dark" met him, crying, "Wrong me not; he is mine, and must below to join the wretched crew, For the deceitful counsel which he gave." The cherub explains that "No power can the impenitent absolve; Nor to repent and will at once consist, By contradiction absolute forbid." The spirit recounts how the cherub seized him and bore him to Minos, who "Twin'd eight times round his callous back the tail, Which biting with excess of rage, he spake: 'This is a guilty soul, that in the fire must vanish.'" Hence, the spirit now roves "A prey to rankling sorrow in this garb."
The flame then parts in dolour, writhing its sharp horn. The narrator and Virgil go onward, up along the rock, to another arch overhanging the foss where others pay for committed sin.

**CANTO XXVIII**
The narrator despairs of words to fully tell of the wounds and blood he now sees in the ninth chasm, which surpasses in horror any historical massacre. A "rundlet" (cask) does not gape so wide as one spirit he sees, torn from chin to "hinder passage," with entrails dangling, midriff, and ventricle open to view.
The mangled spirit eyes the narrator, bares his breast, and cries, "Now mark how I do rip me! lo! How is Mohammed mangled! before me walks Ali weeping, from the chin his face cleft to the forelock." He explains that all the others here "did sow scandal and schism, and therefore thus are rent." A fiend hacks them cruelly with a sword, slivering them again after their gashes close when they complete their round. He asks the narrator why he stands musing, delaying his sentenced pain.
Virgil replies that death has not yet overtaken the narrator, nor does sin conduct him to torment. Virgil, who is dead, guides him through hell "to make full trial of your state."
More than a hundred spirits stop, amazed, to mark the narrator, forgetting their pains. Mohammed, with foot raised to depart, warns the narrator to "Bear this warning to Dolcino: bid him, if he wish not here soon to follow me, that with good store of food he arm him, lest impris'ning snows yield him a victim to Novara's power."
Another shade, pierced in the throat, mutilated nostrils, and lopt ear, advances, baring his windpipe, smeared with crimson. He asks the narrator, if he returns to the "pleasant land" of Latium, to remember Piero of Medicina and instruct "the twain, whom Fano boasts her worthiest sons, Guido and Angelo," that they will be "cast forth, and whelm'd under the waves near to Cattolica, through perfidy of a fell tyrant." He describes this as a foul injury. The "one-ey'd traitor" (Malatestino, whom another spirit here wished were blind) will bring them to conference and so shape their end that they will not need to pray against Focara's wind.
The narrator asks who the one is whose sight awakens such sad remembrance. The spirit lays his hand on another's cheek-bone, expanding his jaws, crying, "Lo! this is he I wot of; He speaks not for himself: the outcast this who overwhelm'd the doubt in Caesar's mind, Affirming that delay to men prepar'd Was ever harmful." The narrator notes how terrified Curio seemed, whose tongue was cut out. Then one, maimed of each hand, lifts his bleeding stumps, sullied with gory spots, and cries, "Remember thee of Mosca, too, I who, alas! exclaim'd, 'The deed once done there is an end,' that prov'd A seed of sorrow to the Tuscan race." The narrator adds, "Ay, and death to thine own tribe." The spirit then hurries off, grief-stung.
The narrator lingers to behold the troop, seeing things he fears to tell of without more proof, but conscience makes him firm. He sees a headless trunk, pacing onward, bearing its severed head in hand "lantern-wise pendent," which looks at them and says, "Woe's me!" The spirit thus lights himself, being "two... in one, and one in two." How that can be, only God knows. When he stands at the bridge's foot, he raises his arm, thrusting the head into view, so they might hear his words: "Now behold this grievous torment, thou, who breathing go'st to spy the dead; behold if any else be terrible as this." To bear tidings of him on earth, he identifies himself: "I am Bertrand, he of Born, who gave King John the counsel mischievous. Father and son I set at mutual war." He compares his act to Ahitophel spurring Absalom and David. For parting those "so closely knit," he carries his brain "parted, alas! from its source, that in this trunk inhabits." Thus, the law of retribution works in him.

**CANTO XXIX**
The narrator's eyes are so "inebriate with view of the vast multitude, whom various wounds disfigur'd" that he longs to stay and weep. Virgil rouses him, asking why he still gazes "among the maim'd and miserable shades." He states the valley winds "two and twenty miles" and the moon is already beneath their feet, so time is short.
The narrator replies that if Virgil knew the cause of his looking, he would excuse the tarrying. He follows Virgil, adding that he believes "a spirit dwells, one of my blood, wailing the crime that costs him now so dear," in the cave where he fixed his ken.
Virgil tells him not to afflict his soul, but to direct his thought elsewhere. He saw him point menacingly at the narrator at the bridge's foot, and heard him named Geri of Bello. The narrator was so busy with Bertrand de Born that he did not see Geri leave. The narrator explains that Geri's "violent death yet unaveng'd" by his kin made him contemptuous, hence he passed him speechless, making the narrator more compassionate.
They discourse to where the rock first showed the other valley, which would have had more light if it were not for the darkness. They reach the last cloister in Malebolge's dismal rounds, and a "sore lament" assails him, headed with "points of thrilling pity," forcing him to close his ears.
The torment is compared to all the maladies of Valdichiana's lazar-houses, Sardinia, and Maremma's fen heaped in one foss, with a dire stench.
They descend to the utmost shore of the long rock, still to the left. His sight is livelier to explore the depth, where "All-searching Justice" dooms forgers. The narrator thinks it was not more rueful to see Aegina's nation droop from pestilence (restored from ant seeds as bards told) than to see these spirits languishing in the murky vale, piled on stacks. They lie confused, one over another, some crawling sidelong.
They journey step by step, observing and listening to the diseased, who struggle to lift their forms. He sees two sitting propped against each other like brazen pans, barked from head to foot with tetter. They quickly ply their nails through "furiousness of ne'er abated pruriency," drawing off crust in flakes like scales from fish.
Virgil asks one, who rends his "coat of proof" with his fingers, if any Latian-born are among them. The spirit, weeping, replies both are from Latium and asks who Virgil is. Virgil replies he descends with a living man to show him hell's abyss.
They start asunder and turn trembling towards them. Virgil tells the narrator to speak what he wishes. The narrator asks them to tell who they are and their race, so their remembrance may not be lost in the upper world, despite their "unseemly and disgustful" punishment.
One answers he was from Arezzo, brought to die by fire by Albero of Sienna. But what he died for does not bring him here. He admits telling Albero in sport that he could fly, and Albero, admiring and void of wisdom, wished to know his art. Only because he did not make him a Daedalus, Albero prevailed on one "suppos'd his sire to burn me." Minos doomed him to this chasm, last of the ten, for practicing alchemy on earth.
The narrator asks Virgil if any race is as light as Sienna's, suggesting even France cannot show such a frivolous tribe. The other leprous spirit hears and replies, "Be Stricca from this charge exempted, he who knew so temp'rately to lay out fortune's gifts; and Niccolo who first the spice's costly luxury discover'd in that garden, where such seed roots deepest in the soil." He also exempts Caccia of Asciano's troop who lavished vineyards and woods, and Abbagliato who showed "rare wisdom." To know who seconds him against the Siennese, he tells the narrator to look closely, for he is Capocchio's ghost, who "forg'd transmuted metals by the power of alchemy." He knows the narrator must remember how he aped "creative nature by my subtle art."

**CANTO XXX**
The narrator recalls the frenzy of Athamas, driven by Juno's resentment, who dashed his son Learchus on a rock and caused his spouse to plunge. He also recalls Hecuba, distraught after Polyxena's slaughter and finding Polydorus, running barking like a dog. He states that Furies never showed such cruelty as he now sees in two "pale and naked ghosts" scampering wildly like swine. One reaches Capocchio, sticking his fangs deep in his neck-joint, dragging him. The other, from Arezzo, left trembling, says the other is "Schicchi," who still vents his spite in "random mischief."
The narrator asks the trembling spirit to identify the other before it speeds away. He replies that it is "the ancient soul of wretched Myrrha," who burned with unholy flame for her own father, assuming a false shape to commit the sin. The other, who passes onward, "dar'd to counterfeit Donati's features, to feign'd testament the seal affixing, that himself might gain, For his own share, the lady of the herd."
When the two furious shades vanish, the narrator turns to other cursed spirits. He sees one shaped like a lute, if the groin were severed. Swollen by dropsy, his limbs disproportionate, his paunch not suiting his visage, he gasps with wide lips.
He addresses the narrator, "O ye, who in this world of misery, wherefore I know not, are exempt from pain," asking him to regard Adamo's woe. Adamo states he lacked nothing in life, but now craves "one drop of water." The rills of Casentino, flowing to the Arno, are always in his view, drying him up more than his disease. Justice, from the place of his transgression, quickens his sighs. He says he falsified metal with the Baptist's form in Romena, for which his body was burned on earth. He wishes to see Guido, Alessandro, or their brother, and would not exchange that sight for Branda's spring. One, he says, is already within, if the mad spirits tell truly, but his limbs are fettered. If he could move an inch every hundred years, he would seek him. He was brought among this tribe because they induced him to stamp florens with three carats of alloy.
The narrator asks about the "abject pair" smoking closely to his right. Adamo replies he found them there when he dropped into the gulf, and they will not turn until time runs its course. One is "the false accuser of the Hebrew youth" (Potiphar's wife, here Hecuba or Sinon's wife, but actually Potiphar's wife); the other is Sinon, "that false Greek from Troy." Sharp fever drains their moisture, steaming up a cloud.
One of the two, perhaps galled by the name, strikes Adamo on the paunch, which resounds like a drum. Adamo returns the blow. Sinon says Adamo's "o'erweighty limbs" may prevent movement, but he has an arm for such employ. Adamo replies he did not have it so ready when he went to the fire, but readier when he coined "th' impostor gold." Sinon retorts that Adamo speaks true, but he "gav'st not such true testimony" at Troy. Adamo tells the "perjur'd one" to remember the horse that "did teem with death." Sinon returns the accusation, citing Adamo's thirst and "fluid mound" (dropsy). Adamo calls Sinon's mouth wide to "let pass its evil saying." He admits thirst, but is "stuff'd with moisture," while Sinon is parched, his head racked, needing no urging to "lap Narcissus' mirror up."
The narrator is fixed on listening, when Virgil admonishes, "Now beware: a little more, and I do quarrel with thee." The narrator perceives Virgil's anger and turns to him with such shame that it still confounds him. He feels like one who dreams of harm and wishes it were a dream, wanting to excuse himself but unable.
Virgil tells him, "More grievous fault than thine has been, less shame, might expiate." He tells him to cast all sorrow from his soul and, if he encounters such a conference again, to remember Virgil is at his side, as "To hear such wrangling is a joy for vulgar minds."

**CANTO XXXI**
The tongue that wounded him now ministers cure. The narrator recalls Achilles' javelin causing pain and then health.
They turn their back on the "vale of woe" and cross the mound in dim twilight. He hears a loud horn sound, making thunder feeble. His eyes strain to the sound, which Orlando did not blow so terribly when Charlemagne's host was overthrown. He sees "many lofty towers" and asks Virgil what land it is. Virgil replies he has erred in imagining, as his eye had too much "intervening darkness" to traverse. They will see how distance deludes the sense.
Virgil gently takes his hand, saying these are not towers but giants, immersed in the pit from their navel downward around the bank. As fog disperses, revealing objects, so his error flees and fear comes over him as they near the brink. He compares the turreted shore to Montereggion.
He sees the face, shoulders, breast, and part of the huge belly of one giant, with arms along his ribs. He reflects on nature's wisdom in framing these monsters, slaves for war, and how her wisdom is greater in the elephant and whale, for when "brute force and evil will are back'd with subtlety, resistance none avails." The giant's visage is as long and bulky as Saint Peter's pine. Three Friezelanders could not reach his hair. He is exposed thirty ample palms from where a man loops his garments.
The giant shouts, "Raphel bai ameth sabi almi." Virgil addresses him as "O senseless spirit! let thy horn for thee interpret: therewith vent thy rage." He tells him to search his neck for the belt that binds his horn and notes the "baldrick" hanging on his breast. Virgil tells the protagonist, "He doth accuse himself. Nimrod is this, through whose ill counsel in the world no more one tongue prevails. But pass we on, nor waste our words; for so each language is to him, as his to others, understood by none."
Turning leftward, they speed forth and find another "far fiercer and more huge" shade a sling's throw away. The narrator cannot say who had girt him, but his right arm is fettered behind, and the other with a chain from neck down, meeting five times around his form. Virgil says this proud one "would of his strength against almighty Jove make trial," hence his requital. They call him Ephialtes, mighty when giants brought fear on gods, but now his arms move never. The protagonist wishes to see Briareus. Virgil says they will see Antaeus, who speaks and is unfettered, and will place them where "guilt is at its depth." Briareus, whom the protagonist wants to see, stands further on, in chains, "like to this spirit, save that in his looks more fell he seems."
Ephialtes shakes like a tower rocked by an earthquake, increasing the protagonist's dread, but he sees the cords holding him fast. They journey on to Antaeus, who issues from the cave "five ells complete without the head."
Virgil addresses Antaeus, recalling his strength in the valley that made Scipio heir of glory, and how he carried a hundred lions as spoil, and if he had fought with his brethren, men would believe the sons of earth conquered through him. Virgil asks him to place them down beneath where cold "locks up Cocytus," not forcing them to crave Tityus' or Typhon's help. He says there is one (the protagonist) who can bestow renown on Antaeus in the upper world, for he lives and looks for longer life, "if before the time Grace call him not unto herself."
Antaeus swiftly stretches his hands and catches Virgil. Virgil, feeling the grapple, tells the protagonist to clasp him, then catches him up so they are both one burden. Antaeus appears like the leaning Carisenda tower, stooping. The narrator wished for another way, but Antaeus lightly places them in the abyss, "that Lucifer with Judas low ingulfs," then rises like a stately mast.

**CANTO XXXII**
The narrator wishes for rough and hoarse rhymes to suit this "hole of sorrow," for to describe the depth of the universe is not a jest and demands a mature tongue. He invokes the Muses. He calls the inhabitants "ill-starr'd folk, beyond all others wretched."
They stand in the dark pit beneath the giants' feet, but lower. A voice warns the narrator, "Look how thou walkest. Take good heed, thy soles do tread not on the heads of thy poor brethren." He turns and sees a lake whose frozen surface seems more like glass than water, thicker than the Danube or Tanais. If Tabernich or Pietrapana had fallen on it, "not e'en its rim had creak'd." Like frogs croaking above the wave, the spirits stand "Blue pinch'd and shrin'd in ice," moving their teeth like storks, faces downward, expressing dolour with their eyes.
He sees two spirits so strictly joined that their hair is mingled. He asks who they are. They bend their necks, and their eyes, moist within, distill tears onto their lips, frozen between their orbs. They clash together "like two enraged goats."
One, whose ears are reft by the cold, exclaims, "Why on us dost speculate so long?" He identifies them: their father was Alberto, master of the valley where Bisenzio slopes, and they issued from one body. He says Caina holds no shade more worthy of congelation, not Arthur's foe, not Focaccia, nor Mascheroni (whose head obstructs his view). He identifies himself as Camiccione, awaiting his kinsman Carlino, whose "deep guilt shall wash out mine."
He then marks a thousand visages shaped into a "doggish grin" by the cold, causing shivering horror. As they journey toward the middle, the protagonist's foot violently strikes the face of one spirit.
The spirit weeps, "Wherefore dost bruise me? Unless thy errand be some fresh revenge for Montaperto, wherefore troublest me?" The protagonist asks Virgil to wait so he can rid himself of doubt. He then asks the spirit, who still curses him, who he is. The spirit asks who the protagonist is, roaming Antenora and smiting cheeks with such force.
The protagonist replies he is living, "to thy joy perchance," if fame is dear to him, so he may enroll his name. The spirit retorts, "The contrary of what I covet most... hence; nor vex me more. Ill knowest thou to flatter in this vale."
The protagonist seizes his hair, crying, "Name thee, or not a hair shall tarry here." The spirit replies, "Rend all away... yet for that I will not tell nor show thee who I am, Though at my head thou pluck a thousand times." The protagonist pulls more than one tuft, and the spirit barks, eyes drawn in. Another spirit cries, "What ails thee, Bocca? Sound not loud enough thy chatt'ring teeth, but thou must bark outright? What devil wrings thee?" The protagonist tells Bocca he will bear "true tidings" of his shame. Bocca replies to tell what he lists, but to also speak of "him whose tongue hath been so glib" (Buera), who wails for French gold. He names Beccaria, Soldanieri, Ganellon, and Tribaldello (who opened Faenza).
They leave him. The narrator sees two spirits pent in one hollow, one's head a cowl to the other. The uppermost gnaws the other's brain where the spine joins, more furiously than Tydeus gnawed Menalippus. He asks the cause of such hate, on condition that if his grievance is warranted, he will repay him in the world above.

**CANTO XXXIII**
The sinner lifts his jaws from his repast, wipes them on the mangled hair of the head he was gnawing, then begins. He says obeying the protagonist's will calls up fresh sorrow. If his words can bear "fruit of eternal infamy" to the traitor he gnaws, the protagonist will see him speak and weep. He doesn't know who the protagonist is but recognizes him as Florentine. He identifies himself as Count Ugolino and the other as Archbishop Ruggieri. He explains that Ruggieri's "ill thoughts" led to his capture and murder. He will tell what the protagonist has not heard: "How cruel was the murder."
He describes a "small grate" in the mew (tower) named Famine, where others must still pine. Several moons had passed since he slept an "evil sleep" that tore the curtain off the future. He dreamed Ruggieri, as master of the sport, chased a gaunt wolf and its whelps (Ugolino and his sons) to the mountain that hides Lucca from Pisa. Lanfranchi, Sismondi, and Gualandi ranged before him with lean dogs. After a short course, the father and sons seemed tired, and he dreamed he saw sharp tusks gore their sides.
He awoke before dawn, hearing his sons (who were with him) weep and ask for bread. He addresses the reader, saying they are cruel if they feel no pang. The hour when food was brought drew near. The dream made them all misgive, and he heard the "horrible tower" locked beneath its outlet. He looked at his sons' visages, weeping not, feeling "all stone within." His sons wept, and little Anselm cried, "Thou lookest so! Father what ails thee?" He shed no tear nor answered that day or the next night. When a faint beam entered their "doleful prison," and he saw his own image in four countenances, he bit his hands through agony. His sons, thinking he bit from hunger, rose and cried, "Father, we should grieve far less, if thou wouldst eat of us: thou gav'st these weeds of miserable flesh we wear, And do thou strip them off from us again."
To avoid making them sadder, he kept still. That day and the next, they were silent. He exclaims, "Ah, obdurate earth! Why open'dst not upon us?" On the fourth day, Geddo flung himself at his feet, crying, "Hast no help for me, my father!" He died. The narrator states he saw the three (other sons) fall one by one between the fifth and sixth days. Then, grown blind, he groped over them for three days, calling on them, until "fasting got the mastery of grief."
Having spoken, he fastens his teeth on the wretched skull again. The narrator exclaims against Pisa, shaming it, wishing Capraia and Gorgona would rise and dam the Arno's mouth so every soul in Pisa would perish. He argues that even if Ugolino betrayed castles, Pisa had no right to rack his children, Brigata, Ugaccione, and the two gentle ones, whose "tender years" made them "Uncapable of guilt."
They pass onward, where other spirits are "skarf'd in rugged folds of ice," not on their feet, but reversed. Here, "weeping suffers not to weep," for grief finds impediment at their eyes, turning inward for sharp anguish, tears hanging "like crystal vizors."
The narrator feels a breath of wind despite the cold. He asks Virgil the source, thinking all vapor is quenched. Virgil replies they will soon be where his eye will tell him the cause of this "airy shower."
One spirit in the cold crust cries out, "O souls so cruel! that the farthest post hath been assign'd you, from this face remove the harden'd veil, that I may vent the grief impregnate at my heart, some little space ere it congeal again!" The narrator replies he will help if the spirit tells who he was, promising to descend to the lowest ice if he fails.
The spirit answers, "The friar Alberigo am I, who from the evil garden pluck'd its fruitage, and am here repaid, the date more luscious for my fig." The narrator exclaims, "Hah! Art thou too dead!" Alberigo replies he is ignorant of his body's fate in the upper world. He explains that Ptolomea (this region) has the privilege that the soul often drops here before Atropos severs it. He says that the moment a soul betrays, its body is yielded to a fiend who moves and governs it until its time is rounded, while the soul falls headlong to this cistern. He adds that "perchance above doth yet appear the body of a ghost, who here behind me winters," referring to Branca Doria, who came to this fastness many years ago.
The narrator expresses disbelief, saying Branca Doria is not dead but performs all natural functions. Alberigo replies that Michael Zanche had not yet reached the "upper foss" (of pitch) when Branca Doria left a demon in his stead in his own body, and one of his kin (who wrought treachery with him) also did so. Alberigo asks him to open his eyes. The narrator refuses, deeming "Ill manners were best courtesy to him."
The narrator then exclaims against the Genoese as perverse and foul, wondering why they are not canceled from earth, as he found one of them (Branca Doria) with Romagna's darkest spirit (Alberigo), already plunged in Cocytus in soul while seeming alive in body on earth.

**CANTO XXXIV**
Virgil points out, "The banners of Hell's Monarch do come forth towards us; therefore look... if thou discern him." The narrator sees what he thinks is a windmill in the distance, stirred briskly by the blast. He draws behind Virgil to shield himself from the wind.
He arrives where souls are whelmed underneath, transparent like glass, some prone, others upright, some arched face to feet. They reach the point where Virgil wishes him to see "The creature eminent in beauty once." Virgil steps aside and pauses, exclaiming, "Lo! lo! behold Dis! and lo the place, where thou hast need to arm thy heart with strength."
The narrator describes himself as frozen and faint, unable to express his state with words, "not dead nor living." He describes Lucifer, the emperor of sorrow, standing mid-breast from the ice, his stature so great that the narrator is more like a giant than the giants are in Lucifer's arms. He notes Lucifer's former beauty and his hideous present state, from which all misery flows.
Lucifer has "three faces: one in front of hue vermilion, th' other two with this midway each shoulder join'd and at the crest; The right 'twixt wan and yellow seem'd: the left To look on, such as come from whence old Nile Stoops to the lowlands." Under each face shoot two mighty wings, enormous like a bat's, without plumes. He flaps them, creating three winds that freeze Cocytus. He weeps from six eyes, tears distilling down three chins with bloody foam. At every mouth, his teeth champ a sinner, bruised as with a ponderous engine. The foremost sinner is tormented more by "fierce rending," his back often stripped of skin. Virgil identifies the uppermost spirit, suffering worse punishment, as Judas, "he that hath his head within and plies the feet without." Of the other two, with heads under, the one hanging from the murky jaw is Brutus (who writhes and speaks not), and the other, "large of limb," is Cassius. Virgil then says night re-ascends, and it is time for parting, as "All is seen."
The narrator clips Virgil around the neck as bade. Virgil, seeing the wings open enough, catches the "shaggy sides," descending "from pile to pile... between the thick fell and the jagged ice." When they reach the point where the thigh turns on the haunches' swelling, Virgil, with pain and struggle, turns his head where his feet stood before, grappling at the fell, "as one who mounts," making the narrator think they were turning back into hell.
Virgil, panting, says, "Expect that by such stairs as these... We must depart from evil so extreme." He issues forth at a "rocky opening," places the narrator on a brink to sit, then joins him. The narrator raises his eyes, expecting to see Lucifer above, but sees him now "With legs held upward." The narrator reflects on the toil he felt at this point.
Virgil cries, "Arise... The way is long, and much uncouth the road; And now within one hour and half of noon The sun returns." They are not in a lofty palace but a natural dungeon with ill footing and scant light. The narrator, rising, asks Virgil, "Where is now the ice? How standeth he in posture thus revers'd? And how from eve to morn in space so brief Hath the sun made his transit?"
Virgil explains: "Thou deemest thou art still on th' other side the centre, where I grasp'd th' abhorred worm, that boreth through the world." He clarifies that the narrator was on the other side as long as Virgil descended; when Virgil turned, the narrator "didst o'erpass that point, to which from ev'ry part is dragg'd All heavy substance." He is now "under the hemisphere opposed to that, which the great continent doth overspread," where the sinless Man expired. His feet are planted on the "smallest sphere," whose other aspect is Judecca. Morning rises here when evening sets there. Lucifer stands fixed as at first. He fell from heaven on this part, and the earth, prominent before, veiled herself with the sea through fear of him and retired to their hemisphere. Perhaps to shun him, the vacant space was left here by what firm land appears on this side, which sprang aloof.
There is a place beneath, as distant from Beelzebub as the vaulted tomb extends, discovered not by sight but by the sound of a brooklet descending a hollow rock. By that "hidden way," Virgil and the narrator enter, to return to the "fair world." Heedless of repose, they climb, Virgil first, the narrator following, until "the beautiful lights of heav'n dawn'd through a circular opening in the cave." Thus, issuing, they "again beheld the stars."

**PURGATORY**

**CANTO I**
The narrator's "light bark of my genius" lifts sail, speeding over "better waves," pleased to leave the "cruel sea" of Hell behind. He will now sing of the "second region," where the human spirit is purged from sin and prepared for Heaven. He invokes the Muses and Calliope for aid.
A "sweet hue of eastern sapphire" spreads over the serene air, bringing him unwonted joy after escaping the "deadly gloom" of Hell. The radiant planet (Venus) makes the orient laugh, veiled beneath the Pisces' light.
He turns to the right and fixes his mind on the other pole, seeing "Four stars ne'er seen before save by the ken of our first parents." Heaven seems joyous from their rays. He laments the northern site, bereft of these.
As he ceases gazing, an old man stands alone by his side, worthy of reverence, with a long, hoary beard. The light of the four stars shines on his face, making him appear like the sun.
The old man asks, "Say who are ye, that stemming the blind stream, Forth from th' eternal prison-house have fled?" He asks who conducted them or lit their way from the darkness of Hell. He questions if the statutes of the abyss are broken or if new laws are ordained in heaven.
Virgil, taking hold of the narrator, makes him kneel in reverence. Virgil replies he comes not of himself but was besought by a "Dame from heaven" (Beatrice). He explains that the narrator, a mortal, never saw the farthest gloom but erred through folly, approaching so near that little space was left to turn. Virgil was dispatched to rescue him, and this (Purgatory) was the only way. He has shown the narrator all regions of the bad and now purposes to show spirits purged of sin under the old man's command. He explains that "From high descends the virtue" aiding their journey. He asks for acceptance, stating the narrator journeys in search of "liberty," dear to those who refused life for it, like the old man himself, who found death sweet in Utica.
Virgil adds that "the' eternal edicts are unmov'd: He breathes, and I am free of Minos' power," abiding in the circle where the eyes of "thy chaste Marcia beam." He implores the old man by Marcia's love to let them pass through his "sev'n regions," promising thanks from Marcia if he does not disdain mention below.
The old man (Cato) replies that Marcia was pleasing in his sight while he was there, and he granted all her requests. But now that she dwells beyond the "accursed stream," she cannot move him due to the law ordained when he issued thence. However, if a "Dame from heaven" directs Virgil, no flattery is needed; her name is enough. He instructs them, "Go therefore now: and with a slender reed See that thou duly gird him, and his face Lave, till all sordid stain thou wipe from thence." He explains that it would not be seemly for the protagonist to come before "the foremost minister in heaven" with eyes obscured. He states that this islet, where the wave beats, produces many reeds on its oozy bed, but no other plant that doesn't bend to the water's sway. He tells them not to return this way but that the rising sun will show them the easiest ascent of the mountain.
Cato disappears. The narrator rises, speechless, and turns to Virgil, who tells him to follow, as they must retreat to where the plain declines.
Dawn has chased the morning prime. The narrator sees the trembling of the ocean stream. They traverse the deserted plain like lost travelers. Where the dew still strives with the sun and a fresh wind breathes, Virgil places both hands on the watery grass. The narrator, understanding his intent, stretches his tear-suffused cheeks to him. Virgil restores his hue concealed by the shades of hell.
On the solitary shore, Virgil girds the narrator with a reed as instructed. The narrator marvels that wherever one reed is plucked, another immediately arises.

**CANTO II**
The sun has reached the horizon that covers Salem's walls, and night, opposite to the sun, has issued from the Ganges, holding the scales dropped when she reigns highest. Aurora's cheek has turned to orange where the narrator is.
They linger by the water's brink. A light appears swiftly coming through the sea, no winged course equaling its career. The narrator asks Virgil about it, then sees it grow in size and brightness. Something of bright hue appears on either side, then another from underneath. Virgil remains silent until he recognizes the pilot, then cries, "Down, down; bend low Thy knees; behold God's angel: fold thy hands: Now shalt thou see true Ministers indeed."
Virgil notes how the angel needs no oar or other sail but his wings. The "bird of God" appears brighter as it approaches, so bright the narrator must bend down his eyes. It drives ashore a small, swift, light bark that drinks no wave. The heavenly steersman is seen at the prow, "visibly written blessed in his looks."
Within are a hundred spirits or more, singing "In Exitu Israel de Aegypto" together. The angel blesses them with the sign of the holy cross, and they leap out on land. The angel returns swiftly. The crew is astounded, gazing around.
The sun darts its beams, having chased Capricorn. The strange tribe, lifting their eyes to them, asks, "If ye know, Declare what path will Lead us to the mount."
Virgil replies they are strangers here, having come by a "rough and hard" road, so the ascent will seem like play. The spirits, perceiving the narrator lives from his breathing, grow pale with wonder. Like a crowd flocking a herald, they fix on him, forgetting their errand.
One spirit darts forward with fond ardor to embrace the narrator. The narrator tries to clasp him, but his hands pass through empty. The shadow smiles and draws back. The narrator hastens to follow, but it bids him desist. He recognizes it as Casella and asks him to pause and talk. Casella replies he loves him still as in his mortal frame and pauses, asking why the narrator walks there.
The narrator replies he journeys to return to the world. He asks why Casella lost so much time. Casella explains that the angel, who "takes when and whom he chooses," often denied him passage. But for the past three months, he has taken whoever wished to enter with free leave. Casella gained kind admittance at the Tiber's mouth, where his wings are pointed, for all who do not descend to Acheron throng there.
The narrator asks Casella, if new laws have not destroyed memory of his "sweet song of love," to console his spirit, overcome by pain from traveling far with its frame. Casella sings "Love that discourses in my thoughts" with such soft accents that the sweetness still thrills the narrator. Virgil and all the other spirits are so pleased that nothing else seems to occupy their thoughts.
They stand in mute attention. The venerable old man (Cato) exclaims, "How is this, ye tardy spirits? What negligence detains you loit'ring here? Run to the mountain to cast off those scales, that from your eyes the sight of God conceal." Like a flock of pigeons abandoning their meal when alarmed, the new-come troop deserts the song and hastens to the mountain's side, as one who goes yet knows not where he tends. The narrator and Virgil also depart with hurried steps.

**CANTO III**
The sudden flight scatters the spirits toward the mountain. The narrator adheres to Virgil, wondering how he could have sped without him. Virgil seems smitten with the "bitter pang of self-remorse."
As Virgil slows his pace, the narrator's mind expands with joy. He sets his face against the steep ascent. The sun, flaring behind, is broken by his form, as his rays meet resistance in him. He turns aside, fearing he's been left, seeing only the ground obscured before him. Virgil kindly asks, "Why distrustest thou? Believ'st not I am with thee, thy sure guide?" He explains it is evening where his body lies, removed to Naples. He tells the narrator not to marvel if no shadow falls before him, no more than one ray obstructs another in the sky. He states that bodies endure torments of heat and cold by a virtue whose working God wills not to be revealed. He calls insane anyone who hopes reason can explore the space holding "three persons in one substance." He advises against seeking the "wherefore," reminding them that many desired fruitlessly, like Plato and the Stagyrite. Virgil then bows his forehead and breaks off speech in troubled mood.
They reach the mountain's foot, finding the rock so steep that climbing it would be vain. Even the wildest, most untrodden path elsewhere would be an easy ladder compared to this.
Virgil asks, "Who knows on which hand now the steep declines?... so that he may ascend, who journeys without aid of wine?" As he explores the pathway, the narrator gazes upward and sees spirits approaching so slowly they seem not to move.
The narrator points them out to Virgil, who replies, "Let us tend thither: they but softly come. And thou be firm in hope, my son belov'd."
The spirits are a thousand paces behind them when they draw back on the crags and stand unmoved, like one walking in doubt. Virgil addresses them as "O spirits perfect! O already chosen!" asking them by "blest peace" to instruct them where the mountain declines, so their attempt to mount is not vain. He notes that loss of time grieves most him who knows most.
Like sheep stepping from their fold, first one, then pairs or threes, while the rest stand fearfully, bending eye and nose to ground, following the foremost, so the first of the fortunate crew move forward, modest and graceful. When they see the light from the narrator's right side fall broken on the ground, casting a shadow, they stop and retreat.
Virgil confesses it is a human body they see and asks them not to marvel at the broken light, but to believe they aspire to climb "not without virtue deriv'd from Heaven." The virtuous tribe replies, "Turn, and before you there the entrance lies," signaling with bent hands.
One spirit asks the narrator to turn his visage and see if he has ever seen him. The narrator turns and beholds a comely, fair, and gentle spirit with a gash on one brow. The narrator humbly disclaims ever having seen him. The spirit then shows a wound high on his breast and smilingly says, "I am Manfredi, grandson to the Queen Costanza." He asks the narrator, when returned to his fair daughter (parent of Aragon and Sicily's pride), to inform her of the truth if anything else is told of him. He explains that after two mortal blows shattered his frame, he turned weeping to God, who forgives. His sins were horrible, but infinite goodness receives all who turn to it. Had Cosenza's shepherd (who Clement sent to hunt him) better scanned this divine text, his bones would have lain near Benevento, protected by a mole. But now rain drenches them and wind drives them to the Verde stream, where, with lights extinguished, they were removed from their bed.
Manfredi states that "by their curse we are not so destroy'd, but that the eternal love may turn, while hope retains her verdant blossoms." He explains that one who dies in contumacy against the holy church, though repentant, must wander "thirty-fold for all the time in his presumption past," if not shortened by "prayers of good men." He asks the narrator to advance his bliss by revealing to Costanza how he beheld him and the terms of his interdict, for "much profit comes by means of those below."

**CANTO IV**
The narrator reflects that when a sensation seizes a faculty, the soul collects itself on that power alone, disproving the error that the soul is not singly lighted in the breast. So when something heard or seen keeps the soul turned, time passes unnoticed. This truth he finds by proof, hearing the spirit and wondering, for the sun had measured fifty steps unobserved. Then, all the spirits shout, "Here is what ye ask."
The path they ascend is a narrow "aperture," like a forked thorn stake stopping a larger opening to a vineyard. The narrator and Virgil ascend solitary. He notes that one needs to fly "with the swift wing and plumes of high desire" here.
They ascend through broken rock, close-pent on each side, needing hands and feet. Reaching near the highest ridge, where the plain opens, the narrator exclaims, "O master! say which way can we proceed?" Virgil replies, "Let no step of thine recede. Behind me gain the mountain, till to us some practis'd guide appear." The eminence is so lofty no eye can reach its point, and the side rises more steeply than a line from the mid-quadrant to the center.
Wearied, the narrator asks Virgil to turn and behold him. Virgil replies, "My son! Thus far put forth thy strength;" and points to a track projecting around the hill. Spurred by his words, the narrator clambers behind him until his feet press the plain circuit beneath.
Seated there together, they turn eastward, whence their ascent began. The narrator looks at the nether shores, then to the sun, wondering that it smote them from the left. Virgil perceives his amazement and explains that if Leda's offspring (Castor and Pollux, associated with Gemini) were with the sun, the ruddy zodiac would wheel nearer the bears, if it hadn't forsaken its ancient course. He explains that if Sion and this mountain were placed on earth with one horizon, the path of the sun, which Phaeton misguided, would pass by one on one side and by the other on the other side.
The narrator exclaims that he never saw anything so clear, discerning where his ken seemed to fail. He understands that the "mid orb of the supernal motion" (the Equator) departs toward the north from here, while those in Judea see it toward the warmer part. He then asks how far they have to journey, as the hill mounts higher than his sight.
Virgil replies that the ascent is difficult at first but grows easier the more one proceeds. When it seems pleasant, then it will be easy, like going down the tide in a vessel. Then he will reach the end of this path and can hope to rest. "No more I answer, and thus far for certain know."
As Virgil finishes, a voice sounds nearby, "Yet ye first perchance may to repose you by constraint be led." They turn and see a huge stone, of which neither was aware. They draw to it and find some spirits standing behind the rock, "as a man thru' idleness might stand." One, seeming very weary, sits down, folding his knees about with his face bent down between them.
The narrator points him out to Virgil as more idle than if laziness were his sister. The spirit turns to them, lifts his face over his thigh, and says, "Up then, proceed Thou valiant one." The narrator recognizes him. Despite his breathlessness, he approaches. The spirit, Belacqua, barely lifts his head, saying, "Well hast thou discern'd, How from the left the sun his chariot leads."
The narrator laughs at Belacqua's lazy acts and broken words, saying he grieves for him no more. He asks why Belacqua sits upright, waiting for an escort, or if it is just his accustomed ways. Belacqua replies, "My brother, of what use to mount, when to my suffering would not let me pass the bird of God, who at the portal sits?" He says he must be borne around outside Heaven's limits for as long as he delayed repentant sighs in life, "if prayer do not aid me first, that riseth up from heart which lives in grace."
Virgil, ascending, cries, "Haste thee, for see the sun has touch'd the point meridian, and the night now covers with her foot Marocco's shore."

**CANTO V**
The narrator leaves those spirits and follows Virgil. One spirit points at him, exclaiming, "See how it seems as if the light not shone from the left hand of him beneath, and he, as living, seems to be led on." The narrator turns and sees them gazing at him, then at the broken light beneath.
Virgil exclaims, "Why are thy thoughts thus riveted... that thou hast slack'd thy pace? or how imports it thee, what thing is whisper'd here? Come after me, and to their babblings leave the crowd. Be as a tower, that, firmly set, shakes not its top for any blast that blows! He, in whose bosom thought on thought shoots out, still of his aim is wide." The narrator replies, "I come," with a tinge of color that merits pardon.
A little way before them, some come along the hill, singing "Miserere." Perceiving the narrator's body gives way for rays to pass, they change their song to a "long and hoarse exclaim." Two run as messengers to meet them, asking to learn of their condition. Virgil tells them to return and bear tidings that his frame "is real flesh." If they paused to view his shade, "enough is answer'd them." He tells them to honor and prize the narrator.
The spirits return swiftly, like fiery vapors or August clouds. Arriving, they wheel back on them like a troop with loose rein. Virgil exclaims that many throng to petition the narrator, telling him to go on and listen.
The spirits shout, "O spirit! who go'st on to blessedness with the same limbs, that clad thee at thy birth, a little rest thy step. Look if any one amongst our tribe thou hast e'er beheld, that tidings of him there thou mayst report. Ah, wherefore go'st thou on? Ah wherefore tarriest thou not? We all by violence died, and to our latest hour were sinners, but then warn'd by light from heav'n, so that, repenting and forgiving, we did issue out of life at peace with God, who with desire to see him fills our heart."
The narrator replies he sees their visages but remembers none. He offers to perform any service they wish, by the peace he seeks.
One spirit replies that none distrust his kindness, even without an oath, so long as his will doesn't fail for want of power. He, speaking first, entreats the narrator, if he ever sees the land between Romagna and Charles' realm, to courteously ask those in Fano to pray for him to purge his grievous sins. He came from there. He explains that the deep passages where his blood issued were made on his bosom in Antenor's land, where he thought to be secure. The author of the deed was Este's prince, who pursued him with excessive wrath. He states he might have breathed had he fled toward Mira when overtaken at Oriaco, but he sped to the marsh, fell tangled, and saw his life-blood float the plain.
Another spirit says, "Ah! so may the wish, that takes thee o'er the mountain, be fulfill'd, As thou shalt graciously give aid to mine. Of Montefeltro I; Buonconte I: Giovanna nor none else have care for me, Sorrowing with these I therefore go." The narrator asks what force or chance drew him from Campaldino's field that his sepulture was never known.
Buonconte replies that a stream named Archiano runs at Casentino's foot, sprung in Apennine. Where its name is canceled, he came, pierced in the heart, fleeing on foot, bloodying the plain. Sight and speech failed him, and he fell, finishing with Mary's name, his flesh tenantless. He tells the narrator to report the truth to the living. God's angel took him, while the devil of hell exclaimed, "O thou from heav'n! Say wherefore hast thou robb'd me? Thou of him Th' eternal portion bear'st with thee away For one poor tear that he deprives me of. But of the other, other rule I make."
Buonconte explains how the devil then came, using his power to raise wind and smoky mist from collected vapor, covering the valley from Pratomagno to the mountain range with clouds as day spent. The impregnated air changed to water, and rain fell, rushing into the fosses and then to the great river with headlong sweep. The stiffened frame of Buonconte was found at the Archiano's mouth and dashed into the Arno, loosening the cross he made on himself. The river hurled him on, wrapping him in muddy spoils.
The third spirit, Pia, asks the narrator to remember her when he returns to the world. She says, "I once was Pia. Sienna gave me life, Maremma took it from me. That he knows, Who me with jewell'd ring had first espous'd."

**CANTO VI**
Men separating from a game of dice, the loser remains sad, while others go with the winner. One runs ahead, one twitches his mantle, one bids him remember him. The winner stops not, but motions them aside. The narrator was like this, escaping the throng by promising.
He saw him from Arezzo who fell by Ghino's arm, and him swallowed by the stream in his chase. Frederic Novello entreated with outstretched hand, and the one from Pisa who tested Marzuco's constancy. He beheld Count Orso and the soul of Peter de la Brosse, dismissed from life for spite and envy, not crime. He warns the Lady of Brabant to beware lest she herd with worse for her false deed.
Freed from spirits praying for others' prayers, the narrator asks Virgil why his text states heaven's supreme decree cannot bend to supplication, yet these entreat with this design. Virgil replies that both his writing and their hope are valid, if the narrator considers that "the sacred height of judgment doth not stoop, because love's flame in a short moment all fulfils, which he who sojourns here, in right should satisfy." He adds that when he wrote, prayers had no access to God (for those in Limbo). He advises the narrator not to rest content unless Beatrice, who infuses light between truth and mind, assures him. He states Beatrice is above, on the mountain's crown.
The narrator asks Virgil to mend their speed, as he is not tired and the hill stretches its shadow far. Virgil replies their progress will be as much as they can dispatch for the day. He explains that the narrator cannot be there until he once more beholds the sun returning, which is now hidden behind the steep. He then points out a solitary spirit looking at them, saying it will instruct them.
They approach the spirit, who stands in "high abstracted mood," scarce moving his eyes. It speaks nothing, but lets them pass, eyeing them like a lion. Virgil politely asks for the best ascent. The spirit returns no answer but asks of their country and life. When Virgil says "Mantua," the solitary shadow rises and cries, "Mantuan! I am thy countryman Sordello." They embrace.
The narrator laments "slavish Italy! thou inn of grief," a vessel without a pilot, no longer lady of provinces but a "brothel-house." This gentle spirit from the sound of his land greeted a fellow citizen with glad cheer, while Italy's living ones war among themselves, even within the same walls. He urges Italy to look around her coasts and see if any part enjoys peace. He questions the use of Justinian's reins if the saddle is unpressed, saying it aggravates her shame. He calls for the people to obey and let Caesar sit in the saddle, if they marked God's commands. He blames "German Albert" for abandoning Italy, who has grown savage for lack of spur. He calls for "Just judgment from the stars" to fall on Albert's blood, striking his successor with dread, for he and his father have allowed the "garden of the empire to run waste" through greed.
He bids them come see the Capulets and Montagues, Philippeschi and Monaldi, sunk in grief and racked by suspicion. He urges a cruel one (Albert) to come and behold the oppression of nobles and their injuries, and what safety Santafiore can supply. He calls on Albert to see Rome, a desolate widow, crying for her Caesar. He asks if God's eyes are turned elsewhere, or if this is part of His counsel.
He notes that Italian cities are "o'erthrong'd with tyrants," with every villager a "great Marcellus." He then addresses Florence, saying she may remain unmoved by this digression, thanks to her wise people. Many have justice in their heart, long waiting for counsel, but Florence has it "on their lip's edge." Many refuse to bear common burdens, but Florence answers uncalled, crying, "Behold I stoop!" He bids Florence be glad for her wealth, peace, and wisdom, but states facts will witness his truth. Athens and Sparta made little progress compared to Florence, who uses such subtlety that she weaves a thread in October that scarce reaches mid-November. How many times have customs, laws, coins, and offices been renewed, and people changed? He says Florence is like a sick wretch who finds no rest, shifting sides for respite.

**CANTO VII**
After seven joyful greetings, Sordello asks, "Who are ye?" Virgil replies that his bones were buried by Octavius before this mount was sought by spirits. He is Virgil, deprived of heaven only for "lack of faith." Sordello appears to waver, then bows and embraces Virgil, calling him "Glory of Latium!" He asks what desert or undeserved favor shows Virgil to him, and if he comes from below and what cloister.
Virgil replies he has arrived through every orb of that sad region, led by heavenly influence. He states there is a place below, not of torments but dun shades, where mourning breathes in sighs. He abides there with "little innocents" (unbaptized infants) and those who did not put on the three holy virtues but understood and followed the rest.
He asks Sordello to direct them to where Purgatory truly begins. Sordello replies they have no certain place; he can go up or around. He will guide them as far as he can. But as day declines, they cannot proceed upwards by night. Therefore, they should choose a "place of pleasant sojourn." Some spirits sit apart to the right. He will lead them there.
Virgil asks why ascending by night is impossible, if by another or through weakness. Sordello, trailing his finger on the ground, replies, "Only this line thou shalt not overpass, soon as the sun hath disappear'd; not that aught else impedes thy going upwards, save the shades of night." These perplex the will. They might return below or wander around the mountain.
Virgil, marveling, exclaims, "Then lead us quickly, where thou sayst, that, while we stay, we may enjoy delight." They move a little space, and the narrator perceives the mountain hollowed out like large valleys. Sordello points to where "the high bank recedes" in a bosom, telling them to await the renewal of day.
A crooked path leads them traverse into the ridge's side. Refulgent gold, silver, scarlet grain, ceruse, Indian wood, and fresh emeralds are surpassed by the colors of the herbs and flowers in that recess. Nature not only lavishes colors but also creates a "rare and undistinguish'd fragrance."
The narrator sees spirits sitting on the grass and flowers, chanting "Salve Regina." Virgil, who turned their steps, says before the sun sets, they should not proceed. From this eminence, they will better discern the acts and visages of all.
He points to Rodolph, sitting high above the rest, appearing to have neglected his duty, not moving his lip to the others' song. Rodolph, the Emperor, "might have heal'd the wounds whereof fair Italy hath died." Next, Ottocar, who comforted Rodolph, swayed the country where the Moldaw springs. He was worth more in swaddling clothes than his son Winceslaus, "a bearded man, pamper'd with rank luxuriousness and ease." The next, with a depressed nose, in counsel with the gentle-looking one, "flying expir'd, with'ring the lily's flower" (Philip III of France). He knocks his breast. The other, making a couch for his cheek with his hand, sighs frequently. They are the father (Philip III) and father-in-law (Charles I of Anjou) of "Gallia's bane" (Philip IV). They know his vicious life, hence their grief.
He points to one "so robust of limb," keeping measure in song, who "with ev'ry virtue bore his girdle brac'd" (Peter III of Aragon). If his son (Alfonso III) had lived, his virtue would have been poured from vessel to like vessel, which cannot be said of his other heirs, James and Frederick. Human worth rarely mounts to the branches of the tree, ordained by God as a free gift. Virgil applies these words to Charles (Charles II of Anjou) no less than his brother, which Pouille and Provence now grieve, as the plant degenerates from its seed. Costanza still boasts of her valorous spouse more than Beatrice and Margaret.
He then points to "the king of simple life and plain, Harry of England, sitting there alone," who spreads better issue through his branches. Lastly, he points to "That one, who on the ground beneath the rest sits lowest, yet his gaze directs aloft," who is William, the brave Marquis, whose actions at Alexandria and his war make Confrat and Canavese weep.

**CANTO VIII**
It is the hour that awakens fond desire in men at sea and melts pilgrims' hearts. The narrator, no longer heeding to hear, begins to mark one spirit risen from its seat, imploring audience with its hand. It joins its palms and raises them, gazing steadfastly toward the east, as if telling God, "I care for naught beside." It sings "Te Lucis Ante" so devoutly and softly that the narrator's senses are lost. The rest follow with the hymn, gazing upward.
The narrator tells the reader to make their eyes keen for the truth. He sees the gentle band look up silently, pale and lowly. He sees two angels descend from on high, with flame-illuminated swords, broken at their points. Their vesture and wings are green. One stands over them, the other on the opposing hill, containing the troop in the middle. The narrator sees the whiteness on their heads but cannot discern their visages, overpowered by too much brightness. Sordello exclaims, "From Mary's bosom both are come... as a guard over the vale, ganst him, who hither tends, The serpent." The narrator turns around, frozen with fear, clinging to Virgil.
Sordello says, "To the valley now (For it is time) let us descend; and hold converse with those great shadows: haply much Their sight may please ye." The narrator measures three steps and is beneath, noting one spirit who looks desirous to know him. The air is dim but clears enough to reveal what was concealed.
They advance toward each other. The narrator feels joy recognizing Nino, a "courteous judge." They exchange kind salutations. Nino asks how long since the narrator arrived at the mountain's foot. The narrator replies he came through the sad seats of woe this morning, still in his first life, journeying to gain the other. Nino and Sordello draw back, amazed. One turns to Virgil, the other to a seated spirit, crying, "Conrad! up with speed: Come, see what of his grace high God hath will'd."
Nino then turns to the narrator, saying, "By that rare mark of honour which thou ow'st to him, who hides so deeply his first cause... when thou shalt be beyond the vast of waves. Tell my Giovanna, that for me she call there, where reply to innocence is made." He believes his mother no longer loves him, having changed her white and wimpled folds, which she will wish for again with grief. He says her actions easily show "how long in women lasts the flame of love, if sight and touch do not relume it oft." He adds that the viper (Visconti) calling Milan to the field will not make her a burial as fair as "shrill Gallura's bird" (Nino's own coat of arms, the cock).
Nino speaks with the stamp of "right seal" glowing in his bosom. Meanwhile, the narrator's eyes travel to heaven, where the bright stars are slowest. Virgil asks what has caught his gaze. The narrator replies, "The three torches, with which here the pole is all on fire." Virgil explains that the four stars seen this morning are beneath, and these have risen in their stead.
While Virgil speaks, Sordello draws him and cries, "Lo there our enemy!" pointing to a serpent along the side where no barrier rises around the little vale, "such haply as gave Eve the bitter food." The evil snake comes on between the grass and flowers, reverting its head, licking its back. The narrator cannot tell how the celestial falcons moved from their seat, but he sees them in motion, hearing the air cut by their green plumes. The serpent flees, and the angels return to their stations.
The spirit (who had come to Nino) has not loosened his sight from the narrator through all the conflict. He begins, "So may the lamp, which leads thee up on high, find, in thy destin'd lot, of wax so much, As may suffice thee to the enamel's height." He then says, "If any certain news of Valdimagra and the neighbour part Thou know'st, tell me, who once was mighty there They call'd me Conrad Malaspina, not That old one, but from him I sprang. The love I bore my people is now here refin'd."
The narrator replies he was never in their dominions, but their glory is manifest throughout Europe.
