He praises their illustrious house, saying its fame proclaims its nobles and land, so even those who were never there know it. He swears that their nation does not impair "the value of her coffer and her sword." Nature and custom give her such privilege that while the world is twisted by a bad head, she alone "walks aright, and has the evil way in scorn." Conrad Malaspina then says, "Now pass thee on: sev'n times the tired sun Revisits not the couch, which with four feet The forked Aries covers, ere that kind opinion shall be nail'd into thy brain with stronger nails than other's speech can drive, if the sure course of judgment be not stay'd." He bids them farewell, as dawn glimmers and the angel comes. He would not hear more.

**CANTO IX**
Tithonus' old consort (Aurora) looks palely over the eastern cliff, her brow lucid with jewels. Night has passed two steps of her ascent, and the third is closing. The narrator, having "so much of Adam" (mortality) with him, sinks down upon the grass, overcome with sleep, where all five (Virgil, Sordello, Nino, Conrad, and the narrator) are seated.
Near dawn, when the swallow renews her sad lay and minds wander more from the flesh, full of holy divination in dreams, the narrator dreams of a golden-feathered eagle in the sky, hovering for descent. He imagines he is in the place from where Ganymede was snatched. He thinks the eagle strikes its quarry only here. The eagle wheels, rushes down, and snatches him upward "even to the fire." He thinks both he and the eagle burn intensely, breaking his sleep.
He shakes himself, like Achilles awaking on Scyros, pale like one ice-struck with dread. Virgil stands by his side. The sun is now more than two hours aloft. The narrator looks to the sea. Virgil cries, "Fear not: assur'd we are at happy point. Thy strength shrink not, but rise dilated. Thou art come To Purgatory now." He points to the cliff and the entrance where it seems disparted. Virgil explains that before dawn, a lady (Lucia) came while the narrator slept in the flowery vale. She told him, "I am Lucia. Suffer me to take this man, who slumbers. Easier so his way shall speed." Sordello and the other spirits tarried, and she bore the narrator up to this summit as day shone, and Virgil pursued her steps. She placed him there, and her eyes showed Virgil the entrance, then she vanished with his sleep.
The narrator is changed from doubt to comfort. Virgil, seeing him fearless, moves up the cliff, and the narrator follows. The narrator notes that his theme rises, so he props the structure more artfully. They draw near an opening like a breach in a wall, seeing a portal and three steps leading to it, each of a different color. One watches but speaks no word.
The watcher is seated on the highest step, his visage beyond the narrator's power to bear. He grasps a naked sword, whose rays glance back, dazzling the narrator. He cries, "Speak from whence ye stand: What would ye? Where is your escort? Take heed your coming upward harm ye not." Virgil replies a "heavenly dame" told them to "Pass that way: here the gate is." The courteous keeper replies, "And may she befriending prosper your ascent... Come then Before our steps." They go there.
The lowest stair is "marble white so smooth and polish'd," reflecting the narrator's form. The next is "darker than sablest grain," a rough, singed block, cracked lengthwise and across. The third, massy above, seems porphyry, "flam'd red as the life-blood spouting from a vein." On this, God's angel (the keeper) sustains either foot, seated on a diamond threshold.
Virgil cheerily draws the narrator up the steps, telling him to ask with a humble heart to unbar the bolt. The narrator casts himself at the angel's feet, praying for pity and opening. He falls thrice on his bosom. The angel inscribes seven P's (for peccata, sins) on his forehead with the blunt point of his drawn sword, saying, "Look... When enter'd, that thou wash these scars away." The angel's robe is the color of ashes or dry earth. From beneath his vestment, he draws two keys: one gold, one silver. With the pale key first, then the burnished, he plies the gate. He states that if either key fails to turn in the keyhole, access is in vain. The gold key is more precious, but the silver needs skill and sagacity. He holds them from Peter, instructed to err rather in opening than keeping fast, so long as the suppliant implores.
He thrusts open the door, exclaiming, "Enter, but this warning hear: He forth again departs who looks behind." The swivels turn with a strong, harsh grating sound. The narrator listens, hearing "We praise thee, O God," blended with sweet melody, like choral voices with organ music.

**CANTO X**
Having passed the threshold (which the soul's ill affection disuses, making the crooked seem straighter), the narrator hears it close. He wonders what plea would have availed had he turned his eyes back.
They mount the "riven rock," winding alternately like waves. Virgil says, "Here some little art behooves us... that our steps observe the varying flexure of the path." They speed so slowly that the moon once more rises before they thread the strait.
When they come to an open area where the mountain retires as one solid mass, the narrator is spent with toil, and both are uncertain of the way. The plain is more lonesome than desert roads. From the brink to the foot of the steep bank, the space measures thrice a man's stature. The cornice appears equal in extent as far as his eye can see.
Before their feet move on the summit, the narrator discovers the bank is "marble white," sculptured so exquisitely that Polycletus and nature itself would be shamed. The angel who brought tidings of peace, sculpted to life, seems to say "Hail!" for Mary (who opened the heavenly gates) is imaged there, with the words "Behold the handmaid of the Lord."
Virgil tells the narrator not to fix his mind on one place. The narrator turns and marks another story graven on the rock, behind Mary's form. He moves near it. Engraved in the same marble are the cart and kine drawing the sacred ark, aweing mankind from its unbidden office. Many people come before it, parted in seven choirs. One hears them not singing, another hears them sing. A doubt arises between eye and smell from the curled incense fume. Preceding the ark is David, Israel's harper, dancing and leaping, seeming "Less and yet more than kingly." Opposite, from a great palace, Michol looks forth "like a lady full of scorn and sorrow."
The narrator then moves to behold the next tablet, which shines whitely. Stored on the rock is the glory of Emperor Trajan, whose worth moved Gregory to earn his conquest. A widow stands at his bridle, attired in tears and mourning, amidst a throng of knights with eagles overhead. The wretch appears to say, "Grant vengeance, sire! for, woe beshrew this heart my son is murder'd." Trajan replies, "Wait now till I return." She asks what if he does not return. He says, "Where I am, who then is, may right thee." She asks what is others' good if he neglects his own. At length he answers, "It beseemeth well My duty be perform'd, ere I move hence: So justice wills; and pity bids me stay."
The narrator marvels at this visible speaking, new and strange. He gazes fondly on these patterns of "meek humbleness." Virgil whispers, "Lo... a multitude advance. These to the lofty steps shall guide us on." The narrator turns his eyes.
The narrator warns the reader not to miss their purpose, hearing how God decrees debts be canceled. He tells them not to ponder the form of suffering but what succeeds. Virgil tells him that what he sees tending hither "bears no trace of human semblance." Virgil explains they are "courb'd to earth, beneath their heavy teems of torment," so even his eye struggled at first. He bids him look intently to discern their pangs.
The narrator then exclaims, "Christians and proud! O poor and wretched ones! That feeble in the mind's eye, lean your trust upon unstaid perverseness! Know ye not that we are worms, yet made at last to form the winged insect, imp'd with angel plumes that to heaven's justice unobstructed soars? Why buoy ye up aloft your unfleg'd souls? Abortive then and shapeless ye remain, Like the untimely embryon of a worm!"
He sees these spirits fashioned like a corbel supporting a floor, crumpling knees to breast, stirring "ruth unfeign'd." Each is more or less contract according to his burden, but one, showing most patience, wails, "I can endure no more."

**CANTO XI**
The spirits under their heavy burdens pray the "Our Father," imploring God to hallow His name, join creation to extol His might, and bring His kingdom's peace. They ask that His will be done on earth as by angels in heaven. They pray for daily manna and for pardon as they pardon others. They ask God not to let their virtue be easily subdued by the old adversary, but to free them from his incitements. This last petition is for those remaining on earth, not for themselves.
The narrator reflects that these spirits go round the first circuit, purging "the world's gross darkness off." He wonders what can be vowed for them by those on earth whose wills have "root of goodness." He concludes they should help them wash away stains so they may spring to the starry spheres.
He then asks them that as mercy-tempered justice speeds their burdens, they would show him the shortest way to the ladder and the easiest ascent, as he, bearing Adam's fleshly raiment, mounts slowly despite his will.
The answer does not reveal the speaker but instructs them, "Along the bank to rightward come with us, and ye shall find a pass that mocks not toil of living man to climb." The speaker adds that were he not hindered by the rock taming his "arrogant neck," forcing him to stoop his visage to the ground, he would view the living man to see if he knew him and crave his pity. He identifies himself as Omberto, "of Latiun, of a Tuscan horn A mighty one." His "old blood and forefathers' gallant deeds" made him so haughty that he forgot "the common mother" and scorned men, hence his fall, by a fate Sienna's sons in Campagnatico can tell. Pride injured not only him but his kindred. His lot is to groan under this weight until he appeases God's justice.
The narrator bends his visage, and another spirit (not the speaker) twisted beneath the weight sees him, recognizes him, and calls. He fixes his eyes with difficulty as the narrator passes. The narrator exclaims, "Oderigi, art not thou Agobbio's glory, glory of that art which they of Paris call the limmer's skill?"
Oderigi replies, "Brother! with tints that gayer smile, Bolognian Franco's pencil lines the leaves. His all the honour now; mine borrow'd light." He admits he was not courteous in life due to zeal for pre-eminence, for which he pays here. He would not be here had he not turned to God before he was unable to sin. He laments the vanity of human glory, how Cimabue's fame was eclipsed by Giotto, and how one Guido snatched the prize from another, and another may yet drive both from their nest. Worldly fame is but a blast of wind. He asks if the narrator will live longer in men's mouths if his flesh is shriveled than if he died earlier, noting that such a span is briefer than a twinkling of an eye compared to eternity. He points to the spirit before him, Provenzano, who once resounded widely through Tuscany but is now scarce named in Sienna. He was sovereign when Florence fell to "madd'ning rage," proud then as she is loathsome now. He says renown is like an herb that withers.
The narrator tells Oderigi his words breathe meekness and allay his "tumours." He asks about Provenzano. Oderigi replies Provenzano is here because he "reach'd, with grasp presumptuous, at the sway of all Sienna." He still goes, never resting since he died, an acquittance for his excessive earthly daring.
The narrator then asks how Provenzano gained admittance so soon, given that souls delaying repentance linger in lower spaces unless prayers befriend them. Oderigi explains that when Provenzano was at his glory's height, casting aside dignity, he "fix'd him on Sienna's plain, a suitor to redeem his suff'ring friend, who languish'd in the prison-house of Charles," not refusing to tremble for his sake. He will say no more, knowing his words are dark, but the narrator's neighbors will soon comment on the text. He says "This is the work, that from these limits freed him."

**CANTO XII**
The narrator journeys with the laden spirit (Omberto) at equal pace, like oxen, as long as Virgil permits. When Virgil bids him quit and proceed, stating each man must push his bark with sail and oars, the narrator raises his body, ready for speed, but remains submissive in thought.
He pursues Virgil, who warns him to "Bend thine eyesight down: For thou to ease the way shall find it good To ruminate the bed beneath thy feet."
The narrator sees sculptured forms on the earth-level tombs, like memorials. Here, with more curious skill, whatever space stretches from the mountain is portrayed. He sees Lucifer, once noblest, falling lightning from heaven. On the other side, Briareus is pierced by a celestial bolt, cumbering earth. He sees the Thymbraean god (Apollo) with Mars and Pallas around their father (Jove), armed, gazing on the giant's limbs. He sees Nimrod at the foot of the stupendous work (Babel), bewildered, looking at the crowd attempting to build in Sennaar's plain.
He then beholds Niobe in a trance of woe, seven sons slain on either side. He sees Saul, ghastly, expiring on his own sword in Gilboa, never since visited by rain or dew. He sees Arachne, half spider, crawling up her unfinished web. He sees Rehoboam, fear-smote, whirled in his chariot with none to chase him.
It is shown how Alcmaeon forced his mother to rate her ill-received ornament. How Sennacherib's sons fell on him in the temple. Tomyris's scath and cruel mangling of Cyrus, crying, "Blood thou didst thirst for, take thy fill of blood!" The Assyrians routed, Holofernes slain. Troy in ashes and caverns. He remarks on the masterly skill of the portrayals, where the dead seemed dead and the living seemed alive. He urges the proud "sons of Eve" to swell not their necks, lest their looks betray their evil path.
So engrossed in thought, the narrator does not notice how much of the mount they have circled or how much more of the sun's course has passed. Virgil warns him to raise his head, for it is not time for slow suspense. He points to an angel approaching, the "sixth handmaid" returning from service. He tells the narrator to wear a seemly grace of awe so the angel will gladly further them aloft, reminding him that "this day ne'er dawns again."
The narrator, repeatedly warned about time's loss, understands. The angel approaches, snow-white in vesture, with a visage casting tremulous lustre. He opens his arms and wings, saying, "Onward: the steps, behold! are near; and now th' ascent is without difficulty gain'd."
The narrator laments that few hasten at such tidings. The angel leads them where the rock parts, beating his wings against the narrator's front, promising safe passage. The acclivity is relieved by steps carved in the old, simple age, but on each hand, the cliff presses close.
Entering, they hear ineffable voices singing, "Blessed are the poor in spirit." The narrator notes the stark contrast to hell's shrieks. They climb the holy stairs, and the narrator feels lighter, asking Virgil what heavy thing he has been lightened of. Virgil replies that when "sin's broad characters," still on his temples but nearly effaced, are all erased (like one already erased), his feet will be so overcome by will that they will feel no labor, but delight.
The narrator, like one who discovers something on his head through others' gestures, stretches his right hand fingers and finds only six of the seven P's traced on his brow. Virgil smiles.

**CANTO XIII**
They reach the summit of the scale and stand on the "second buttress of that mount which healeth him who climbs." A cornice, like the former, girdles the hill, but its arch bends with a less ample sweep.
No shadow or image is seen; the rampart and path are smooth, reflecting only the rock's sullen hue. Virgil fears delay if they wait to question. He fixes his eyes on the sun, using his right side as a central point, turning his left aside. He invokes the "pleasant light" to conduct them on this new way to their bourn, saying the world owes warmth and lustre to the sun, and its beams should guide them.
They journey a short space, impelled by prompt will, about a mile. They hear invisible spirits flying toward them, courteously inviting to "love's table." The first voice cries, "They have no wine." Another comes, crying, "I am Orestes." A third, "Love ye those have wrong'd you."
Virgil explains this circuit "knots the scourge for envy," and the cords are drawn by charity's correcting hand. The curb is harsher, as the narrator will hear. He tells him to fix his eyes through the air and he will see a multitude seated along the "shelving grot." The narrator opens his eyes and sees shadows with garments as dark as the rock. As they pass, he hears crying, "Blessed Mary! pray for us, Michael and Peter! all ye saintly host!"
The narrator believes no one on earth is so remorseless as not to pity the sight he next sees. His eyes teem with sorrow. He is so near he sees their semblances clearly. Their covering seems vile sackcloth. One stays another, leaning, and all lean against the cliff, like blind beggars near confessionals, their heads sunk on fellows, to stir compassion not by words alone, but by sight of misery. Heaven is a niggard of its light to them, for "a thread of wire, impiercing, knits them up" through the orbs of all, like for taming a hawk.
The narrator thinks it wrong to pass and look without being seen. He turns to Virgil, who, knowing his mute appeal, says, "Speak; and be brief, be subtle in thy words."
Virgil comes to the part of the cornice with no rim. On the other side are the spirits, bathing their cheeks with penitential tears that force a way through the impalement.
The narrator turns to them and says, "O shades!... Assur'd that to your eyes unveil'd shall shine The lofty light, sole object of your wish, So may heaven's grace clear whatsoe'er of foam Floats turbid on the conscience... As ye declare... if any soul Of Latium dwell among ye; and perchance That soul may profit, if I learn so much."
A voice replies, "My brother, we are each one citizens of one true city. Any thou wouldst say, who lived a stranger in Italia's land."
The narrator notices a spirit with an expectant look, chin raised like one bereft of sight. He asks the spirit, "who for thy rise are tutoring," to disclose himself by place or name.
It replies, "I was... of Sienna: here I cleanse away with these the evil life, soliciting with tears that He, who is, vouchsafe him to us. Though Sapia nam'd, in sapience I excell'd not, gladder far of others' hurt, than of the good befell me." To prove she does not deceive, she recounts her folly: when her years waned, her fellow citizens met enemies near Colle. She prayed God to grant what He had willed. They were vanquished and fled. She marked the hunt and, glad beyond bounds, lifted her shameless brow, crying, "It is over. Heav'n! I fear thee not." At life's verge, she wished for peace with God, and her repentance would not have supplied her lack of duty had not the hermit Piero, touched with charity, prayed for her.
She asks who the narrator is, walking with "lids unclos'd" and breathing. The narrator replies his eyes "may yet be here ta'en from me; but not long; for they have not offended grievously with envious glances. But the woe beneath urges my soul with more exceeding dread. That nether load already weighs me down."
Sapia asks, "Who then amongst us here aloft hath brought thee, if thou weenest to return?" The narrator replies, "He, who standeth mute beside me. I live: of me ask therefore, chosen spirit, if thou desire I yonder yet should move for thee my mortal feet." Sapia replies this is so strange a thing, it is a great sign God loves him. She asks him to assist her with his prayer and, by what he most covets, to save her fame among her kindred if his feet ever tread Tuscan soil. She adds he will behold her kindred with "that vain multitude, who set their hope on Telamone's haven, there to fail confounded, more shall when the fancied stream they sought of Dian call'd: but they who lead their navies, more than ruin'd hopes shall mourn."

**CANTO XIV**
Two spirits bending to each other discuss the narrator: "Say who is he around our mountain winds, or ever death has prun'd his wing for flight, that opes his eyes and covers them at will?" They urge the other to gently accost him. Both then address the narrator, leaning back their faces.
One asks, "O soul, who yet Pent in the body, tendest towards the sky! For charity, we pray thee' comfort us, Recounting whence thou com'st, and who thou art: For thou dost make us at the favour shown thee Marvel, as at a thing that ne'er hath been."
The narrator begins, "There stretches through the midst of Tuscany, a brooklet, whose well-head Springs up in Falterona, with his race Not satisfied, when he some hundred miles Hath measur'd." He says he brings his frame from its banks. To tell who he is would be misspent words, for his name "scarce sounds on rumour's lip."
The first spirit interprets, "thou dost speak of Arno's wave." The other asks why he concealed the river's title as one would "some horrible thing." The first spirit replies he doesn't know, but it is fitting the valley's name should perish. He describes how from the source where the Alpine steep teems, to where the ocean is restored, "virtue is worried down" like a snake, either by disastrous influence or misguided wills. Thus, in the "miserable vale," nature is transformed, as if they "had shar'd of Circe's feeding." He describes its inhabitants as swine, then curs, then wolves, then foxes replete with craft. He reveals that the narrator's grandson will become a hunter of those wolves on the fierce stream's shore, selling their living flesh, then dooming them to slaughter like aged beasts. He will reave many of life, but himself of worth, leaving such havoc that it will not spread to prime lustihood again in a thousand years.
The spirit who listened changes looks, perturbed by tidings of woe. His visage and the other's speech make the narrator desire their names. He meekly inquires.
The first shade replies, "Thy wish imports that I vouchsafe to do For thy sake what thou wilt not do for mine. But since God's will is that so largely shine His grace in thee, I will be liberal too." He identifies himself as Guido of Duca. Envy so parched his blood that he turned livid at another's joy. He wonders why man places his heart where exclusion of participants in good is needed. He introduces the other spirit as Rinieri, "the boast and honour of the house of Calboli," where no heritage of his worth remains.
He laments that not only his blood but others between the Po, the mount, the Reno, and the shore have been stripped of bliss. Such a growth of "rank and venom'd roots" has sprung up, mocking culture's toil. He asks where good Lizio, Manardi, Traversalo, and Carpigna are. He calls the new generations "bastard slips of old Romagna's line." He points out that in Bologna, the low artisan, and in Faenza, Bernardin sprout as "a gentle cyon from ignoble stem." He weeps recalling the loved names, Guido of Prata, Azzo, Tignoso, Traversaro's house, Anastagio's, and the ladies and knights who bewitched them into love and courtesy, where now malice reigns. He asks why Brettinoro tarries, as its family is gone. He praises Bagnacavallo for ending his lineage but condemns Castracaro and Conio for propagating a race of Counts from their blood. He says Pagani will do well when their "demon child" tries. He tells Hugolin of Fantolini his name is safe as none is expected to cloud its lustre. He then tells the narrator to go, for he takes more delight in weeping than in words, such pity has wrung his heart.
They know the gentle spirits heard their steps, and their silence assures them. As they leave, a voice like lightning cries, "Whosoever finds will slay me," then flees. Another voice crashes, "Mark in me Aglauros turn'd to rock." The narrator draws closer to Virgil.
The air rests in mute stillness. Virgil explains, "There was the galling bit. But your old enemy so baits his hook, He drags you eager to him. Hence nor curb Avails you, nor reclaiming call." Heaven calls and courts their gaze with beauties, yet their eye turns to earth. Therefore, God smites them.

**CANTO XV**
The narrator describes the sun's journey, which has less than a third remaining to its western goal. Evening is there, and midnight here. The sun's beams strike their forehead directly. Due to their path circling the mountain, they journey toward sunset. The narrator feels a weight of "exceeding splendour" press his front, causing amaze. He shields his eyes with his hands, clipping the diminished orb. He compares the refracted light to rays striking water or a mirror.
He asks Virgil what this is, "gainst which I strive to shield the sight in vain?" and "which towards us moving seems?" Virgil replies not to marvel if the "family of heav'n" dims his sense, for it is a messenger inviting man's ascent. Such sights, not grievous, will soon bring delight as his perception rises to their pitch.
The angel hails them with glad voice: "Here enter on a ladder far less steep than ye have yet encounnter'd." Ascending, they hear chanted sweetly, "Blessed the merciful," and "happy thou! That conquer'st."
The narrator and Virgil go alone, and the narrator asks Virgil what Romagna's spirit meant by "bliss exclusive with no partner shar'd." Virgil replies it's no wonder he chides others, knowing the sorrow of his own defect. He explains that because men point their wishes at a mark where communion lessens part, "envy bloweth up the sighs." No fear of that would touch them if love of a higher sphere exalted desire, "for there, by how much more they call it ours, So much propriety of each in good Increases more, and heighten'd charity Wraps that fair cloister in a brighter flame."
The narrator feels less satisfied and more doubtful, asking how good distributed makes many richer than if shared by few. Virgil replies his mind, reverting to earth, "strikes darkness from true light." The "highest good unlimited, ineffable," speeds to love, giving as much ardor as it finds. The "sempiternal effluence" streams wherever charity extends. So, the more aspirants to bliss are multiplied, "more good is there to love, and more is lov'd; as mirrors, that reflect, each unto other, propagated light." If his words don't satisfy, Beatrice will resolve his doubts fully. He must ensure his five scars (P's) are erased.
The narrator says Virgil contents him, when he finds they have gained the next round, and wonder keeps him mute. He suddenly seems rapt away by an ecstatic vision. He sees a crowd in a temple, and a dame (Mary) at the entrance saying, "Child! why hast thou dealt with us thus? Behold thy sire and I sorrowing have sought thee." The vision flees. Next, a female (Lavinia) appears, weeping, saying, "If thou, Pisistratus, be lord indeed over this city... Avenge thee of those arms, whose bold embrace hath clasp'd our daughter." Her sovereign (Pisistratus) replies benignly, "How shall we those requite, who wish us evil, if we thus condemn the man that loves us?" After that, he sees a multitude burning in fury, stoning a youth (Stephen), who bows to the ground yet lifts his eyes to heaven, praying forgiveness for his foes.
His spirit returns from its flight, and he observes that his vision was not unreal. Virgil, seeing him struggling to shake off sleep, exclaims, "What ails thee, that thou canst not hold Thy footing firm... Like to a man by wine or sleep o'ercharg'd?"
The narrator tells Virgil what appeared to him. Virgil replies that even with a hundred vizards, his thoughts could not elude him. He explains the vision was shown "that freely thou mightst ope thy heart to the waters of peace," not asking "what ails thee" to discern his state, but to give fresh vigor to his foot. Such goads the slow and loitering need.
They journey on, gazing at the evening sky. A fog, dark as night, gathers toward them. There is no room for escaping, and the mist bereaves them of sight and pure air.

**CANTO XVI**
Hell's gloom or unlustrous night never spread a veil as thick, palpable, and gross as this fog. Entering its shade, the narrator cannot endure it with unclosed lids. Virgil draws near, offering his shoulder for support.
The narrator journeys through the "bitter air and foul," listening to Virgil's warning, "Look that from me thou part not." He hears voices, each praying for peace and compassion to the "Lamb of God that taketh sins away." Their prelude is "Agnus Dei," and through the choir, one voice, one measure. The narrator asks if these are spirits. Virgil confirms they are those who "loose the bonds of wrath."
One voice asks, "Now who art thou, that through our smoke dost cleave? And speak'st of us, as thou thyself e'en yet Dividest time by calends?" Virgil tells the narrator to reply and ask if the passage leads upward.
The narrator addresses the spirit, "O being! who dost make thee pure, to stand beautiful once more in thy Maker's sight! Along with me: and thou shalt hear and wonder." The spirit replies, "Long as 't is lawful for me, shall my steps follow on thine; and since the cloudy smoke Forbids the seeing, hearing in its stead Shall keep us join'd."
The narrator states that he, in his mortal body, ascends to higher regions, coming through the "fearful agony of hell." If God has granted him such grace to behold His kingly state, he asks the spirit to reveal who he was before death and if he tends correctly to the pass.
The spirit replies he was "of Lombardy, and Marco call'd: Not inexperienc'd of the world, that worth I still affected, from which all have turn'd The nerveless bow aside." He confirms the narrator's course tends right to the summit and asks for prayers when the narrator comes aloft.
The narrator pledges to perform what he requests, but expresses a doubt that sorely wrings him. He notes that Virgil's opinion now doubles his previous doubt that the world is so forlorn of good and swarms with evil. He asks for the cause, as some place it in heaven, some on earth.
Marco sighs and begins, "Brother! the world is blind; And thou in truth com'st from it." He explains that those who live refer all causes to heaven, "E'en as its motion of necessity Drew with it all that moves." If this were so, free choice would be none, nor justice joy for virtue, woe for ill. He asserts that human movements have their "primal bent from heaven; Not all; yet said I all;" but they still have "Light... to follow evil or good, And of the will free power, which... Conquers at last... triumphant over all." Subject to mightier force and better nature, they abide free, not constrained by stars. If mankind errs, the cause is within themselves.
He explains that the soul, from God's hand, comes like a babe, artless and ignorant, save that its Maker dwells with gladness. It willingly turns to whatever yields joy, tastes "some slight good," and pursues it fondly if no guide or rein directs it. Hence, law and a sovereign were needed to mark "the fortress and main tower of the true city." Laws exist, but none observe them, not even the shepherd (Pope) who "chews the cud but doth not cleave the hoof" (i.e., is not truly clean). Thus, the multitude, seeing their guide strike at the very good they covet, feed there and look no further. The cause is not corrupted nature, but "ill-conducting, that hath turn'd the world to evil."
Rome once boasted two suns (Empire and Papacy) that cast light on both the world's and God's way. One (Papacy) has since quenched the other, and "the sword Is grafted on the crook; and so conjoin'd Each must perforce decline to worse, unaw'd by fear of other." He tells the narrator to mark the blade (sword) if he doubts.
He says the land where Adige and Po roll was once of courtesy and valor, before Frederick's time. Now, those who have left to talk with good men or frequent their haunts may pass limits securely. Three aged ones remain, Gherardo, Conrad, and Guido of Castello, who "chide the new" time and wish for a better world. He concludes, "The church of Rome, Mixing two governments that ill assort, Hath miss'd her footing, fall'n into the mire, And there herself and burden much defil'd."
The narrator tells Marco his arguments convince him, and he understands why Levi's offspring received no heritage. He asks who Gherardo is, a sample of the perished race. Marco replies the narrator's words deceive or try him if he, speaking Tuscan, has not heard of "good Gherardo." He says he knows him only by that, unless he borrowed another name from his daughter Gaia. Marco then bids them farewell, for dawn gleams, and he must away before the angel appears. He would not hear more.

**CANTO XVII**
The narrator recalls how he was once enveloped by cloud on a mountaintop, seeing no better than a mole. Then, as the vapors melted, the sun's sphere seemed wading. So he first re-beheld the sun, which was now overhanging its bed.
He reflects on the "quick and forgetive power" of fantasy that sometimes robs them of themselves. He wonders what moves it, if not the senses. Perhaps light kindled in heaven or gliding down by divine will. Portrayed before him came traces of impiety of Procne, changed to a bird. His mind was so wrapped he gave no place to external thoughts.
Next, a crucified shape appeared in his fantasy, visage speaking "fell rancour, malice deep," dying amidst Ahasuerus, Esther, and Mordecai. This vision burst like a bubble. Then a damsel appeared, weeping loud, crying, "O queen! O mother! wherefore has intemperate ire Driv'n thee to loath thy being? Not to lose Lavinia, desp'rate thou hast slain thyself. Now hast thou lost me. I am she, whose tears Mourn, ere I fall, a mother's timeless end." (Amata, Lavinia's mother, committing suicide).
As sleep breaks off with sudden radiance, so the imagery vanished when light struck his face. He turns to survey his location, hearing a voice exclaim, "Here ye mount," leaving him no other purpose but to gaze. His virtue fails, unequal to the light. Virgil explains this is a "Spirit from above, who marshals us our upward way, unsought; And in his own light shrouds him." He says they must not refuse to ascend quickly before it darkens, as they may not then until morning.
Virgil leads them, and at the first stair, the narrator perceives the waving of a wing that fans his face and whispers, "Blessed they The peacemakers: they know not evil wrath."
The sun's last beams are high above, and night close behind. The narrator feels his sinews slacken. They reach the summit and are fixed like a bark at land. Waiting, he asks Virgil what guilt is purged on this circle. Virgil replies, "The love of good, whate'er wanted of just proportion, here fulfils. Here plies afresh the oar, that loiter'd ill."
To understand clearly, Virgil explains that no being, creator or created, was ever without love, either natural or of the free spirit. Natural love is without error, but the other swerves if bent on ill objects, or through excess or defect of vigor. When it seeks primal blessings or inferior ones with due measure, no delight partakes of ill. But if it warps to evil, or pursues good with too much or too little ardor, "the thing created then Works 'gainst its Maker." Hence, love is the "germin of each virtue" and each act meriting pain.
Since love intends the welfare of the loved thing, all are secure from self-hatred. And no being can exist apart from the first, so they are restrained from hating God.
Granting this, the evil must be another's which is loved. Such love is gendered three ways: one hopes for preeminence by depressing a neighbor's worth; one fears loss of power, fame, favor, or glory if a fellow rises, and loves their opposite; one thirsts for vengeance due to wrong or insult, and must dote on another's evil. This "threefold love is mourn'd" here.
He then instructs on the other sort of love that follows good with disordered course. All indistinctly apprehend bliss and yearn for it, striving to tend to that bourn. If they behold or seek it with "a love remiss and lax," this cornice lays its penal torment on them. Other good exists, where man does not find happiness; it is not true fruition. Love too lavishly bestowed on this is mourned along three circles above them. He will not account for that tripartite division, finding it fitter for the narrator's own research.

**CANTO XVIII**
Virgil ends his discourse, inquiring if the narrator is content. The narrator, still thirsty to hear, is mute outwardly but inwardly fears his questioning offends. Virgil, a "true father," marks his secret wish and gives him boldness to speak. The narrator states his sight gathers lively virtue from Virgil's beams, making his words distinct. He asks Virgil, whom his heart holds dearest, to unfold love, the source of good deeds and their opposite.
Virgil replies, "To what I now disclose be thy clear ken Directed, and thou plainly shalt behold How much those blind have err'd, who make themselves The guides of men." The soul, created apt to love, moves whichever way something pleasing prompts her once wakened by pleasure. Their apprehension forms a counterfeit, presenting an ideal shape that attracts the soul. If she inclines toward it, "love is that inclining, and a new nature knit by pleasure in ye." Like fire seeking its birthplace, the captive soul enters desire, which rests not before enjoying the loved thing. This shows how truth is hidden from those who say all love is praiseworthy in itself, for though its substance seems good, good wax doesn't guarantee a good impression.
The narrator replies Virgil's words and his docile mind reveal "what love is." But new doubts arise: if love is offered from without, and the spirit knows no other footing, whether it tends right or wrong is no desert of hers.
Virgil replies he can show what reason discovers, but what lies beyond must be expected from Beatrice, as it's faith's task, not reason's. He explains that spirit, "substantial form, with matter join'd Not in confusion mix'd," has specific virtue from that union, felt only when it works, as vegetable life by a green leaf. Man knows not whence his intellect deduces primal notices or his appetites their first affections, like bees gathering honey; at first, volition merits neither blame nor praise. But supreme over lower faculties, man has a virtue whose "just voice uttereth counsel," which should keep "the threshold of assent." This is the source of merit, taking or severing affections as chaff is winnowed. Men reasoning profoundly marked this innate freedom, leaving their moral teaching to the world. He grants that all love arises from necessity, but the power to dismiss or harbor it is in themselves. He reminds him that Beatrice calls free choice "the noble virtue."
The moon, belated near midnight, makes stars wink and fade, its broad disk like a crag on fire. The weight on the narrator's thought is lightened by Virgil.
As his questions receive solution, the narrator muses in dreary slumber. But he does not slumber long, for a multitude rushes upon them, turning the steep, with fury and random rout, like Ismenus and Asopus echoing for Thebes, impelled by eagerness of holy love.
The crowd overtakes them swiftly. Two spirits at their head cry weeping, "Blessed Mary sought with haste the hilly region. Caesar to subdue Ilerda, darted in Marseilles his sting, and flew to Spain." Others shout, "Oh tarry not: away; let not time be lost through slackness of affection. Hearty zeal to serve reanimates celestial grace."
Virgil addresses them, "O ye, in whom intenser fervency Haply supplies, where lukewarm erst ye fail'd, Slow or neglectful, to absolve your part Of good and virtuous, this man, who yet lives, (Credit my tale, though strange) desires t' ascend, So morning rise to light us. Therefore say Which hand leads nearest to the rifted rock?"
A shade replies, "Come after us, and thou shalt find the cleft. We may not linger: such resistless will Speeds our unwearied course. Vouchsafe us then Thy pardon, if our duty seem to thee Discourteous rudeness." He identifies himself: "In Verona I Was abbot of San Zeno, when the hand Of Barbarossa grasp'd Imperial sway, That name, ne'er utter'd without tears in Milan." He predicts one with "one foot in his grave" will soon weep for that monastery, ruining his misused power by setting his ill-compact, worse-minded, evil-born son in place of its true pastor. Whether he spoke more or was mute, the narrator knows not, for he sped far beyond them.
Virgil points out two more chiding their sin with sharp remorse in the rear of the troop. They shout, "First they died, to whom the sea Opened, or ever Jordan saw his heirs: And they, who with Aeneas to the end Endur'd not suffering, for their portion chose Life without glory." (This refers to slothful Israelites and Trojans). As they flee past sight, new thoughts rise in the narrator, followed by others, until his eyes close, and meditation changes to dream.

**CANTO XIX**
At the hour when no heat relics chafe the moon's cold beams, and the geomancer sees his "Greater Fortune" ascend the east, the narrator dreams of a stammering, aslant-eyed, distorted-footed, maimed-handed, pale woman's shape. He looks upon her, and his gaze cheers her, unloosing her tongue, raising her decrepit form erect, and illuminating her faded face with love's hue. Recovering speech, she warbles a strain that enthralls him. She sings, "I am the Siren, she, whom mariners On the wide sea are wilder'd when they hear: Such fulness of delight the list'ner feels. I from his course Ulysses by my lay Enchanted drew. Whoe'er frequents me once Parts seldom; so I charm him, and his heart Contented knows no void."
Before her mouth closes, a dame of holy semblance appears, shaming her. With stern voice, she asks Virgil, "Say, O Virgil, who is this?" Virgil approaches, eyes on the goodly presence. The other dame seizes the Siren, tearing her robes, opening her before, and showing her belly, from which a loathsome smell exhales, waking the narrator.
He turns, and Virgil says he has called him thrice, urging him to rise and find the opening. The narrator rises. Day fills the sacred mountain's circuits. They journey on, the early ray striking their shoulder. The narrator follows, stooping his forehead like a man burdened with thought. He hears, "Come, enter here," in a soft, mild tone.
An angelic shape with swan-like wings marshals them along where the sloping walls retire. Fanning them, he affirms that those who mourn are blessed, for comfort shall be theirs.
Virgil asks why the narrator still looks to earth. The narrator replies a "New vision" has raised strange surmises and anxious doubts. Virgil asks if he has seen the "old enchantress" (Siren) for whom spirits weep, and how man may free himself. He tells him to spurn earth, fix his ken on the lure of heaven. The narrator, like a falcon, looks down, then to the sky, eager for the food. So he journeys onward as the rock gives way, until the plain is reached.
On the fifth circle, a race of spirits appears, lying prone on the ground, weeping sore. They sigh, "My soul hath cleaved to the dust." They ask to be directed to the steep rising.
A voice replies, "If ye approach secure from this our doom, Prostration—and would urge your course with speed, See that ye still to rightward keep the brink."
The narrator notes what remains hidden from them, then looks to Virgil, who interprets their suit and beckons assent. The narrator approaches a shade whose words he heard. He asks the spirit, "in whom repentant tears mature that blessed hour," to suspend his care and say who he was, why they grovel prone, and if he wishes his service in the world.
The spirit replies he will know why Heaven reverses their backs toward its cope. He identifies himself first as "the successor of Peter," with a name and lineage from the stream between Chiaveri and Siestri. He learned in a month the weight of the robe of sovereignty, making other burdens seem like feathers. His conversion was late, but as Rome's pastor, he discerned "the dream and cozenage of life," seeing the heart rested not there. Not enamored of that life, love of purer being kindled in his bosom. Until then, he was a soul in misery, alienate from God and covetous. Now, he is punished for his doting. He says converted spirits need such cleansing from avarice, and no direr penalty is inflicted here. As their eyes were fixed below and never lifted to loftier clime, justice has leveled them on earth. As avarice quenched their love of good, justice holds them prisoned, hand and foot, until God pleases.
The narrator stoops his knees to speak, but the spirit perceives his reverence. He asks, "What cause hath bow'd thee thus?" The narrator replies, "Compunction... And inward awe of your high dignity."
The spirit exclaims, "Up... upon thy feet Arise: err not: thy fellow servant I, (Thine and all others') of one Sovran Power." He refers to the gospel truth, "'nor shall be given ill marriage'," to explain his speech. He bids him go and linger no more, as his tarrying delays the tears he needs. He has a kinswoman on earth, Alagia, worthy in herself if ill example does not corrupt her, and she is all that remains of him.

**CANTO XX**
The narrator moves onward, Virgil leading, coasting along the vacant rock, like a man walking battlements on a narrow wall, as those on the other part wring out their "all-infecting malady" too closely press the verge. He curses the "inveterate wolf" (Avarice/Greed), whose maw is bottomless, and implores the spheres of heaven for the coming of one who will chase her away.
They pass with wary and slow steps, attentive to the shades lamenting and wailing. One voice cries, "O blessed Virgin!" like a woman in childbed, adding, "How poor Thou wast... witness that low roof Where thou didst lay thy sacred burden down. O good Fabricius! thou didst virtue choose With poverty, before great wealth with vice."
The narrator is pleased by these words and drawn to know the spirit. It speaks of Nicholas' gift to save maidens' prime. The narrator asks the spirit who he is and why he renews such praise, hoping for reward if he returns to life.
The spirit replies he will tell, not for hell, which he looks for, but because of the grace shining in the narrator before his dissolution. He was "root of that ill plant" (Capetian dynasty) whose poison spreads over Christian land, yielding seldom good fruit. He calls for vengeance, imploring heaven's Judge. He identifies himself as Hugh Capet, from whom the Philips and Louis of France descend, born of one who was a "slaughterer" in Paris. When the ancient kings vanished, he found the reins of empire and friends, so his son (Hugh Capet's son, Robert the Pious) was crowned.
He explains that until the "great dower of Provence" removed stains from their blood, their sway was narrow but wrought no evil. Then, with force and lies, rapine began, seizing Poitou, Navarre, and Gascony. Charles (Charles I of Anjou) came to Italy, slew Conradine (an innocent victim) "for amends," and sent the "angelic teacher" (Thomas Aquinas) back to heaven "still for amends." He sees a future Charles (Charles of Valois) invited from France, unarmed save with the lance the arch-traitor (Judas) tilted with, to rive Florence's bowels, gaining sin and shame, not territory. He sees another (Philip IV) exposing his daughter to market like corsairs their slaves. He curses avarice for subduing their blood so they care not for their own flesh. He sees the "flower-de-luce" (French royal arms) enter Alagna to hide guilt, making Christ's Vicar a captive, his mockery acted again, his holy lip applied with vinegar and gall, bleeding between robbers. He calls Philip IV a "new Pilate" who pushes into the temple with eager sails.
Hugh Capet asks when he will rejoice to see God's vengeance. He says that during daylight, the Virgin's spouse (Joseph) is the theme of their prayers, but at night, they utter different strains, recalling Pygmalion (made traitor, robber, parricide by gold), Midas (greedy wish mocked), and Achan (stole prey, pursued by Joshua's ire). They blame Sapphira and her husband and praise the forefeet that spurned Heliodorus. The mountain rings with the infamy of Thracia's king (Polymnestor), who slew his Phrygian charge. Lastly, a shout ascends, "Declare, O Crassus! for thou know'st, The flavour of thy gold." Each voice is led through many pitches. He says he did not singly rehearse the blessedness they speak of by day because no one near him raised their accent.
They now depart from him, striving to surmount the way. The narrator feels the mountain tremble, like nodding to its fall, an icy chill seizing him as if conveyed to death. He compares it to Delos shaking.
A vehement shout arises from every side. Virgil draws near, crying, "Doubt not, while I conduct thee." All shout, "Glory! Glory in the highest be to God." They stand immovable like shepherds hearing the song in Bethlehem. When the trembling and song cease, they resume their hallowed path, eyeing the prostrate shadows who renew their mourning. The narrator's ignorance struggles with desire for knowledge. He dares not question nor discern, proceeding in thoughtfulness and dread.

**CANTO XXI**
The narrator's natural thirst, quenched only from the well of the Samaritan woman, impels him to haste after Virgil. Pity moves his bosom for the "vengeful deed, though just."
Luke relates Christ appearing to two on their way from the tomb. Similarly, a shade appears behind them, approaching, contemplating the crowd beneath its feet. Unaware, they hear it say, "God give you peace, my brethren!" They turn. Virgil returns a fitting salute, crying, "Peace in the blessed council be thy lot Awarded by that righteous court, which me To everlasting banishment exiles!"
The shade exclaims, "How!" without stopping, asking, "If that ye be spirits, whom God Vouchsafes not room above, who up the height Has been thus far your guide?" Virgil replies that the tokens the narrator bears, traced by the angel's finger, show he must share in the kingdom of the just. But since the wheel (Fortune) has not yet spun the yarn of his mortal dissolution, his soul (sister to Virgil's and the shade's) could not mount of itself. Virgil was taken from hell's ample gulf to lead him as far as his lore avails. He asks the shade why the mount shook and trembled earlier and why all shouted.
The narrator feels his thirst abate from expectation. The shade replies, "In its devotion nought irregular This mount can witness, or by punctual rule Unsanction'd; here from every change exempt." No influence other than what heaven receives can reach them. No tempest, shower, hail, snow, frost, or dew falls higher than the three steps (of the gate of Purgatory). No thick clouds, lightning, or rainbows are seen above. Vapor does not mount above the highest stair where Peter's vicegerent stands. Below, the soil trembles with various motion, but here, through "wind in earth's deep hollow pent," it never trembled until "any spirit feels itself so purified, that it may rise, or move For rising," and then loud acclaim ensues. Purification is proved by the will alone, free to change society, seizing the soul in joy. Desire of bliss is present from the first, but strong "propension" (to sin) hinders it, opposed by heaven's ordinance. This propension is now eager to fulfill allotted torment as it was to sin. The shade states he had lain in this punishment for "Five hundred years and more" but now feels a "free wish for happier clime." Therefore, the mountain trembled, and the spirits praised their liege Lord. The narrator is filled with content.
Virgil, the sage, then says, "Now... I see the net That takes ye here, and how the toils are loos'd, Why rocks the mountain and why ye rejoice." He asks the shade who he was on earth and why he was prostrate for so long.
The shade replies that "In that time, When the good Titus... Aveng'd those piteous gashes, whence the blood By Judas sold did issue," he was "abundantly renown'd" with the "name Most lasting and most honour'd," though "not yet with faith endued." His "vocal Spirit" was so sweet that Rome drew him from Tolosa, where he merited a myrtle garland. "Statius they name me still. Of Thebes I sang, And next of great Achilles: but i' th' way Fell with the second burthen." He says the sparks of his poetic flame were derived from the "bright fountain of celestial fire" (Virgil's Aeneid), which was his nurse and authority. He would abide "the revolution of another sun" (another 500 years) in banishment to have lived coeval with Virgil.
Virgil turns to the narrator, enjoining silence by his countenance. But the will bears not supreme control; laughter and tears follow passion. The narrator smiles, winking. The shade breaks off, peering into his eyes, asking why a smile beamed across his visage.
The narrator is "straite'd," one side (Virgil) binding silence, the other (the shade) conjuring him to speak. He sighs. Virgil tells him to speak and tell what the shade asks. The narrator explains that he marvels at his smiling, but there is "room for yet more wonder." He reveals that Virgil, who guides his ken on high, is the Mantuan by whom the shade "didst presume of men and gods to sing." If the shade deemed another cause for his smile, he should believe the narrator's words about Virgil are the true cause.
The shade bends down to embrace Virgil's feet, but Virgil forbids him, "Brother! do it not: Thou art a shadow, and behold'st a shade." The shade rises and replies, "Now hast thou prov'd The force and ardour of the love I bear thee, When I forget we are but things of air, And as a substance treat an empty shade."

**CANTO XXII**
They leave the angel who turned their steps to the sixth circle, one Gash (P) from the narrator's forehead erased. Those whose wishes tend to justice shout, "Blessed!" ending with, "I thirst." The narrator, more nimble, journeys without toil, following the swift-footed shades.
Virgil begins: "Let its pure flame From virtue flow, and love can never fail To warm another's bosom' so the light Shine manifestly forth." He explains that since the spirit of Aquinum's bard (Thomas Aquinas) came among them in the deep and told of Statius's (the shade's) affection, Virgil's goodwill has been as strong as for one unseen. These stairs will seem short. He asks Statius, as a friend, how "covetous desire could find Place in that bosom, 'midst such ample store Of wisdom."
Statius, somewhat moved to laughter, replies each syllable is a dear pledge of love. He says things appear that minister false matters when true causes are removed. Virgil's question assures him he believes Statius was covetous, perhaps because he found him in that circle (where avarice is punished). Statius declares he was "too wide of avarice," and for that excess, thousands of moons have waxed and waned on his sufferings. Had he not heeded Virgil's exclamation against the "cursed thirst of gold," he would have met "the fierce encounter of the voluble rock" (the opposite punishment, for prodigality). He realized his hands could hasten to lavishment and turned from this evil in penitence. He notes how many with shorn locks (prodigals) will rise from their graves, having not repented this offense in ignorance. The fault directly opposite to any sin wastes its "green rankness on one common heap." Therefore, if he was with the avaricious, it was to cleanse himself through reverse of their transgression.
Virgil asks Statius, "While thou didst sing that cruel warfare wag'd By the twin sorrow of Jocasta's womb, From thy discourse with Clio there, it seems As faith had not been shine: without the which Good deeds suffice not. And if so, what sun Rose on thee, or what candle pierc'd the dark That thou didst after see to hoist the sail, And follow, where the fisherman had led?"
Statius replies: "By thee conducted first, I enter'd the Parnassian grots, and quaff'd Of the clear spring; illumin'd first by thee Open'd mine eyes to God." He credits Virgil as one who, journeying through darkness, hears a light behind that profits him not but makes followers wise, when he exclaimed, "Lo! A renovated world! Justice return'd! Times of primeval innocence restor'd! And a new race descended from above!" Statius owes to Virgil being both poet and Christian. He promises to inform his lines with livelier coloring. He says that soon, messengers from heaven spread true belief, and Virgil's word accorded with new instructors. Induced by this, Statius resorted to them, and their sanctity won him over. During Domitian's rage, he mixed his tears with theirs and succored them, their righteous customs making him scorn other sects. He was baptized before leading the Greeks in fiction, but secretly remained Christian through fear, conforming to Pagan rites. For that lukewarmness, he paced the fourth circle for "Five centuries and more."
He asks Virgil, who has raised the covering from this blessing, if he knows where old Terence, Caecilius, Plautus, and Varro bide, if condemned, and in what province of the deep. Virgil replies, "These... with Persius and myself, And others many more, are with that Greek, Of mortals, the most cherish'd by the Nine, In the first ward of darkness." There they converse about the mount where their nurses live. He names Pella's bard (Alexander the Great), Teian (Anacreon), Agatho, Simonides, and other Greeks. He mentions Antigone, Deiphile, Argia, Ismene, and the one who showed Langia's wave (Hypsipyle). Deidamia with her sisters, blind Tiresias' daughter (Manto), and Peleus' sea-born bride (Thetis) are also there.
Both poets are silent, no longer obstructed by ascent or steep walls, casting inquiring eyes. Four handmaids of the day have finished, and the fifth is at the chariot-beam. Virgil suggests they bend their right shoulder, circling the mount as usual. Custom guides them.
They go before, the narrator following, listening to their speech of "Mysterious lessons of sweet poesy." But they cease. Midway, they find a tree with goodly fruit, pleasant to smell. It spreads less ample downward, so none can climb aloft. From the side closing their path, a liquid crystal falls from the rock, showering through sprays. The bards draw near. A voice from the leaves says, "Ye shall be chary of me;" and adds, "Mary took more thought For joy and honour of the nuptial feast, Than for herself who answers now for you. The women of old Rome were satisfied With water for their beverage. Daniel fed On pulse, and wisdom gain'd. The primal age Was beautiful as gold; and hunger then Made acorns tasteful, thirst each rivulet Run nectar. Honey and locusts were the food, Whereon the Baptist in the wilderness Fed, and that eminence of glory reach'd And greatness, which the' Evangelist records."

**CANTO XXIII**
The narrator's eyes are fixed on the green leaf like one chasing trifles. Virgil warns, "Son! our time Asks thriftier using. Linger not: away."
The narrator turns his face and steps toward the sages, cheered by their converse, feeling no toil. He hears weeping and a song, "My lips, O Lord!" mingled to create pleasure and pain. He asks Virgil what he hears. Virgil replies, "Spirits... who as they go, perchance, Their debt of duty pay."
Thoughtful pilgrims overtaking strangers turn and look but do not stay. Similarly, a crowd of silent, devout spirits approaches from behind with speedier motion, eyeing them. Their eyes are dark and hollow, their visages pale and lean, bones staring through skin, dryer and meagrer than Erysichthon pinched by famine.
The narrator muses, "Lo! the race, who lost Jerusalem, when Mary with dire beak Prey'd on her child." Their sockets seem like rings without gems. The letter M is traced plainly on their foreheads. He wonders how the scent of water and an apple could cause such pining want.
A spirit turns his deeply sunken eyes on the narrator, crying vehemently, "What grace is this vouchsaf'd me?" The narrator recognizes the voice of Forese, not his looks. Remembrance is kindled from that spark. Forese implores respect for his "wan and leprous wither'd skin... this macerated flesh." He asks the narrator to speak truly of himself and who his escorts are.
The narrator replies that Forese's face, which he once bewailed as dead, now makes him weep at its transformation. He asks by Heaven what blasts them, deferring his own speech.
Forese explains, "The water and tee plant we pass'd, Virtue possesses, by th' eternal will Infus'd, the which so pines me." Every spirit who bewails gluttony is here purified by hunger and thirst. The odor of the fruit and spray inflames them with desire. They encompass their route not once alone to add fuel to pain, but it is solace, for that will leads them to the tree by which Christ was led to call Elias when he paid ransom.
The narrator replies that not five years have passed since Forese changed worlds. If he had finished sinning before knowing kindly grief, how did he come so soon? The narrator expected to find him lower, where time is recompense for time.
Forese replies he was brought early by his Nella's tears and devout prayers, which drew him from the coast of lingering expectation and set him free from other circles. His widow is prized by God for her virtuous deeds. He laments that Sardinia's barb'rous tract has chaster dames than Florence. He sees a time coming when Florence's unblushing dames will be warned from the pulpit against baring bosoms. He asks what savage women needed such discipline to walk with covered limbs. He prophesies that they shall taste sorrow unless foresight cheats him, before the cheek of one now rocked asleep is clothed with down. He asks the narrator to hide himself no more, as all gaze where he veils the sun.
The narrator replies that remembering their past together may still grieve him. He attributes his change of life to Virgil, who preceded him a few evenings past. He points to Virgil, saying he brought him through the "profoundest night of the true dead" with his flesh, aiding him to climb this mountain, which rectifies what the world made crooked. He has Virgil's word that he will accompany him to Beatrice, but must leave him there. He points out Statius as the other shade for whom their realm shook with exultation when he arose.

**CANTO XXIV**
Their journey is not slackened by talk, nor talk by journeying. They speak and travel stoutly. The shadowy forms gaze at the narrator with wonder, perceiving he has life. The narrator continues, saying he journeys perhaps more tardily for others' sake. He asks if Forese knows where Piccarda is and if he sees any notable figures among the crowd.
Forese replies, "My sister (she for whom, 'Twixt beautiful and good I cannot say Which name was fitter) wears e'en now her crown, And triumphs in Olympus." He explains that due to their worn semblance from diet, it is lawful to name each one. He points out Buonaggiuna of Lucca and the face beyond him, pierced to a leaner fineness, who had keeping of the church, from Tours, purging Bolsena's eels and muscadel by abstinence.
He shows many others, all seeming content when named. The narrator sees Ubaldino grind teeth on emptiness from hunger, and Boniface wave his crozier, and the Marquis of Este, who swilled at Forli with less drought, yet was never sated. The narrator singles out the one from Lucca (Buonaggiuna), who took most note of him. He hears him whisper of Gentucca, indistinctly, where justice fixes her sting.
The narrator tells the spirit he seems to wish to speak and asks to hear him. The spirit replies, "Woman is born, Whose brow no wimple shades yet, that shall make My city please thee, blame it as they may. Go then with this forewarning. If aught false My whisper too implied, th' event shall tell." He asks if the narrator is "th' inventor of that new lay, which begins With 'Ladies, ye that con the lore of love'."
The narrator replies, "Count of me but as one Who am the scribe of love; that, when he breathes, Take up my pen, and, as he dictates, write."
The spirit replies, "Brother! the hind'rance which once held The notary with Guittone and myself, Short of that new and sweeter style I hear, Is now disclos'd. I see how ye your plumes Stretch, as th' inditer guides them; which, no question, Ours did not. He that seeks a grace beyond, Sees not the distance parts one style from other." Contented, he falls silent.
Like birds near the Nile, flying in formation, the spirits turn their visage, speeding nimbly through leanness and desire. Like a man tired from a trotting steed, Forese lingers behind, asking, "When shall I again behold thee?"
The narrator replies he knows not how long his life will last, but his wishes will arrive before him, as his city is daily scooped of good and threatened with ruin.
Forese cries, "Go now! lo! he, whose guilt is most, Passes before my vision, dragg'd at heels of an infuriate beast." He describes it speeding toward the "vale, where guilt hath no redemption," increasing swiftness until it strikes a blow, leaving a "corse most vilely shatter'd." He says not long will those wheels roll before the narrator sees what his words cannot plainly tell. He quits him, saying time is precious here.
Forese departs with lengthened strides, like a knight pricking forth to display prowess, leaving the narrator with Virgil and Statius.
When Forese is beyond sight, another fruit tree, thick hung and blooming fresh, appears. As they turn toward it, a multitude below raises hands and shouts to the boughs. Like hungry children begging, denied by one who holds the desired object aloft, they are drawn on.
At length, undeceived, they go their way. They approach the tree. Sounds from the thickets say, "Pass on, And come not near. Stands higher up the wood, Whereof Eve tasted, and from it was ta'en 'this plant'." The narrator passes forth with both bards, close to the rising side. They then hear, "Remember... those noblest creatures of the clouds, How they their twofold bosoms overgorg'd Oppos'd in fight to Theseus: call to mind The Hebrews, how effeminate they stoop'd To ease their thirst; whence Gideon's ranks were thinn'd."
They hear the sins of gluttony, reguerdoned with woe. They then travel a thousand paces along the lonely path, contemplative and mute.
Suddenly, a voice exclaims, "Why pensive journey thus ye three alone?" The narrator shakes like a scared animal and raises his head. He sees a shape as bright and glowing red as glass or metal in a furnace. "If ye desire to mount," it cries, "here must ye turn. This way he goes, Who goes in quest of peace." His countenance dazzles the narrator, who faces backward to his guides, walking as sound directs.
A gentle wind like May air, impregnated with fragrance, blows on his front. He perceives the moving of a wing shedding ambrosial smell, and then a voice: "Blessed are they, whom grace Doth so illume, that appetite in them Exhaleth no inordinate desire, Still hung'ring as the rule of temperance wills."

**CANTO XXV**
It is an hour when climbers need to walk uncrippled, as the sun has left Taurus and night left Scorpio. They enter their way, one before the other, as only singly can one climb the steep, narrow scale.
The narrator's desire to question Virgil arises and falls, like a young stork lifting its wing to fly but not venturing from the nest. Virgil, unhindered by their haste, says, "Fear not to speed the shaft, that on thy lip Stands trembling for its flight." Encouraged, the narrator asks, "How there can leanness come, Where is no want of nourishment to feed?"
Virgil replies if he remembered Meleager wasting with the wasting brand, this would not trouble him. And if he thought how his reflected form vibrates in a mirror, what seems hard would appear no harder than ripe summer fruit. But to find full repose, Virgil calls on Statius to heal his wound.
Statius answers, "If in thy presence I unfold to him The secrets of heaven's vengeance, let me plead Thine own injunction, to exculpate me." He then begins to explain: "Blood, concocted well, Which by the thirsty veins is ne'er imbib'd, And rests as food superfluous... in the heart Derives effectual virtue, that informs The several human limbs, as being that, Which passes through the veins itself to make them." More concocted, it descends where shame forbids mention, and distils in a natural vessel onto another's blood. Then each unites, one to endure, the other to act, through a recipient mold. It coagulates, then vivifies what its substance caused to bear. Indued with animation, the active virtue (differing from a plant only in being on its way, not at its limit) continues to operate, moving and feeling like a sea sponge, assuming organic powers its seed conveyed. This is the period when the virtue from the generating heart is pliable and expansive, for each limb is planned in the heart by nature. He explains how an animal becomes a babe, wiser than the protagonist's error of disjoining the soul from passive intellect because he saw no organ for it.
Statius tells the narrator to open his bosom to the truth. As soon as articulation is complete in the embryo's brain, the "primal Mover with a smile of joy" imbreathes new spirit, replete with virtue, which draws what it finds active to its own substance, forming an individual soul that lives, feels, and reflects on itself. To marvel less, he compares it to the sun's heat changing wine, mixed with moisture filtered through the vine.
When Lachesis spins the thread, the soul takes both human and divine (memory, intelligence, will), keener than before, other powers inactive. It falls to a strand where the departed roam, learning its path. The place receives her, and the plastic virtue beams, distinct as in living limbs. Like air refracting a casual beam, the ambient air wears the form imprinted by the soul. Like flame following fire, the new form follows the spirit, hence it has "semblance, and is shadow call'd," endowed with senses, speech, laughter, tears, and sighs, which the narrator may have witnessed on the mount. The obedient shadow presents whatever passion moves within them. This is the cause of what the narrator marvels at.
They reach the last flexure of their way, turning right. Other care awaits them. The rocky precipice hurls redundant flames, and an upblown blast drives them back, sequestered. They must pass one by one along the side bordering the void. The narrator fears fire on one hand, headlong fall on the other. Virgil warns, "Strict rein must in this place direct the eyes. A little swerving and the way is lost."
From the burning mass, the narrator hears "O God of mercy!" sung and feels desire to turn. He sees spirits proceeding along the flame and wishes to share his view between their footsteps and his. At the hymn's close, they shout, "I do not know a man;" then in low voice resume the strain. When that ends, they cry, "To the wood... Ran Dian, and drave forth Callisto, stung With Cytherea's poison." Then they return to their song, extolling many who lived chastely and the bonds of wedded love. They do not cease this task as long as the fire enclasps them. Such skill is needed to medicine this last-healing wound.

**CANTO XXVI**
As they walk singly along the rim, Virgil warns the narrator to look well. The sun irradiates the western clime, changing from azure to white. The narrator's shadow makes the "umber'd flame burn ruddier." Many spirits marvel at this strange sight, noting, "He seems... no insubstantial frame." They stretch toward him, careful not to pass the burning pale.
One spirit asks, "O thou, who followest The others, haply not more slow than they, But mov'd by rev'rence, answer me, who burn In thirst and fire: nor I alone, but these All for thine answer do more thirst, than doth Indian or Aethiop for the cooling stream. Tell us, how is it that thou mak'st thyself A wall against the sun, as thou not yet Into th' inextricable toils of death Hadst enter'd?"
The narrator would have declared himself, but attention turns to a new appearance. Midway the burning path, a crowd comes, and the narrator sees the shadows press forward, each snatching a hasty kiss, then away. Like ants peering one at another, perhaps to spy their mutual road.
After this greeting, before the first step onward, loud clamor rises from either tribe. Those newly come shout, "Sodom and Gomorrah!" These, "The cow Pasiphae enter'd, that the beast she woo'd Might rush unto her luxury." Like cranes flying to Riphaean mountains or Lybic sands, one crowd hastens off, the other advances, resuming their first song weeping and their shouts.
The same spirit who asked earlier approaches, eager to listen. The narrator, having noted their will twice, speaks: "O spirits secure, Whene'er the time may be, of peaceful end! My limbs, nor crude, nor in mature old age, Have I left yonder: here they bear me, fed With blood, and sinew-strung. That I no more May live in blindness, hence I tend aloft. There is a dame on high, who wind for us This grace, by which my mortal through your realm I bear." He expresses hope that their wish may soon be fulfilled, that heaven's orb may receive them. He asks them to tell who they are and who the multitude is that passed behind them, so it may be recorded on his page.
Each spirit appears like a rustic, amazed in a city. But when rid of that amaze, the one who questioned replies: "O blessed, who, for death preparing, tak'st Experience of our limits, in thy bark! Their crime, who not with us proceed, was that, For which, as he did triumph, Caesar heard The snout of 'queen,' to taunt him." (i.e. those who committed sodomy). Hence their cry of "Sodom," to rebuke themselves and aid the burning by their shame. "Our sinning was Hermaphrodite: but we, Because the law of human kind we broke, Following like beasts our vile concupiscence, Hence parting from them, to our own disgrace Record the name of her, by whom the beast In bestial tire was acted." He explains their deeds and sin. He says time doesn't permit naming them all. He identifies himself: "Guinicelli I, Who having truly sorrow'd ere my last, Already cleanse me."
The narrator feels pious joy, like two sons gazing on their mother rescued from Lycurgus, when he hears the name of his "father" and the father of those who use "sweet and pleasant rhymes of love." He listens thoughtfully, gazing on him, approaching not nearer due to the fire. When his eyes are fed, he devotes himself wholly to Guinicelli's service.
Guinicelli replies his words are deeply engraved, so Lethe shall not wash them off. He asks, since the oath has sealed the truth, what cause impels the love his looks and speech betray.
The narrator replies, "Those dulcet lays... which, as long As of our tongue the beauty does not fade, Shall make us love the very ink that trac'd them."
Guinicelli cries, "Brother!" and points to a shade before him. "there is one, whose mother speech Doth owe to him a fairer ornament. He in love ditties and the tales of prose Without a rival stands, and lets the fools Talk on, who think the songster of Limoges O'ertops him. Rumour and the popular voice They look to more than truth, and so confirm Opinion, ere by art or reason taught. Thus many of the elder time cried up Guittone, giving him the prize, till truth By strength of numbers vanquish'd." He asks the narrator, if he has gained free entrance to Christ's cloister, to say a Pater Noster for him. Guinicelli then vanishes through the fire like a fish.
The narrator approaches the spirit Guinicelli indicated and asks his name. He replies, "Thy courtesy So wins on me, I have nor power nor will To hide me. I am Arnault; and with songs, Sorely lamenting for my folly past, Thorough this ford of fire I wade, and see The day, I hope for, smiling in my view. I pray ye by the worth that guides ye up Unto the summit of the scale, in time Remember ye my suff'rings." Arnault then disappears in the refining flame.

**CANTO XXVII**
The sun is positioned as when its early radiance quivers on the heights where Christ's blood streamed (Jerusalem), while Libra hangs above the Ebro, and new fires flash on the Ganges. Day is sinking when the angel of God appears before them, joyful. He stands on the brink of the flame and sings, "Blessed are the pure In heart," with a voice of lively clearness. As they approach, he cries, "Go ye not further, holy spirits!... Ere the fire pierce you: enter in; and list Attentive to the song ye hear from thence."
The narrator, hearing this, is like one laid in the grave. He clasps his hands, looks at the fire, and conjures forms of those consumed in flames.
Virgil turns to him with gentle looks, "My son, Here torment thou mayst feel, but canst not death. Remember thee... if I Safe e'en on Geryon brought thee: now I come More near to God, wilt thou not trust me now? Of this be sure: though in its womb that flame A thousand years contain'd thee, from thy head No hair should perish. If thou doubt my truth, Approach, and with thy hands thy vesture's hem Stretch forth, and for thyself confirm belief. Lay now all fear... Turn hither, and come onward undismay'd." Still, the narrator, though conscience urged, does not advance.
Virgil, seeing him fixed, cries, "Mark now, my son, From Beatrice thou art by this wall Divided." Like Pyramus opening his eyes at Thisbe's name as life ebbed, the narrator turns to Virgil, relenting when he hears the name of Beatrice.
Virgil shakes his forehead, asks, "How long Linger we now?" then smiles like one at a child eyeing fruit. He walks into the fire before the narrator, asking Statius to come behind.
The narrator wishes he could cast himself into molten glass to cool, so intense is the conflagration. Virgil, to comfort him, talks of Beatrice, saying, "Her eyes... E'en now I seem to view." A voice singing from the other side guides them. Following the voice, they issue forth where the path leads upward. They hear, "Come... Come, blessed of my Father." These sounds hail them from within a radiant light that the narrator cannot endure. The voice adds, "The sun... hastes: and evening comes. Delay not: ere the western sky is hung With blackness, strive ye for the pass."
Their way arises upright within the rock, facing heaven. Not many stairs are passed when they perceive the sun behind them by the fading shadow. Before one face of darkness involves the horizon, each makes a stair his pallet, not because will fails, but power, forbidden further travel by the mountain's nature. Like goats ruminating under shade at noon, or a swain guarding his flock, all three abide, the narrator as a goat and the others as shepherds, pent by rock.
A glimpse of sky is seen above, showing stars with more than wonted glory. As he gazes, sleep overcomes him, bringing tidings of future hap. Around the hour when Venus first lightened on the mountain, he dreams of a young, beautiful lady passing over a lea, culling flowers and singing: "Know ye... I am Leah: for my brow to weave A garland, these fair hands unwearied ply. To please me at the crystal mirror, here I deck me.
