But my sister Rachel, she Before her glass abides the livelong day, Her radiant eyes beholding, charm'd no less, Than I with this delightful task. Her joy In contemplation, as in labour mine."
As glimmering dawn breaks, darkness and slumber flee. The narrator rises, seeing Virgil already risen. Virgil says, "That delicious fruit, Which through so many a branch the zealous care Of mortals roams in quest of, shall this day Appease thy hunger." Never did the narrator hear such pleasant sounds. Desire to mount grows, and at each step, he feels wings increasing.
When they reach the ladder's top, Virgil fixes his eyes on him, saying, "Both fires, my son, The temporal and eternal, thou hast seen, And art arriv'd, where of itself my ken No further reaches. I with skill and art Thus far have drawn thee. Now thy pleasure take For guide. Thou hast o'ercome the steeper way, O'ercome the straighter. Lo! the sun, that darts His beam upon thy forehead! lo! the herb, The arboreta and flowers, which of itself This land pours forth profuse! Till those bright eyes With gladness come, which, weeping, made me haste To succour thee, thou mayst or seat thee down, Or wander where thou wilt. Expect no more Sanction of warning voice or sign from me, Free of thy own arbitrement to choose, Discreet, judicious. To distrust thy sense Were henceforth error. I invest thee then With crown and mitre, sovereign o'er thyself."

**CANTO XXVIII**
Through the celestial forest, whose thick shade tempers the new-springing day, the narrator eagerly roams to search its limits. He leaves the bank, leisurely pursuing his way over ground breathing delicious odor. A pleasant, never-intermitted, never-veered air smites his temples. The obedient sprays lean trembling to where the mountain casts its shade, but not so disordered that feathered quiristers do not apply their art, welcoming prime hours and warbling amid the leaves, with inept tenor. He compares it to the melody rolling through piney forests on Chiassi's shore when Aeolus loosens the south wind.
His steps, though slow, carry him so far into the wood he cannot ken where he entered. His path is bounded by a rill bending to the left with rippling waters. No earthly wave is as clean as this, transpicuous, clear, yet it rolls darkly beneath perpetual gloom, admitting no sun or moonlight.
His feet advance not, but his eyes pass over the streamlet to survey the tender May-bloom. He then beholds a lady all alone, singing and culling flowers. The narrator addresses her, "Lady beautiful! Thou, who... with love's own beam Dost warm thee... Ah! please thee hither towards the streamlet bend Thy steps so near, that I may list thy song. Beholding thee and this fair place, methinks, I call to mind where wander'd and how look'd Proserpine, in that season, when her child The mother lost, and she the bloomy spring."
Like a lady turning in a dance, she turns at his suit, maiden-like, veiling her eyes, and comes so near he distinctly catches her dulcet sound. Arriving where the limpid waters lave the sward, she raises her eyes, shooting splendor on him. She stands on the opposite bank and smiles, her fingers shifting the intermingling dyes which that lofty land unbosoms without seed. Only three paces separate them, yet the flood is as hateful to him as the Hellespont to Leander, because it gives no passage.
She says, "Strangers ye come... Wond'ring, ye not without suspicion view My smiles: but that sweet strain of psalmody, 'Thou, Lord! hast made me glad,' will give ye light, Which may uncloud your minds." She asks if he wishes to hear anything else, as she came to answer every doubt.
The narrator replies he doesn't know how to reconcile this wave and rustling sound with what he heard of opposite report (i.e. of the mountain being bare). She replies she will unfold the cause and purge the cloud that enwraps him. The "First Good," whose joy is in himself, created man for happiness and gave this place as a pledge of eternal peace. Man fell through his own defect, changing laughter to sorrow. To prevent vapors from ascending to vex man's peaceful state, this mountain rose so high, exempted from elemental rage where the gate bars its limit. Because the circumambient air circles with its first impulse, it strikes the summit (open to impassive air), making the wood resound. The shaken plant impregnates the voyaging breeze, which flies abroad, and the other land receives it, conceiving and producing varied trees. This explains how some plants appear without seed on earth. This holy plain is filled with "prolific foison of all seeds" and bears fruit never plucked elsewhere. The water he beholds springs not from veins but from a solid, undecaying fountain, its full supply fed by omnific will. It pours on one side with power to remove remembrance of offense (Lethe), on the other to bring back remembrance of good deeds (Eunoe). Both must be tasted. She states his thirst may be content even if she stops, but she offers a corollary: poets of old may have dreamed of this place when recording the golden age. Here was man guiltless, here perpetual spring, every fruit, and the far-famed nectar.
Turning to the bards, she ceases. The narrator notes their smile. He then directs his face to the lady again.

**CANTO XXIX**
Singing, as if enamored, she resumes and closes the song with, "Blessed they whose sins are cover'd." Like wood-nymphs, she moves on against the current, up the verdant rivage. The narrator observes her mincing step, pursuing with as tardy a step.
Not a hundred paces separate them when she turns and cries, "My brother! look and hearken." A sudden lustre runs across the great forest, so bright the narrator doubts it's lightning, but it endures and waxes, and sweet melody runs through the luminous air. He chides the hardihood of "our first parent," for woman, the creature of an hour, endured not restraint of any veil when earth obeyed heaven. Had she borne it devoutly, "joys, ineffable as these, Had from the first, and long time since, been mine."
He walks through the wilderness of "primy sweets" that never fade, expectant of higher beatitude. Before them, the air under green boughs glows like a blazing fire, and distinct melody is heard. He invokes the thrice-holy virgins and Helicon and Urania for aid to unfold things that mock thought.
A space onward, what seem like seven trees of gold falsely appear due to distance. Closer, his faculty distinguishes them as "tapers of gold" and traces "Hosanna" in the singing. Their garniture flames with more ample lustre than the moon.
The narrator turns to Virgil, who shows no less amazement. His view reverts to the lofty things moving so slowly that a bride would outstrip them. The lady calls aloud, "Why thus yet burns Affection in thee for these living, lights, And dost not look on that which follows them?"
The narrator marks a tribe walking behind them, attendant on their leaders, clothed in such white raiment as never seen on earth. The watery gleam on his left reflects his left side as in a mirror.
He chooses a station on the river's edge, separated only by the stream, to gain clearer prospect. He beholds the flames go onward, painting the air behind them with trails of "liveliest pencils," distinctly marked with "sev'n listed colours" like the sun's bow and Cynthia's zone. These streaming gonfalons flow beyond his vision. Ten paces apart, "foul and-twenty elders," two by two, crowned with flower-de-luces, sing, "Blessed be thou among The daughters of Adam! and thy loveliness Blessed for ever!" After these, four animals follow, each crowned with verdurous leaf, with six wings full of eyes. The narrator refers to Ezekiel for their form, noting John agrees except on the pennons.
The space enclosed by the four animals holds a triumphal car, drawn by a Gryphon. The Gryphon stretches its uplifted wings between the middle and the three listed hues on each side (three on each side), rising out of sight. Its bird-like members are golden, the rest white with vermeil. This car surpasses any Roman pomp. Three nymphs circle at the right wheel: one ruddy like flame, one like emerald flesh and bones, the third like new-fallen snow. The white seems to lead, then the ruddy, and the others take their treasure (song) from her who leads. At the other wheel, a quaternion band, clad in purple, advances festively, one leading with "Three eyes." In rear, two old men, dissimilar in raiment but alike in port, grave. One shows himself a favored counselor of the "great Coan" (Hippocrates), whom nature made to serve the costliest creature. His fellow (Seneca or Ovid), bearing a sword, frightens the narrator. Next, four others of humble seeming. And behind them all, one single old man, sleeping, with a shrewd visage. These seven are like the first troop but wear no lilies, only roses and vermeil flowers.
When the car is opposite, a thundering sound is heard, staying the chosen multitude. They halt with the first ensigns.

**CANTO XXX**
The "polar light," which never knows setting or rising, stands fixed. The saintly tribe before the Gryphon turns to the car. One, as if from above, shouts thrice, "Come, spouse, from Libanus!" and the rest take up the song. The narrator compares this to the blessed rising at the last audit. "Blessed thou! who com'st!" they cry, scattering "unwith'ring lilies."
The narrator sees at break of day the eastern clime all roseate and the sky serene. So, in a cloud of angelic flowers, a virgin appears, veiled in white with an olive wreath, beneath a green mantle, robed in living flame.
No terror creeps over his spirit, which long abode in her presence. His eyes no longer know her, yet a hidden virtue from her awakens the power of "ancient love" within him.
The heavenly influence, which thrilled him in childhood, smites him. He turns leftward to Virgil, panting like a babe for refuge, wanting to cry that "no dram of blood" does not quiver, the old flame showing tokens of reviving fire. But Virgil has gone, leaving him. His cheeks are blurred with soiling tears.
A voice says, "Dante, weep not, that Virgil leaves thee: nay, Weep thou not yet: behooves thee feel the edge Of other sword, and thou shalt weep for that."
Like an admiral pacing the deck, inspiring his crew, the narrator sees the virgin (Beatrice) stationed on the left side of the car, turning at the sound of his own name. Her veil, bound with Minerva's foliage, prevents him from seeing her clearly. With royal act, insulting over her thrall, she adds, "Observe me well. I am, in sooth, I am Beatrice. What! and hast thou deign'd at last Approach the mountain? knewest not, O man! Thy happiness is whole?"
The narrator's eyes fall on the clear fount, but seeing himself, he recoils to the greensward, burdened by shame. She looks with stern majesty, like a mother to an awe-struck child, with a bitter flavor mingled in her pity. She breaks off, and the angels sing, "In thee, O gracious Lord, my hope hath been," but go no further than, "Thou Lord, hast set My feet in ample room."
The narrator compares himself to snow melting in the sun, without a sigh or tear until the angels sing their sweet symphony, expressing soft compassion. Then the ice in his bosom turns to spirit and water, gushing forth from lips and eyelids.
Beatrice stands immovable on the chariot's right edge, addressing the pity-touched bright semblances. She states that they keep vigil in eternal day, so she shapes her answer for the weeping narrator, so his sorrow may equal his transgression. Not only through the "mighty orbs" and constellations, but through "benign Largess of heav'nly graces," he was gifted in the freshness of his being, so all better habits thrived. The more strength in the soil, the more evil seed and lack of culture mar it. Her looks sometimes upheld him, as she showed her youthful eyes and led him by their light. But as she reached the "threshold of my second age" (death) and changed mortal for immortal, he left her and gave himself to others. With increased beauty and virtue, she was less dear to him. His steps turned to deceitful ways, following false images of good. Her inspirations, in dreams and otherwise, availed not. He fell so deep that nothing could preserve him except seeing "the children of perdition." To this end, she visited the "purlieus of the dead," and one (Virgil) received her weeping supplications. She states it would be a breaking of God's decree if Lethe were passed and tasted "Without the cost of some repentant tear."

**CANTO XXXI**
Beatrice resumes her words, turning their point on the narrator, who previously felt them only with a lateral edge. "Say thou, who stand'st beyond the holy stream, If this be true. A charge so grievous needs Thine own avowal." The narrator is so amazed his voice expires imperfectly.
After a pause, she asks, "What dost thou muse on? Answer me. The wave On thy remembrances of evil yet Hath done no injury." A mixed sense of fear and confusion produces a "Yea" that needs vision to interpret. Like a crossbow over-bent, the narrator bursts beneath the heavy load with tears and sighs, his voice slackened.
She asks, "When my desire invited thee to love The good, which sets a bound to our aspirings, What bar of thwarting foss or linked chain Did meet thee, that thou so should'st quit the hope Of further progress, or what bait of ease Or promise of allurement led thee on Elsewhere, that thou elsewhere should'st rather wait?"
The narrator draws a bitter sigh, then wailingly answers, "Thy fair looks withdrawn, Things present, with deceitful pleasures, turn'd My steps aside." She replies, "Hadst thou Been silent, or denied what thou avow'st, Thou hadst not hid thy sin the more: such eye Observes it." But when the sinner's cheek breaks into tears of self-accusing, justice's wheel runs counter to the edge in their court. To profit by his shame and arm him with strength against the Siren-voice, she bids him lay aside grief and listen as she unfolds "how opposite a way my buried flesh should have impell'd thee." He never spied anything so sweet in art or nature as her limbs, now scattered in dust. If the sweetest thing failed him with her death, what mortal thing should tempt his wish afterward? When he felt the dart of perishable things upon her death, he should have pruned his wing to follow her, not stooped again "to 'bide a second blow for a slight girl, Or other gaud as transient and as vain." The new bird awaits the fowler's aim twice or thrice, but for a full-plumed one, the net is spread in vain.
The narrator stands silent and ashamed like a child, acknowledging his fault. She resumes, "If, but to hear thus pains thee, Raise thou thy beard, and lo! what sight shall do!"
With less reluctance than a sturdy oak is rent by a blast, the narrator raises his visage. By the beard, he notes the secret sting of her words.
No sooner does he lift his aspect than the vision of "goodly creatures" vanishes. His eyes, wavering, bend their light on Beatrice. She turns toward the Gryphon (the animal with two natures), and even under her veil and parted by the rill, her loveliness surpasses her former self as much as she surpassed others on earth. Remorseful goads shoot through him. Everything else that had beguiled him is now loathsome. The bitter consciousness smites his heart, and he falls to the ground. She who caused it knows his state.
When his strength returns, he finds the lady he first saw (Matilda) above him. She cries, "Loose me not... Loose not thy hold;" and drags him up to his neck into the stream, sweeping along swift as a shuttle.
Approaching the blessed shore, "Tu asperges me" is heard sung so sweetly the narrator cannot remember or tell the sound. The beautiful dame, expanding her arms, clasps his temples and immerses him where the wave should drench him. Raising him, she presents him within the "fourfold dance of lovely nymphs," who cover him with their arm. They say, "Here are we nymphs, And in the heav'n are stars." Before Beatrice visited earth, they were appointed her handmaids. They will lead him to her eyes, but the three yonder, of deeper ken, will quicken his sight to scan the light of gladness in them.
They begin their song and lead him to the Gryphon's breast, where Beatrice stands turned toward them. "Spare not thy vision. We have stationed thee Before the emeralds, whence love erewhile Hath drawn his weapons on thee." As they speak, a thousand wishes rivet his eyes on her beaming eyes, fixed on the motionless Gryphon. As the sun strikes a mirror, the Gryphon's twofold being shines within Beatrice's orbs, ever varying, now reflected in one figure, now in another. The narrator muses on this wondrous sight.
Full of amaze and joy, his soul feeding on the viand, the other three nymphs, with gestures of loftier line, advance, dancing in a festive, angelic ring. They sing, "Turn, Beatrice!... O turn Thy saintly sight on this thy faithful one, Who to behold thee many a wearisome pace Hath measur'd. Gracious at our pray'r vouchsafe Unveil to him thy cheeks: that he may mark Thy second beauty, now conceal'd." The narrator exclaims at her splendor, beyond human representation when her charms were revealed under "cope of the still-chiming heaven."

**CANTO XXXII**
The narrator's eyes are bent with eager coveting to rid them of their ten years' thirst for Beatrice. No other sense is waking, and even his eyes are fenced from heed of aught else, so tangled by Beatrice's saintly smile. Forcibly, the sacred virgins turn his sight to the left, warning, "Too fix'd a gaze!"
His vision labors like eyes strained by the sun. But soon recovering, he marks the "glorious army" wheel and turn on their right, facing the sun and sevenfold lights. Like a well-ranged troop with raised bucklers wheeling, the "goodly regiment of heav'n" passes, before the car slopes its beam. The damsels turn at the wheels, and the sacred burden on the Gryphon moves with a smooth pace. The fair dame who drew him through the wave (Matilda), accompanied by Statius and himself, pursues the wheel.
He passes through the high wood, now void. Beatrice descends from her station. All murmur "Adam," circling a plant despoiled of flowers and leaves. Its tresses, spreading as they rise, are so tall Indians might gaze at them. The spirits shout, "Blessed thou! Gryphon, whose beak hath never pluck'd that tree Pleasant to taste: for hence the appetite Was warp'd to evil." The Gryphon replies, "Yea: for so The generation of the just are sav'd." Turning to the chariot-pole, he draws it to the foot of the widowed branch and binds it to the stock where it grew.
As radiance from above, mingled with that from the setting scaly sign (Scorpio), makes plants burgeon, so the plant, once bare, is renewed with a hue fainter than rose, deeper than violet.
An unearthly hymn arises. The narrator does not understand or endure its harmony. He wishes he could describe his falling into sleep. He passes to his waking, telling how a flash of splendor rends his sleep, and one cries, "Arise, what dost thou?" Like the chosen three on Tabor's mount, who saw the blossoming tree (Christ) and awoke to find Moses and Elias gone, so the narrator awakens to find the "piteous one" (Matilda) standing over him.
He exclaims, "And where... Is Beatrice?" She replies, "See her... Beneath the fresh leaf seated on its root. Behold th' associate choir that circles her. The others, with a melody more sweet And more profound, journeying to higher realms, Upon the Gryphon tend." Whether her words close here, he knows not, but his eyes now view Beatrice, barring other thoughts. She sits alone on the ground, guarding the wain bound to the twyform beast. The seven nymphs form a cloister around her, holding lights safe from winds.
Beatrice says, "A little while thou shalt be forester here: And citizen shalt be forever with me, Of that true Rome, wherein Christ dwells a Roman." To profit the misguided world, she tells him to keep his eyes on the car and write what he sees upon returning to the world.
The narrator, inclining at her feet, directs his thought and eyes as she bids. He sees the "bird of Jove" (eagle) descending with swift motion, pouncing on the tree, crushing rind, buds, and leaflets. It strikes the car, making it reel like a ship.
Next, a fox, hunger-pined, springs into the chariot's womb. But the "saintly maid" (Beatrice) rebukes him, and he scampers away. Then the eagle darts into the hull, leaving it lined with feathers. A voice from heaven, like a heart rived with sorrow, cries, "O poor bark of mine! How badly art thou freighted!" Then earth opens, and a dragon issues, fixing its forked train through the chariot, then dragging part of the bottom forth, exulting.
What remains of the car clothes itself with plumes, green as lively turf, which perhaps had been offered with chaste purpose. The wheels and beam are clothed quickly. The holy structure puts forth heads: three on the beam (horned like oxen) and one on each side (with a single horn). Over it sits a "shameless whore" (papacy), her ken roving loosely. At her side stands a giant (French monarchy), mingling kisses with her. But her lustful eyes wander to the narrator, and the "fell minion" (giant) scourges her from head to foot. Full of jealousy and rage, he unlooses the monster (chariot) and drags it so far across the forest that its shades alone shield the harlot and the new-formed brute.

**CANTO XXXIII**
The trinal and quaternion virgin bands begin their sweet psalmody, weeping, "The heathen, Lord! are come!" Beatrice listens, sad and sighing. When they give her place to speak, she rises, glowing bright as fire, and answers, "Yet a little while, and ye Shall see me not; and, my beloved sisters, Again a little while, and ye shall see me."
She then marshals the seven nymphs, beckoning the narrator and Statius to follow. She passes on, and before her tenth step, her eyes meet the narrator's. With a mild visage, she cries, "So mend thy pace... that if my words Address thee, thou mayst still be aptly plac'd To hear them."
As the narrator hastens to her side, she asks, "Brother! Why mak'st thou no attempt at questioning, As thus we walk together?" The narrator, speaking with reverence, answers imperfectly, "Lady! what I have need of, that thou know'st, And what will suit my need."
She replies she wills him to rid himself of fearfulness and shame, to speak no more as one who dreams. She tells him, "Thus far be taught of me: The vessel, which thou saw'st the serpent break, Was and is not: let him, who hath the blame, Hope not to scare God's vengeance with a sop." She prophesies that the eagle (Empire) will not be without an heir forever, and the foul whore and her accomplice giant will be slain. She plainly views the approaching stars whose conjunction will bring a season when "one sent from God, (Five hundred, five, and ten, do mark him out)" will slay them. If her dark saying fails to persuade, "ere long Events shall be the Naiads, that will solve This knotty riddle." She tells him to take heed and teach these words to those who live "that life, which is a race to death." When he writes, he must not conceal how he has seen the plant (tree of justice) "that twice hath now been spoil'd." Whoever robs or plucks it sins against God, who hallowed it for His sole use. For taste of this, the first soul (Adam) yearned in pain and desire for "five thousand years and upward."
She states his reason slumbers if it deems the plant's inverted height without due cause. If "vainer thoughts" had not dyed his soul dark, he would have seen "God's equal justice morally implied in the forbidden tree." But since his understanding is hardened to stone, she wants him to take it painted, if not written, in him.
The narrator replies his brain is stamped by her like wax by a seal. He asks why her speech soars beyond his sight. She answers, "To the end That thou mayst know... the school, That thou hast follow'd; and how far behind, When following my discourse, its learning halts: And mayst behold your art, from the divine As distant, as the disagreement is 'Twixt earth and heaven's most high and rapturous orb."
The narrator replies he doesn't remember being estranged from her, nor does conscience chide him. Smiling, she tells him to recall drinking Lethe's wave, and "in that forgetfulness itself conclude Blame from thy alienated will incurr'd." She promises her words will be "as naked as will suit them to appear in thy unpractis'd view."
The sun, sparkling more, possesses the mid-day circle. The seven-fold band pauses at the verge of a "dun umbrage hoar," like an alpine cliff. Before them, Tigris and Euphrates seem to issue from one fountain, lingering at parting. The narrator asks what water this is. They tell him to entreat Matilda.
Matilda replies she has taught him this and more, and Lethe's water has not hidden it from him. Beatrice says that some pressing care has darkened his mind's eye. She points to Eunoe, telling Matilda to lead him there to revive his fainting virtue. Matilda, like a courteous spirit, takes the narrator and calls to Statius to come with him.
The narrator wishes he could sing of that beverage (Eunoe). But since the leaves for this second strain are full, his art checks him. He returns from the "most holy wave, regenerate, E'en as new plants renew'd with foliage new, Pure and made apt for mounting to the stars."

**PARADISE**

**CANTO I**
The glory of God, whose might moves all things, pierces the universe, shedding more resplendence in one part, less elsewhere. The narrator was in heaven, which partakes most largely of this light, witnessing things beyond words to relate. His intellect is so absorbed memory cannot follow, but he will sing of what he stored in thought.
He invokes Apollo for aid, asking to be made a vessel of his worth, as his laurel claims. He says one brow of Parnassus sufficed him so far (for Hell and Purgatory), but now both are needed. He asks Apollo to breathe in his bosom, as when Marsyas was flayed. If Apollo imparts enough power, the narrator will crown himself with laurel at the tree's foot. He notes that if Caesar or bard seldom gather wreaths, joy must spring to Apollo when one breast is inspired with such thirst. From a small spark, great flame has risen; perhaps others will follow with better voice.

Nick Carraway, the narrator, recounts his experiences after moving East in the spring of 1922 to work in the bond business. He establishes his habit of reserving judgment, a trait he attributes to his father, but notes an exception for Jay Gatsby, the man for whom he holds "unaffected scorn" yet admires for his "extraordinary gift for hope."

Nick rents a small house in West Egg, Long Island, situated next to an opulent mansion owned by the mysterious Mr. Gatsby. He soon visits his second cousin, Daisy Buchanan, and her wealthy, arrogant, and physically imposing husband, Tom Buchanan, at their elaborate Georgian Colonial mansion in the more fashionable East Egg. At their home, Nick also meets Jordan Baker, a professional golfer. During dinner, Tom expresses racist views about the "Nordic race" and discusses a book he's read. Daisy, displaying a facade of cynical sadness, expresses a wish that her daughter would be a "beautiful little fool." A phone call interrupts dinner, revealing Tom's affair to Nick. Miss Baker confirms that Tom "has some woman in New York." Nick observes Daisy's underlying unhappiness and Jordan's "incurable dishonesty," having recalled a past scandal involving her moving a golf ball during a tournament. As Nick leaves, Daisy asks about a false rumor of his engagement. That night, Nick sees Gatsby for the first time, standing on his lawn, stretching his arms toward a distant green light across the bay.

Soon after, Tom takes Nick to the "valley of ashes," a desolate industrial wasteland, where they stop at a garage owned by George B. Wilson, a "spiritless man." Tom introduces Nick to Wilson's wife, Myrtle, who is also Tom's mistress. Myrtle is a vibrant, sensuous woman in her mid-thirties. Tom arranges to meet her in New York, and she quickly joins them, changing into a more elaborate dress and buying a dog. They go to a small apartment Tom keeps for Myrtle in the city. Guests arrive, including Myrtle's sister, Catherine, and Mr. and Mrs. McKee. Myrtle's personality transforms, becoming haughty and artificial in her new dress. Catherine reveals to Nick a rumor that Gatsby is a relative of Kaiser Wilhelm and that Daisy is Catholic, preventing Tom from divorcing her to marry Myrtle (a detail Nick knows to be false about Daisy). Myrtle recounts her regret over marrying Wilson, whom she thought was a gentleman but who borrowed a suit for their wedding. The party becomes increasingly chaotic as they drink heavily. Late in the evening, during an argument, Myrtle repeatedly shouts Daisy's name, provoking Tom to violently break her nose with his open hand. Nick leaves the chaotic scene with Mr. McKee.

Nick attends one of Gatsby's extravagant, uninvited parties, the first time he's been genuinely invited. He feels out of place among the hundreds of guests, many of whom don't know Gatsby and spread wild rumors about him (e.g., that he killed a man, was a German spy). Nick eventually finds Jordan Baker, and they join a group where more rumors about Gatsby are discussed. In Gatsby's library, they encounter a drunk man with "owl-eyed" spectacles, marveling that the books are real. Later, Nick meets Gatsby himself, a young man about thirty, who has a captivating smile and a formal but slightly absurd way of speaking. Gatsby is called away for a phone call. Jordan tells Nick Gatsby claims to be an Oxford man, but she doubts it. Nick observes Gatsby's isolation at his own party. Gatsby's butler later requests Jordan Baker for a private conversation. She emerges an hour later, amazed by what she heard but sworn to secrecy, and cryptically suggests Nick call her. As Nick leaves the party, he witnesses a car crash outside Gatsby's gate, involving the "owl-eyed man" and another drunken guest.

One morning, Gatsby picks Nick up in his luxurious yellow car. Gatsby attempts to tell Nick about his past, claiming to be from a wealthy, deceased Middle Western family, educated at Oxford (though he slips and says San Francisco), and a decorated war hero. He shows Nick a medal from Montenegro and an old Oxford photograph as proof. Gatsby then reveals that he has a "big request" for Nick, which Jordan Baker will explain. On their drive to the city, Gatsby speeds past a policeman, showing a white card to avoid a ticket, hinting at powerful connections. Gatsby and Nick have lunch with Meyer Wolfshiem, a gambler who reveals his cuff links are made of human molars and who admits to having "fixed the World's Series back in 1919." Gatsby abruptly leaves when Tom Buchanan appears at the restaurant, avoiding a direct confrontation.

Later that afternoon, Jordan Baker reveals Gatsby's true motive to Nick: Gatsby bought his mansion specifically to be across the bay from Daisy, near the green light at the end of her dock. He wants Nick to invite Daisy to tea at Nick's house so Gatsby can "come over" and for Daisy to see his house. Jordan recounts her past with Daisy: In 1917, Daisy Fay, then eighteen, was in love with a young officer named Jay Gatsby in Louisville. On the night before her wedding to Tom Buchanan, Daisy got drunk, clutching a letter, and wanted to call off the wedding, but was prevented. She married Tom the next day. A week after their honeymoon, Tom crashed his car with another woman in it. Daisy later recognized Gatsby's name when Jordan mentioned it. Nick, now understanding Gatsby's long-held dream, develops feelings for Jordan.

Nick invites Daisy to tea at his house, warning her not to bring Tom. Gatsby, extremely nervous and pale, makes elaborate preparations, sending his gardener to cut Nick's grass and a "greenhouse" of flowers. Daisy arrives, and her initial reunion with Gatsby is awkward and strained. After Nick leaves them alone for a while, he returns to find them radiantly happy, Daisy in tears of joy. Gatsby then takes them on a tour of his mansion, during which he briefly contradicts his earlier story of inherited wealth, claiming it took him three years to earn the money, and then vaguely states he was in the "drug business and then ... the oil business." Daisy is moved by his collection of expensive shirts and cries into them, saying they're "such beautiful shirts." Gatsby points out the green light on Daisy's dock from his window, reflecting that its symbolic significance has vanished now that his dream is realized. He shows Nick a photograph of Dan Cody, his deceased mentor. Gatsby receives a mysterious phone call hinting at illegal business. He has his "boarder," Klipspringer, play the piano. Nick observes that Daisy "tumbled short of his dreams," as Gatsby's illusion had grown "beyond her, beyond everything." Gatsby confides in Nick, expressing his desire for Daisy to tell Tom she never loved him, and then they would return to Louisville to marry as if five years had passed. Gatsby believes he "can repeat the past." Nick recalls Gatsby's memory of kissing Daisy five years prior, which completed his "incarnation."

Gatsby's lavish parties abruptly cease. He dismisses his original servants and hires new ones, connected to Wolfshiem, to prevent gossip because Daisy now visits him frequently. Tom, Nick, Jordan, Daisy, and Gatsby gather for lunch at the Buchanan's, a tense affair on a "broiling" hot day. Daisy openly kisses Gatsby in front of Nick and Jordan and tells him she loves him, which Tom notices with astonishment. Daisy's young daughter, Pammy, is brought into the room, and Gatsby looks at her with surprise, as if he never truly believed in her existence. Tom, agitated by Daisy's declaration of love for Gatsby, insists they all go to town. Daisy suggests they take Gatsby's yellow car, but Tom, suspecting Gatsby's intentions, insists on driving Gatsby's car with Jordan and Nick, while Gatsby and Daisy follow in Tom's blue coupé.

On the way to town, Tom confronts Nick and Jordan about Gatsby, revealing he's been investigating him. He accuses Gatsby of being a bootlegger, selling grain alcohol through "drugstores," and being associated with Meyer Wolfshiem. They stop for gas at Wilson's garage in the valley of ashes. George Wilson, looking ill and desperate, tells Tom he needs money because he's "wised up to something funny" and wants to take Myrtle and move West. Myrtle, from an upstairs window, watches their car and mistakenly believes Jordan Baker is Tom's wife, consumed by "jealous terror."

In a suite at the Plaza Hotel, Tom openly confronts Gatsby, accusing him of being a criminal and a "swindler." Gatsby forces Daisy to confess to Tom that she never loved him, but she falters, admitting she "did love him once—but I loved you too." Tom, regaining control, further exposes Gatsby's illegal businesses, mentioning a past associate, Walter Chase, whom Gatsby supposedly left to go to jail. Daisy, terrified and overwhelmed, begs to leave. Tom, triumphant, tells Daisy to drive home with Gatsby in Gatsby's car, declaring Gatsby's "flirtation is over." Nick, realizing it's his 30th birthday, and Jordan leave with Tom in the coupé.

On the return trip through the valley of ashes, they encounter a chaotic scene: Myrtle Wilson has been struck and killed by a car. Michaelis, a coffee shop owner, witnessed Myrtle run into the road, waving and shouting, and be hit by a "death car." A witness confirms it was a "big yellow car." Tom is horrified to find Myrtle dead. Wilson, consumed by grief, cries out. Tom quickly deflects suspicion from himself and his blue car by stating the yellow car wasn't his and he had just arrived from New York. Nick later sees Daisy and Tom together in their kitchen, seemingly "conspiring together," a picture of "natural intimacy," despite not having touched their food. Gatsby is waiting outside their house, telling Nick that Daisy was driving his car when she hit Myrtle, and he will take the blame. He waits outside all night to ensure Tom doesn't harm Daisy.

The next morning, Nick goes to Gatsby's house. Gatsby confesses that Daisy turned out the light in her room around four o'clock. He then recounts his true past: he was a penniless young man who fell in love with Daisy, leading him to pretend to be from her social class and possessing wealth to win her. After he went to war, Daisy, pressured by her social world, chose to marry Tom Buchanan for his "wholesome bulkiness" and secure position. Gatsby frantically tried to return home but was sent to Oxford instead. He later made a "miserable but irresistible journey" to Louisville, revisiting their old haunts, feeling he had lost her forever.

On what becomes his last morning, Gatsby is still hopeful Daisy will call. Nick tells Gatsby that he is "worth the whole damn bunch put together," a compliment Nick later feels glad to have given despite his disapproval of Gatsby. Gatsby puts on his bathing suit and goes to the pool on a pneumatic mattress, instructing his butler to bring any phone calls there. His chauffeur later hears shots. Nick, the chauffeur, butler, and gardener find Gatsby's body floating dead in the pool, shot. Wilson's body is found nearby in the grass.

The narrative shifts to the aftermath of Myrtle's death. Michaelis, who stayed with Wilson, discovers Wilson's growing suspicion about the yellow car and his wife's infidelity, confirmed by an expensive dog leash he found. Wilson, believing the driver of the yellow car murdered Myrtle because she ran out to speak to him, stares at the eyes of Doctor T. J. Eckleburg, declaring "God sees everything." Wilson eventually tracks Gatsby to his house and kills him before taking his own life.

In the wake of the "holocaust," Nick feels responsible as Daisy and Tom have vanished, leaving no address. Meyer Wolfshiem refuses to attend the funeral, claiming "important business" and a policy against getting "mixed up" in deaths. A phone call meant for Gatsby implies his involvement in illegal bond activities. Gatsby's elderly father, Henry C. Gatz, arrives from Minnesota, bringing a picture of Gatsby's house and a childhood book, "Hopalong Cassidy," with Gatsby's youthful "General Resolves" and self-improvement schedule written on the flyleaf. Despite Nick's efforts, almost no one attends Gatsby's funeral except Nick, Mr. Gatz, the minister, and the "owl-eyed man." Klipspringer calls, not for the funeral, but to retrieve his tennis shoes.

Nick, disillusioned by the East, decides to return West. He breaks off his relationship with Jordan Baker, who accuses him of being dishonest. He encounters Tom Buchanan, who defiantly admits to telling Wilson that Gatsby owned the yellow car, believing Gatsby deserved it and was a "coward" for not stopping after hitting Myrtle. Nick concludes that Tom and Daisy are "careless people" who "smashed up things and creatures" and then retreated into their wealth, leaving others to clean up their mess. Nick visits Gatsby's empty house one last time, reflecting on Gatsby's unwavering dream for Daisy and the "green light" that represented his "orgiastic future." He concludes that humanity "beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past."
